Hills, also requested in her handwrit­ ten will that she he buried next to her husband, Ike West, in the Alamo Ma­ sonic- Cemetery at North Pine and East 
Commerce streets. 
A spokesman for the Masons said late Friday he has no objections to the woman’s request.

Married couples may get tax break 

 w a s h i n g t o n p o s t s c n v ic t 
WASHINGTON — The Senate 
Finance Committee Friday ap­ proved by voice vote a plan to cut the taxes of about two-thirds of all taxpayers an average of 
Sill, beginning this year. 
The plan, which would affect only those who take standard deductions, would also ratse the taxes of an esti­ mated 2.1 million single taxpayers — about 3 pct cent of all taxpayers — an average of $52. 
The unanimous action came as the committee continued work on P resi­ dent C arter’s House-passed tax-eut hill to pep up the econom y. C h airm an 
R ussell B. Long. D-Lu.. said he thought the com m ittee would finish 
Monday. 
The tax cut would be achieved through a c hange in the standard de­ duction that is taken by nearly Til per cent of all taxpayers — those who do not itemize their deduc tions 
Under present law this deduction is 
18 per cent of adjusted gross income — total income for most taxpayers — subject to certain m in im u m s and maximums. 
The minimums are $1 .TDD for single taxpayers and heads of household — unmarried taxpayers with dependents 
— and $2,1oo for married couples filing joint r e tu rn s The m a x im u m s are 
$2.4o(1 and $2,8oo. 
Proposal 
The President proposed that this be changed to a flat deduction of $2,2oo for single* taxpayers and $3.(MKI for joint returns. But that would have meant a small tax increase for single taxpayers now at the $2,4oo maximum, so the 
House voted for $2,4oo and $3.OOO instead 
Those am ounts in the House bill, however, would increase the ’‘m a r ­ riage penalty’’ for many taxpayers. 
Already, when two single taxpayers taking the sta n d ard deduction get m arrie d , they lose som e deduction dollars. lf they take the m inim um standard d ed u ction, for ex a m p le , before m a r­ riage they will Im* able to deduct $3,4oo 
— $1,7oo each — and after marriage

Brown: Union is incompatible with discipline 

WASHINGTON (AP) - Military un­ ions could play havoc with the com ­ mand system. Defense Secretary Ha­ rold Brown told Congress on Friday. 
“The functional role of our arm ed forces demands absolute certainty of immediate aud total responsiveness to lawful orders.’’ he told a Senate Armed 
Services Committee hearing. 
Collective bargaining in the military is fundamentally incompatible with the need for an unencumbered com­ mand and control system, he said. 
But Brown declined to endorse either of two bills pending before the Senate 
Armed Services Committee to provide crim in al p enalties for joining or soliciting m e m b ersh ip in unions among military personnel. 
He suggested at one point that a ban against mcmt>crs of the armed forces

 joining a union might be unconstitu­ tional 
Navy Secretary VV Graham Clay tor 
-lr. said unions would be especially inappropriate on ships, where the cap­ tain has lo be supreme. 
But he said lie, too, recognized that prohibiting m em bership in a union raise s d ifficult F irs t A m endm ent problems. 
Chairman John C. Stenms, D-Miss., urged Defense Department officials to 
“ make up your minds which way you are going.” Stenms is author of one of the pending bills 
Brown said the Defense Department already has a policy forbidding any officer or civilian employe from nego­ tiating with anyone over term s and conditions of military service. 
He said a new directive has been drafted and will be issued if necessary, barring the solicitation of union m em ­ bership on military bases. 
Up to now, however, Brown said he has not considered it necessary to ban solicitation, because individual base com manders have that right within their authority to maintain discipline 
Brown indicated he would support a statute to back a ban against on-base union organizing. But he said further legislation should be a p p ro a ch ed cautiously in the light of the first am endm ent’s protections of speech and association

2 /3 mark 

 s n c i A i t o tm i l i n o s n i w s 
KINGSVILLE — Although his pulled hamstring is acting up. Albert Kodri* I gut*/ has completed two-thirds of his pilgrimage/run to San Juan 
Rodriguez, a University of Texas at I 
San Antonio police officer, is running fj on behalf of his 5-year-old daughter, I 
Stephanie, and all other mentally re- ? turded children 
Rodriguez started out early Friday ; 
-morning from IO miles north of Rob- ; stown and went 18 miles south of : 
Riviera He has completed 21o miles of the 32o-mile journey. 
“ He is still wearing a leg brace to relieve the pressure from a pulled hamstring,” said Denise Barnhill of the Bexar County Mental Health/Men­ tal Retardation Center, 
Thursday night. Rodriguez was pre­ sented the key to Corpus Christi by the 
Nueces County sheriff, the Corpus 
Christi mayor and the director (ti the state hospital 
R odriguez was d riv en back to 
Kingsville ti* spend Friday night He will be driven hack Saturday to the spot where he stopped running Friday. 
The runner hopes to reach Harlingen 
Saturday night and the Church til 
Miracles i i i San Juan Sunday noon

Bexar voter registration list hits record 394,635 

Help a Scout do a good turn fo r the handicapped at Goodwill! 

Voter registration in Bexar County has reach ed a record 
394.835, according to figures released Friday. 
With an estimated 538 IHM) persons eligible to vote, the count shows 71 per cent are on the nills. 
All figures came from data collected and processed by the county’s voter registration departm ent under the supervision of Mgr. Roger Berry. 
Heaviest turnout is in the two north­ ern precincts: Precinct 2 of Com. Tom 
Stolhandske and Precinct 3 of Com 
Jeff Wentworth. 
The two precincts account for 227.943 or 57 per cent of the registered voter 

 total for the county. 
Registered B exar County voters numbered only 3o1,o43 in 1972 
The marked show of interest cu r­ rently stems from public focus on the upcoming April 2 Sun A ntonio and suburban City Council* elections and local school district races, according to 
Berry. 
Potential voters may register at any time in the county registration depart­ ment i i i the basement of Bexar County 
Courthouse un Main Plaza. 
It s too late to register fur the April election, however, since the statutory 
3o-day pre-election cutoff has passed

Playwright and lyricist 
Alan Jay 
Lerner is claiming poverty to avoid paying alimony and child support, according to a slate judge in New 
York.

The money was due under a 19o5 
Nevada divorce decree.

“ except for his concurrent confession that his income for 197o has dwindled to a mere $25o.(M)o and that he still has an estate in Oyster Buy, N.Y., 

Children get savings start 

Barney Padway believes in thrift. 
Padway is laying out $2,145 so that 
429 elementary school children will have $5 each lo start personal saving accounts. 
The Coronado, Calif., School Board has accepted the plan, and arrange­ ments were made w ith a bank branch for the savings accounts to be opened by pupils from all three elementary schools. 
“ lf the children earn a little money from their parents, perhaps they can put $1 a week or so in the bank and when they get in high sch»)ol they can earn more and the money can help them through college,” Padway said 
Thursday.

The judge ordered a srK'cial referee to determine U 'rner’s “ true assets and true income and true financial c(»ndition.“

Lady” and “Camelot,” also had been delin q u en t for the p rio r th ree months, but he paid after a judgment was ordered by another justice.

Yasmin files for $1 million 

Princess Yasmin All Khan filed a 
$1 ! million damage suit Friday in 
New York against Bloomingdale's department store over distribution of a shopping bag bearing the picture of a seminude young woman. 
The princess, daughter of actress 
Rita Hayworth, claimed the store had planned to associate her name with the picture on the bags as a 
“ publicity gimmick to increase at­ tendance at the opening of Bloom- ingdale’s in Washington.” The store was opened March 6. 
The suit in Manhattan Supreme 
Court named the Equitable Bag Co. and Federated Department Stores. 
Inc., which operates the fashionable 
Bloomingdale’s departm ent stores here and in Washington. 
Bloomingdale’s had no immediate comment on the suit. 

Kunta Kinte, right, and Shaunta Keith, left, pose for their first pictures. Their mother, 16-yeor-old Sodette Howard of South Miami, Fla., named her babies after characters in the book and TV series ’Roots,’ as have scores of other black parents across the r>ation recently — AP Wirephoto 
Vlarlene halts opening 

Marlene Dietrich has succeeded in blocking Friday’s premiere in Mun­ ich of a movie in which Adolf Hitler is depicted as being secretly in love with her. 
The German-born actress, now writing her memoirs in 
Paris, charged that "Adolf and Marlene” slandered her. and through her 
French lawyer threatened to take legal action to keep it from ever being shown. 
Ulli Lommel the film’s producer, announced the premiere would be 
“ postponed” until next month so that some scen es could be re-photo- graphed. “ I needed a contrast for the horror figure of Hitler,” he said, “ a lH>auty for the beast.” 
There have been many rumors that 

Hitler had a crush on Miss Dietrich. who haled Nazism and fled Germany to escape Hitler. 
She did not return until after World 
War II. but in Lommel’s film she meets Hitler al his wartime retreat in 
Bavaria. 
Carter passes 

Former U S. Sen Jam es Buckley has given President 
Carter good marks for most of his Cabinet ap­ pointments and his support of human rights. 
Buckley, a Republican and Conser­ vative who was defeated by Democrat 
Daniel Moynihan in a re-election bid last year, also said he approved of 
Carter’s attempts to make the presi­ dency more human. 
Vietnam returns 
12 pilots^ remains 

H.ANOI, V ietnam (AP) — The government turned over 12 black steel caskets containing remains of A m er­ ican pilots killed in the Vietnam war to 
President Carter’s special commission 
Friday. 
.\ com m ission m e m b er said , meanwhile, that some U.S. servicemen who deserted may be living voluntarily in Vietnam. 
Vientiane 
The American delegation will fly the remains home aboard its Air Force jet. 
The five-member team leaves Satur­ day for Vientiane, Laos, to seek an accounting of .Americans missing in that Indochina country. 
( (immission C hairm an Leonard 
WiMKlcock, president of the United Au­ to Workers, told an afternoon press conference that the Hanoi government also agreed to set up machinery to de­ termine the fates of Americans still 

 listed as missing in action in the Viet­ nam war. 
Another iiiembtT of the commission. 
Rep. G.V. Montgomery. D-Miss.. said that after 15 months of investigating and the visit to Hanoi, "I personally believe no American is still being held captive.” But he added: “ There is a possibility a few deserters ... who did not want to go hom e” are living in 
\ ietnam. 
In Washington, the Pentagon said it had no evidence that A m erican de­ serters were living in Vietnam.

Relatives’ reactions to certainty varied 

 pmcus 
* mflMNMIY HOUSTON ST AT KROaOWAY 
W aiw iHII d i l l m < c u u o u g h 

 a sso c ia t e d m e s s 
Relief, a last hope dashed and shock were the reaction of so m e of the families and relatives of 12 American pilots whose bodies were handed over to a special U.S. commission by the 
Vietnamese on Friday. 
“ It’s just such a shock right now. I don’t think I can say anything about it.” said Jean Eaton of Narragansett. 
It.I., after hearing about the recovery of her husband’s body. 
Maj. Curtis A. Eaton, an Air Force pilot, bailed out of his burning F-Io5 fighter over Vietnam on Aug. 14, 196B 
Reused an emergency radio to signal for help, and was listed as missing in action. 
Body 
His body was among the 12 turned over to President Carter’s commission by Vietnamese officials in Hanoi. 
Eaton was declared dead last Sep­ tember after his name appeared on a list released by Vietnam of Americans killed in action. 
“ Ifs over for me,” said Virginia 
Capling, widow of Air Force Lt. Col. 
Elwyn R. Capling. “ After nine years of waiting. Com plete silen ce (from 
Vietnamese authorities) for nine years until last September and then nothing unUl now." 
The news which finally convinced her that her husband was no longer alive “came as a relief that he was not suffering,” she said. “ Bul i f s not really a relief to wail nine years lo find out your husband is dead.” 
“ Ifs still agony for the rest of them. 

Action at last \ on prisoners in Bolivia jails ; 

WASHINGTON — Three months ago we described the plight of 35 Americans who are languishing in grim rat-infested Bolivian prisons, uncertain when they will get out. 

Som e have been held for years, without trial, on suspicion of possess­ ing marijuana or cocaine. 
They can thank their own govern­ ment for their misfortune. They were dumped in jail as a direct result of U.S. pressure upon Bolivia to crack down on drug violators. 
The Justice Department even sent an attorney to help the Bolivians draft a tough drug law. 
The U.S. government is also subsi­ dizing th e police who arrested the 
Americans. 
No less than $4 million of the Amer­ ican ta x p a y e rs ’ m oney has been pledged to the Bolivian drug enforce­ ment program. 
Brutality 

This $4 million bequest hasn’t noti­ ceably softened the hearts of the Boli­ vian police toward th e ir American prisoners. 
At least five young Americans have written home about police brutality. 
One complained that the police beat him with a rubber hose. 
Another wrote that he had been bea­ ten and then threatened with execution before a firing squad at sunrise. A long-haired youth was dragged across the prison courtyard by his ponytail. 
Most of the prisoners have com­ plained bitterly about sanitary condi­ tions. 
The prisons are infested with rats and cockroaches. 
The food and waler have caused dy­ sentery, intestinal infection and hepa­ titis. 
Hepatitis 

One prisoner almost died, according to his parents, of hepatitis. 
Another lost 7o pounds in prison as a result of an intestinal infection. Yet the prison authorities refuaed him treat­ ment for nearly a year. 
Another man would have recievcd no medical treatment for flu and malaria except for the kindly intervention of a priest. 
But it is the uncertainly that has c a u s ^ the most anguish. 
.Most of the Americans were arrested for possessing no more than a pinch or two of marijuana or cocaine. 
Some pleaded innocence, claiming they had just happened to attend a party where the pot was smoked. 
No trial 

Yet they have been stuck in the slam m er for months, some as long as lhrt*e years, without a trial. 
Their parents have hired Bolivian lawyers w ho have collected fat fees but accomplished nothing. 
The parents have also complained to us that the U.S. em bassy in La Paz seeinc*d more concerned about the sensibilities of the Bolivian authorities than the suffering of the imprisoned 
.Americans. 

After we wrote about their sad si­ tuation, the S tate D ep artm en t d is­ patched a special team to Bolivia to invE'stigate. 
The investigators visited the Ameri­ cans in prison, with the full co­ operation of the Bolivian goventment. 
Their rejKirt is still in the drafting stage, but we can disclose the main findings: 
• The Stale Department confirmed that most of the American prisoners have been denied due legal process^. 
This is regarded as a flagrant violation of their human rights. 
The Bolivian judges have delibera­ tely held up the tria ls, however, to spare the Americans harsh sentences under the existing law. The iudges are waiting hopefully for the law to be modified. 
• The investigative team also con­ firm ed that A m e ric a n s have been* mistrt‘atcd in Bolivian prisons. 
Not all the com plaints about beat­ ings an brutality could be verified, although the report about one youth being dragged by the hair was af­ firmed. But the investigators conclud­ ed the A m ericans w ere treated no worse than Bolivian prisoners in the same circumstances. 
• There is also no question that sanitary conditions are substandard in the Bolivian prisons. 
The investigators actually saw the rats and cockroaches with their own eyes. 
As a result, many prisoners have had h ealth p ro b lem s. But again, the 
American prisoners are no worse off than their Bolivian cellmates. 
' 
• The State Department agrees that most of the Americans were arrested for simple possession. But a few of the prisoners apparently were drug traf­ fickers. One was caught with 5o pounds of cocaine in his suitcase. 
Belatedly, the State Department has now rnowd lo protect the basic rights of the jailed Americans. 
The department has even cautioned the Bolivian authorities delicately that 
U S. aid could be withdrawn if the hu­ man rights of the prisoners are violat­ ed 
The U.S. em b assy has also been authorized lo retain a Bolivian attor­ ney to give legal advice on the prisoner problem. 

 bul I hope this is the beginning of an accounting,” she said of other families aw aiting word on men rep o rted missing during the war. 
Mrs (’upliiig was notified in Sep- temlHT for the first time that her hus­ band’s name was on the list of airmen killed in Vietnam. Even so, mistakes have lMt*n made In the past and hope was still alive. He bailed out in 19H8 and had iHM.'n heard from alive on the ground but rescuers were unable lo reach him. 
In Om aha, Neb., Mrs. F'rank F. 
Roark, mother of William M. Roark, a 
Navy pilot, said she had a “ mingled jxaction” lo the news that tho remains of her son were turned over to the commission. 
Roark was 2H when he was shot down while flying a bombing mission over 
North Vietnam April 7. 1985. 
“ I’m just thankful we’ll have him hom e," his m other said " B u t I’m amazed that so much lime has elapsed. 
It takes years to really believe he’s gone. You keep hoping he will walk in the door some day. It took us almost five years to come to the conclusion 
Ihut he would never return.” 
• i ’m thankful that our country made an extended effort to accomplish this,” 
Mrs. Roark said. "A person almost has to lose a son to understand." 
Roark’s widow, Karen, rem arried about three years ago and is now living near M ontreal, Canada, with their thn*e children, Lisa, 15; John, 14, and 
William, ll

West Jr.. who died of a drug overdose in Las Vegas. Nev. in January 1968. 

His first wife was Scott Abbey West. with whom he lived in the arca of 
Miami. Fla., iK'fore their separation in 
1964. They were m a rrie d just five years before the separation. 

The divorce was final in May 1965.

Cancer clinic busy just across border 

MATAMOROS. Mexico (A P ) - 
Armed with s>everal “ miracle drugs." 
Byron Purdy opent^l an arthritis and cancer clinic featuring medicines out­ lawed in the United States. 
Laetrile grabbed the limelight ear­ lier this wEH*k when a group of cancer patients, who claimed the drug saved their lives, gathered in Austin lo sup­ port a bill that would legalize the con­ troversial substance. 
P u rd y , who a d m itte d ly h a s no fo r­ m al m ed ical train in g , will sell Ireal- m eiils costing betw een 13oo a n d 11,5o6 depEmdiiig on the type of illn e ss and the length of the slay. 
His clinic, located in this border city across the Rio Grande from Browns­ ville. is staffed by two Mexican doc­ tors. 
Patients will slay in Brownsville ho­ tels and go to his Matamoros clinic for the laetrile or "DMSO" treatm ents banned in the United States. 

Is 
Dimethyl sulfoxide, or UMSO, 
Purdy’s “super drug." 
“ Right now, only velennariaiis or re se a rc h e rs are allow ed to use 
DMSO,” said Purdy. “ It’s good enough for your dog bul if s not good enough for you 
“ If the Texas Legislature legalized laetrile, it wouldn’t affE*ct my clinic. 
‘D.MS'i IS my m ain drug. It does a much iM'tler job than laetrile and it can be used with laetrile. 
“ DMSO is outlawed by the Food and 
Drug Administration (FUA) because the American .Medical Association 
(A.MA) and the big pharm aceutical companies don’t want it in the United 
Stales," Purdy said. “ DMSO is re la­ tively cheap Ifs been used in Europe and some South American countries fur years with success but why would 
American doctors and drug companies w ant a cheaper, better drug when they can charge the prices they do now?”

The only losers would be single tax­ payers now deducting more than $2.’2oo 
— somewhere between $2,2oo and the 
$2 4oo maximum.

S.A. backs Lo-Vaca sale o f surplus natural gas 

U.S. REP. KAZEN, center, chats with Louis Stumberg, left, chamber council chairman, and Frank Manupelli, council vice chairman 

Bv DICK M ERK EL 
CHIEF. EXPRESS NEWS CAPITOL BUREAU 
AUSTIN — A four-month sale of surplus natural gas that could save its utility customers over 
$6oo,ooo and help assure future supplies, was endorsed here 
Friday by San Antonio. 
Officials of Lo-Vaca Gathering Co. laid the sale proposal before repre­ sentatives of its major customers at a meeting. 
The company left the meeting with an endorsement from a majority of the customers including San Antonio’s Ci­ ty Public Service. 
The final say, however, rests with the Texas Railroad Commission which vetoed a similar proposal last .January, also endorsed by Lo-Vaea’s customers. 
The RRC will consider the latest proposal at a 9 a.rn. meeting here 
Monday. 

Friday’s presentation was made by 
Lo-Vaca President William W. Grec hey, and Senior Vice Presidents Guy 
W. LeFlar and Ewald Fischer. 
According to the trio, if the RRC approves the sale it could have several immediate and long-range advantages for both the com pany and its customers. 
However, if the sale is not approved it could have dire consequences for the com pany and s u b se q u en tly its customer group of which San Antonio is the largest, they said. 
Among the im m ediate advantages envisioned would be a reduction in na­ tu ral gas p ric e s to the c u s to m e rs represented by the profits from the sale to Transcontinental Gas Pipeline 
Corp. 
According to Greehey, the four- month sale from April I through July 
31 could run as high as 15o million cubic feet of gas per day. 

The estimated profit to be credited to custom ers from this sale, Greehey said, would be nearly three cents per thousand cubic feet (MCF). 
According to CPS Gen. Mgr. Jack 
Spruce, who attended the session, this could mean a saving of some $18o,ooo a month to San Antonio utility customers based on the c u rre n t av erag e con­ sumption rate. 
Surplus 
The sale would also free surplus gas which Lo-Vaca is now com mitted to either take or pay for from producers at a time of low demand 
By moving this surplus gas, Lo-Vaca would then be able to buy additional spot gas to meet this sum m er’s peak demand period. 
But, more importantly, it would al­ low Lo-Vaca to expand its contracts for future gas purchases in what officials described as a major new South Texas 
Kazen says S.A. bases safe in cuts 

By JA M ES MCCRORY 
No action is being considered to close any San Antonio military bases, 
C S. Rep 
Abraham “ Chick” Kazen declared Friday. 
Kazen’s observation came in an an­ n u a l report to the Military Affairs 
Council of the Greater San Antonio 
Chamber of Commerce at a breakfast in the Civil Center on Main Plaza. 
A member of the House Armed Ser­ vices Committee, Kazen said major military installations in the last ll) years have been reduced from 214 to 
137, and five more cuts are being studied. 
Only one in Texas 
Among those five, he said, and the only one in Texas, is Webb AFB at Big 
Spring. 
Kazen. observing he feels w hat’s good for San Antonio and his district is good for the nation, said no one can predict at this time whether wing mo­ dification work on the C5 aircraft will be done at Kelly AFB. 
The new budget, Kazen said, pro­ vides $12.3 million for m ilitary con­ struction in the San Antonio area. 
“That’s not nearly as large a figure 

 as last year,” Kazen said, “ when we pushed ahead on the big Wilford Hall 
Hospital job, but there are few big construction contracts coming through this year.” 
The budget, Kazen said, contem ­ plates $5.8 million for a logistics m a­ terial storage facility, $72o,(KIO for the 
Air National Guard Avionics Weapons 
Shop and $4oo,ooo for an Ai.* Force 
Reserve T raining F acility at Kelly 
AFB. 
Also included in the budget, the congressman observed, is $4.7 million for a dental facility at Lackland AFB and $334,ooo for alterations of fuel and erosion control systems at Randolph 
AFB. 
The Air National Guard at San An­ tonio, he said, is listed for $51o,ooo for armory expansion and aviation support expansion. 
The House A rm ed Services Com ­ mittee. Kazen said, is recommending a defense budget for fiscal 1977 of $12o.9 billion, $ 8 billion higher than proposed by President Carter. 
The civilian employment levels of the 
Department of 
Defense will remain about the same, Kazen report­ ed. with the possible exception of work 
Draft not far down road says lawmaker 

If the present trend continues, a military draft is not too far down the road. C S Rep. Abraham Kazen pre­ dicted Friday. 
“The recovery of the domestic econ­ omy is h av in g its effect on the all-volunteer force,” Kazen told the 
Military Affairs Council of the Greater 
San Antonio Chamber of Commerce. 
• ‘ There are more jobs, especially for the high school graduates, so they’re 
Showing less interest in military life.” 
The congressman said when unem­ ployment stands at 7.5 per cent, there is a 2o per cent “ shortfall” in recruit­ ing. and if the jobless rate is cut buck to 4 per cent, the military “ shortfall” is 4H per cent. 
President Carter created problems for any future draft system by par­ doning men who evaded the Viet Nam 

 draft, Kazen said. He said he thinks the pardon granted by the President 
“ was unfair to those who responded to the call.” lf the U.S. has to go back to the draft, 
Kazen said, “ will each young man or woman decide for himself whether the nation's need is going to affect his or her life?” lie expressed fears future draft evaders, if another draft law is imple­ mented, will say the Viet Nam draft evaders were pardoned and if they disobey they have the right to expect the same pardon. 

.contracted out by the Air Force. 
The proposed budget, Kazen said, would provide nearly $23 billion for 244 aircraft, and indications are $3.2 bil­ lion of that would be sub-contracted to 
Texas. If so, he added, it would provide 
8,ooo Texas jobs. 
A fter outlining sp e cific s of the number and work being done on wea­ ponry, Kazen said it is generally ac­ cepted the Soviet Union w ants to spread communism across the world. 
Kazen reiterated the U.S. must have a military defense second to none. He said Defense Secretary Harold Brown told the committee in term s of military strength, and social, economic, indus­ trial. and moral strength, the U.S. is second to none. 
Competent intelligence analysts are convinced Leonid Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist party, prefers progress in peace to the risks of war, Kazen asserted. 
In the area of civil defense, Kazen said U.S. civil defense plans look about 
5o per cent effective. The cold facts, he explained, are the plans would enhance survival chances of 5o per cent of the 
American people. 
No attack seen 

Kazen said the best m inds in g o ­ vernm ent believe the U.S. need not expect a nuclear attack. 
“ He (President Carter) said we were roughly equivalent to the Soviet Union 
(in n u clear com p arab ility ), and in case of a major exchange of weapons, each country might lose 5o to IOO mil­ lion people.” Kazen said. 
“ So, when the question comes up of whether we should spend less for de­ fense, my only view at this time is that we should instead be trying to make our strength so evident that no enemy will dare to launch a major attack on our country. 
“ If any nation knows that it would be c o m m ittin g national su icid e if it launched the first strike against us, that may be the best of all protections for our people.” 
That last sentence won Kazen biggest hand of the breakfast.

Not sick or senile, says 
Kazen, Til run again 

Observing he is neither “ sick nor senile,” U.S. Rep. Abraham Kazen 
Friday moved to dispell rumors he will not be seeking re-election iii 1978. 
F rank M anupelli asked the con­ gressman to dispell rumors he is re­ tiring alter his current term at a meeting of the Military Affairs Council of the Greater San Antonio Chamber of 
Commerce. 
The rumors, Manupelli observed, are being circulated iii San Antonio and Austin. 

“ I don’t have any plans to retire any time soon,” the congressman reported. 
" I ’m just getting started up there." 
He pointed out he is a member of the 
D em ocratic m ajority in Congress, working with a Democratic President. 
He said he feels he still has a contri­ bution to make. 
Asked about reports Raza Cnida 
Party founder Jose A n g e l Gutierrez, county judge of Zavala County, will run against him, Kazen retorted it’s a free country and anybody can run. 

By V ICKIE DAV IDSON 

The first woman to anchor 
ABC-TV's evening news was in town Friday. 
And, no, it w a s n ’t B a rb a ra 
Walters. 
Marlene Sanders, who substituted as an anchorm an on the network evening news in 1964 and in the early 197os, was in town to speak at the Women In Communications, 
Inc., Headliners Dinner. 
At one tim e in her career, Ms. 
Sanders said she would like to have been the first full-tim e an­ chorwoman. but “ it w asn’t in the cards. The first woman had to be a star.” 
Ms. Sunders went on to make her own first. She became the first woman vice president of a network news division. 
She was named ABC vice presi­ dent in 1976. 
But, she is a supporter of the wo­ man who has the anchor job she once wanted. 
“ I think she (B arbara Walters) was very badly tre a ted by the press,” Ms. Sanders said Friday afternoon. She said any public fi­ gure has to expect criticism 
Unfair barrage 
But, the barrage on Ms. Walters was unfair. And she attributed it to jealousy. . 
What about the rumored person­ ality shake-ups in ABC’ news? 
“ I read it in the papers like you do.” said Mrs. Sanders. 
“ E v ery b o d y by now is so convinced there are going to be some changes . . . with all that talk there must be something.” 
In a speech prepared for the WK I dinner. Ms. Sanders said opportun­ ities for women are increasing. 
"The last few years have been a period of great progress for many of us, and it is no time to stop — to be complacent." 
When sh e s ta rte d w orking in broadcasting, she said she could count the number of women in the field. 
Ms. Sanders said, however, there is still more to be done, more wo- 

MARLENE SANDERS 
. . . at the top 

 men to be hired and promoted and more attitudes to bo changed. 
“ At ABC, sen sitiv ity tra in in g sessio n s a re now being run for white male managers, women and minorities. 
“ Making new rules is one thing; changing attitudes is another, and probably the most difficult area to deal with. 
“ Despite women's recent gains, it still appears that we are regarded, generally speaking, as unwelcome intruders in an area where the men who run th in g s have enjoyed a monopoly on power from the begin­ ning ” 
Ms. Sanders said women m ust strive for excellence in their work. 

Full pay 

“ But, we also want to be paid in full and be free to go to the very top 
Elf our professions.” 
The five San Antonio career wo­ men honored ut the Friday night dinner were Carolyn Spears, county court judge; Luis Parkhouse, an in­ surance agent; Virginia Stone, a teacher; Vivian Kiolbassa, an office manager, and Thelma Ledger, in­ formation director for the San An­ tonio State Hospital. 

 discovery in which Lo-Vaca is already a customer. 
Greehey told the meething, “ Lo-Vaca has already got in on this South Texas field. We are already buying some ‘in’ of this gas,” he said. 
Fischer said, “ Four producers, who control approximately 25o,ooo acres in this area, currently sell gas to Lo-Va­ ca. However, Lo-Vaca has been unable to purchase the quantity of gas it has already contracted for.” 
Greehey said. "If we don’t take increased volume we stand to lose our contracts altogether in this significant gas producing area." 
He added, “ There are already some interetate pipelines in this area ready to move in and buy the gas. This is a very real threat.” 
By selling off surplus gas now, Lo- 
Vaca would be in a position to meet its current contract obligations, solidify its position as a m ajor buyer in the future and evaluate the field's full po­ tential, he said. 
Preliminary evaluations for expand­ ing its system in the area “ indicate this expenditure to be in the magnitude of $2o-$4l) million,” Fischer suiil. 
F isch e r said a n o th e r im m ed ia te problem facing Lo-Vaca is the pur- chase Elf spot gas to m eet this su m ­ m er’s peak demand period. 
“ It is my intention tEi purchase this gas at today’s prices, rather than on a day-to-day basis at a tim e when de­ mand will push the price well above the current level,” he said. 
“ This is the first time we have had producers threaten to cancel Eiur con­ tracts," Greehey said. 
Kidnap suspect jailed 

An absent without leave Ft. Bliss soldier suspected Elf kidnaping two Kl 
Paso residents and stealing a Ft. Sam 
Houston truck was lodged in Bexar 
County Jail Friday afternoon. 
The soldier had been turned over to 
Ft. Sam Houston authorities- Friday morning after being arrested at Ran­ dolph AFB. Randolph Eifficials said the private was caught allegedly trying to steal a civilian’s car parked on the base. 
Military officials had issueil an alert for the 22-year-old soldier Wednesday night after a truck was stolen at Ft 
Sam Houston. Universal City police reportedly spotted the vehicle but lost it w hile giv ing chase. 
A few hours later, the private was arrested at Randolph, the spokesman said. 
Local police had been searching for the man since Wednesday night when un El Paso man and woman told police they had been forced at gun pEiint to 

E lm o to San Antonio. 
The two, Dorothy L. Covington. 52. and Joe Edward Wheeler, 24, said the man jum ped out of the autom obile after ordering it driven into a down­ town parking garage. 
The man mumbled something alwiut seeing a friend at Lackland AFB, the pair told police. Papers identifying the man as a Ft. Bliss soldier were left in the car, officers reported. 
Army officials identified the soldier as Pfc. John M. Brown, (’ Battery, 3rd 
Training Batallion (missile), 1st Air 
Defense Artillery Training Brigade. 
Military officials said the man was iMiokE'El into Hie* federal sivtion Elf Bex­ ar County Jail, charged with being absent without leave. 
Iii* is scheduled to be transferred to 
Ft. Bliss where he faces auto theft and attempted auto theft charges.

CORPUS 
CHRISTI 
(AP) 
- 
Form er R aza Unida g u b e rn a to ria l candidate Ram sey Muniz was se n ­ tenced to two m ax im u m five-year terms Friday after pleading guilty to conspiring to smuggle marijuana and bond jumping. 
U.S. District Court Judge Owen Cox said the sentences are to be served concurrently, but consecutive to a five-year term Muniz received in San 

Antonio March I. The sentences spell 
B) years im prisonm ent for the two- time candidate. 
Mum/’s guilty plea to the conspiracy charge was part of a plea bargain in which the rem ainder of an 11-count indictment was dismissed March 7. 
The most recent indictment alleged 
Muniz conspired to sm uggle 1,1oo pounds of marijuana to Birmingham, 
Ala., between June 15 and Dec. 7, 1975. 

The San Antonio indictm ent allt*ges 
Muniz conspired to s m u g g le 832 pounds of marijuana from Mexico to a ranch in Medina County. 
Muniz was indicted in November of last year. When he failed to appear in court Nov. 22, 1976, bon d -ju m p in g charges were filed against him. He was arrested in Mexico and turned over to U.S. agents in Laredo last

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 19 1977 

Providing a touch o f lively Irish music to the Second Annual St. Patrick’s D ay Fes­ tivities Friday is Pipe M aj. Jack Brown. 
Brown's music was just part o f the fun at the annual event sponsored by the Irish

Huebner asks growth plan accord 

By J IM WOOD 
San Antonians have more area in which to agree than disagree over the San Antonio Growth 
Sketch, City Mgr. Tom 
Huebner said Friday as he sought to bring the controversial document into perspective. 
“ We should not argue over dots on a map,” he said, referrin g to a 
Growth Sketch map that shows planning projec­ tions of where growth will develop during the next 2o years. 
He also emphasized that the plan is not a “ no growth” plan and is not a plan that directs how land can be used. 
Further, he said the 
Growth Sketch will not cause property taxes to go up. To the contrary, if the city does not have a master plan to direct where tax money is spent, then taxes will be higher, Huebner said. 

The Growth Sketch was described as the first 

 step toward preparation of a master plan. 
Following 
F rid a y ’s discussion, City Council scheduled formal consi­ deration for Thursday. 
In the m eantim e, 
Mayor Lila Cockrell in­ structed the City P la n ­ ning Commission and staff to draw up a report before Thursday stating how they propose to use the Growth Sketch while work on an overall mas­ ter plan continues. 

Strait jacket 
The mayor also said she will not be a party tit a no-growth policy or one that puts the city in a 
“ strait jacket.” 
Huebner said his in­ structions to the staff w ill be planning “ consistent with market realities.” 
The Growth Sketch en­ visions a population in­ crease of 3oo.ooo by the year 2ooo, a projection 
Huebner believes is con­ servative. 
Population shifts from northern states to the Sun 

Belt and the higher than average birth rate in San 
Antonio may raise the total considerably, he said. 

As for the Edwards 
Aquifer, the source of the c ity ’s drinking water, 
Huebner said he is sensi­ tive to the need to protect it. 

Some areas of it should not be developed, he said, but added that others can be safely de­ veloped and should be. 
“ It does not have to re­ main a wilderness." 

Councilman I). Ford 
Nielsen, who was not present Friday, blasted the 
Growth 
Sketch 
Thursday, claiming it would cause taxes to go up because land uses would be changed. 

Councilman Phil Pyn- dus, who is running for re-election in the same district as Nielsen, asked for point by point clarifi­ cation of those claims. 

 all musk....all the time 
TCQXT 

FM STEREO 1o2

By LIZ SWEET 
The' chairm an of the 
Texas Educators Politi­ cal Action C om m ittee 
(TEPAC) said Friday the committee helped cled 
HI 
T exas le g isla to rs friendly to education. 
Russell Owen told the committee that IO candi­ dates for the Senate and 
71 can d id a tes for the 
House who w ere e n ­ dorsed by TEPAC won rn the Nov. 2, 1976 election 
The TEPAC board of trustees met during the 

It is m ost im p o rta n t fo r ed u ca tio n 's future to elect can d id a tes fr ie n d ly to e d u c a tio n ' 

Texas State T each ers 
Assn. 98th annual con­ vention continuing through Saturday in the 
San Antonio Convention 
Center. 
In 1976. TEPEC spent 
$3,15o for contributions to candidates running for 
^enate seats and $9,3oo to support candidates in the

Counting other state elections. Owens said.

Ex-Miss America: 
Failure part o f life 

By DAVID MCLEMORE 
Most young people grow up never realizing failure is a part of life, a fo rm e r Miss A m erica said Friday. 
Marilyn Van Derbur, 
Miss America of 1958.

 was keynote speaker to the 98th annual conven­ tion of the Texas State 
Teachers Assn at the 
Convention Center. 
She is now a mot nation specialist in schools in 
Denver. Colo. 
“ Most students, even excellent ones, think of themselves in term s of failure. They think suc­ cess is only for winners.” she said. 
Happens to all 
“ They never learn — because we don't teach them — that failure is a part of life and that it happens to everyone. 
“ We have to show our young people that b e ­ cause they've failed once does not m ake them a failure " 
Mrs. Van Derbur told teachers they must moti­ vate their students to de­ cide some life goal that is important to students — not the teachers 
“ Help them develop goals and a plan for those goals so they can develop a positive self im age." she said 
“ Blit those goals be­ long to the student. They are very personal. My biggest fear is that some te a c h e r will assign grades for student goals. 
We don't have the right to do that." 
Importance 
Mrs. 
Van 
D erb u r charged the teachers to place m ore im portance on teaching confidence

Voluntary

Profession

Owen said nothing is of greater importance to the future of education than the election of ca n d id a tes who view e d u c a tio n 's needs as a priority.

Saturday 
Spotlight 

Vickie 
Davidson 

Coyness not fo r Dr. Lee 

To hear the talk, you’d sometimes think Amy 
Freeman I-cc sat at the right hand of Clod and her pet project was San An­ tonio. 
At countless communi­ ty meetings, events and banquets, you’ll find 

 she s a guest of note — if she’s not the speaker. 
At 
Alamo 
Heights gatherings, matrons smugly cite her as the last word in art. educa­ tion and what-have-you. 
“ She’s so terribly intel­ lectual. you know.” 

’lf yon are graced with frien dsh ip, it's a debt . . . ran hare to p a y it back' 

At a recent interview, the reference to her as 
“ near diety” brought an inquisitive smile to Amy 
Freeman Lee, a spare 

 woman whose back is bent from a horse riding mishap in her youth. 
“ I ’m too old to start be­ ing coy,” she replies as

 the smile vanishes. 
The H2-year-old woman is sitting in a desk chair in the middle of her painting-lined studio be­ hind the McNay Art In­ stitute. The only sounds breaking the silent even­ ing shadows outside her studio are birds calling to ac h other. 
A lamp shines behind 
Amy making it hard to see her face clearly. It s almost as if she was holding court — a wise one with a very South­ western drawl. 
I’m really not aware that I ’m held in that kind of regard .” she says. 
But, then she* admits she holds the respect and friendship of a number of people. That obligates her, she says. 
“ lf you receive respect from people, then you in­ cur debts. If you are graced with friendship, it’s a debt. A deep, deep debt — you have to pay it back.” 
Artist, author 
Dr. Amy Freeman Lee is a nationally known ar­ tist, an author, a lecturer, board president of Incarnate Word Col­ lege. 
Besides all that, she has her fingers in a number of organizations 
— but, not because she’s a socialite. She says she isn’t. 
“ I’m not good at small talk and I avoid it.” She explains her organizational work is a way to learn cooperation, and she believes i i i co­ operation. It’s also a way to get things done. 
There are people in the city, of course, who would question whether 
Amy Freeman Lee knows anything about coopera­ tion — even near didies have their enemies. 
You don’t always make friends when you’re out­ spoken. Dr. Lee explains, saying she feels so strongly about certain issues she has to do so­ mething. 
It would also be easy for some people to discount the woman as a professional do-gooder born with a silver spoon 

 i ii her mouth. 
“ One of the severests tests for the spirit is af­ fluence and very few people pass it,” she vo­ lunteers unexpectedly during the conversation. 
“Very few people manage to pass it with honor and grace. I see the1 destructiveness of ll all around me. 
Mao volume nu b lished 

AGENCY FRANCE PRE S U 
HANGCHOW, China - 
Big-character slogans seen Friday in Canton and Hangchow, south of 
Shanghai, announced the publication of volume fi\e of Chairman Mao 
Tse-tung’s selected works. 

“ C ertainly, you can gamble it or guzzle it . . . you have the power to make that choice, but you don’t have the moral right.” 
Responsibility 
W hat about her own attitude toward money? 
Dr. Lee says her grand­ mother — who raised her 
— taught her a responsi­ b ility about life and money. 
She explains she had three sets of clothes as a child — play clothes, school clothes and Sun­ day clothes. She had no choice but to take care of them 
Amy w ill talk about money. She also talk freely about herself, her art, about the necessity to be humane to other people — and to animals. 
One of her first me­ mories, she says, was of her passionate love for animals. 
“ I was lucky enough to grow up in a typical U.S. village (Seguin) whtTe you knew everyone and everyone’s dog.” she E x ­ plains iii only the way a good story teller would unwind a story. 
“ I don’t feel complete without my anim als. I don’t like lo travel with­ out one of my dogs.” She says animals are sooth­ ing to the human spirit. 
Meanings 
The human spirit is one thing Dr. Lee has bf»en concerned about for years. She describes her­ self as someone who has always looked for the dee pet meanings. 
Shc’s always wanted to know : Why are we here? 
Why do we create? What is the purpose of life? 
ShE> found herself a be- liever in reincarnation. 
Dr. Lee explains the pur­ pose of life — as she s e t s it — is to refine the spirit, to work on the forwarding address. 
Her search for mean­ ings also led her to ex­ plore Ii e t art 
Work satisfying 
Is she a good artist.' 
Ye‘s. she says, in the re- speet that she finds her work satisfying. 

ARTIST A m y Freem an Lee is a near-oracle for som e San Anton­ ians.

France OKs aid to Zaire 

COM PREG M O M WIRE SERVICES 

KINSHASA, Z aire — 
I he F reneh governm ent ag reed F rid a y to send 
Zaire em ergency m ili­ tary supplies, expected to Im* mainly small arm s and amm unition, to help defeat the 11-day-old in­ vasion in th e m in e ra l- rich, southern area for­ m erly known as K atan­ ga. 
The French prom ise of aid follows agreem ent from the U.S. and Bel­ gian governm ents to fly in m ilitary supplies. 
The second planeload of U.S. military aid — is scheduled to arrive in the capital, K inshasa, early next week. It will com ­ plete the U.S. aid pack­ age.

Kamal Ju m blatt.

M anaging E d ito r 
Carter has captured a policy initiative 

Jim m y Carter is making the most of his newcomer status, and he is m aking stro n g a d ­ vances in tin* face of defenders of tilt' status quo. 
This week he went to the 
United Nations to speak to the permanent members — the Se­ curity Council. Having earlier angered Hit' Russians with his candid rem arks about human rights, the President told the 
U N. delegates his e m p h a s a s upon hum an rig h ts is the 
“ backbone of our foreign po­ licy." 
Then hi' noted what some of them may have forgotten or chosen to ignore: “ All tin' signa­ tories of tin' U. N. charter have pledged themselves to observe and respect basic human rights. 
Thus, no member of the United 
Nations can claim th a t m is ­ treatment of its citizens is solely 
•its own business. Equally, no member can avoid its respon­ sibilities to review and to speak when torture or u n w arra n te d deprivation of freedom occurs in any part of the world." 
The President is taking the initiative away from Com m un­ ists who have professed to speak for tin' downtrodden while try­ ing to refuse the right of others 
— Mr. C arter — to intru d e. 

Thus, the President has cited two tr e a ti e s — the Helsinki treaty and the U. N. c h a r te r treaty — as bases for structur­ ing foreign policy with a human rights backbone. 
Mr. C a r t e r ’s app ro ach to these basic issues, done with confidence and understanding, a ffirm s d e m o c ra c y 's best ideals. Furthermore, Iii' bluntly c h a llen g es the Russian C o m ­ munists on ideological grounds, where they are weakest. The 
President, in tandem with his national security chief, Zbig­ niew Brzezinski, challenges the idea that the Soviet Union is a genuine superpower and points out till' serious flaws in a system that denies its own people basic rights to dignity and freedom. 
Mr. C a r te r ’s thrust is that reduction of the nuclear a rm s race, achievement of harmony in trouble spots, and the pro­ vision of food, good health and education will independent­ ly contribute to advancing the human condition. And most of the w orld's peoples know the 
American capacity to respond in material help as well as ideolo­ gical p r e a c h m e n ts , in s h a rp contrast to Soviet performance. 
The Carter approach may be startling but it is encouraging. 
City finds a market ior in-town housing 

City Council’s advisory com­ mittee on downtown, Centro 21, found a m arket for downtown housing. 
Analysis of resp o n se s to 
45o,ooo questionnaires showed — by projection analysis — thatch per cent of the city’s population has an interest in living in downtown in su itab le places. 
Suitable, in terms of respondent views, means moderate-priced houses. Moderate means houses for under $4o,ooo aud rentals for 
$2oo or less per month. 
Assuming a survey-response market of 15,ooo and a hardcore market of 2o per cent of those who said they would like to live downtown, th ere would de a realistic market for a minimum of 5o,ooo persons. 
Potential investors should evaluate that kind of incentive. 
First problem is obvious; how to build for the price limitation. 
Mission trail goes national 

San Antonio’s hike and bike trail through the Mission Park­ way has been designated a na­ tional trail — one of three in 
Texas — and will be listed na­ tionally as a historic, scenic and recreational trail. 
Mayor Lila Cockrell was no­ tified of the designation this week. 
Mission Parkway is evolving into one of the n a tio n ’s most significant historic-scenic urban 

Aid to elderly 

Sir: Re your artlet*' in tin- Express 
(M arch 18) “ Proposal m ay force el­ derly out of home": 
In the course of trying lo aid. on a person-to person basis, elderly persons who are im poverished and shut-ins, m em bers af tin' four chapters of the 
Daughters af the British E m pire in 
San Antonio have been confronted with shacking cases of elderly people who cannot continue to rem ain in their homes without assistance with house­ hold chores and shopping. 
The Hom em aker-H om e Health Aide 
Service, adm inistered by the Family 
S ervices A ssociation, is th e ir only lifeline 
Yet City M an ag er T hom as 
Heubner proposes to discontinue fund­ ing this service. 
If Mr. Heubner elim inates funds he will in no way benefit the taxpayer, since these people will then be forced into institutions w here it will cost the taxpayer more to support them. 
.lean R. Lange

( num'll decision.) will he a City 

The survey indicates prefer­ ence for single-fam ily dwellings. It might be worth a trial to develop garden a p a r t ­ m ents, redevelop e x istin g buildings into apartments, and to find building sites for other kinds of housing. 

Land costs are assumed to be a p ro b le m . Speculative l a n d ­ holders m ig h t be induced to cooperate or some sort of urban renewal approach could be tried on a test site. With much of the b u sin ess c o m m u n ity lately embarked upon free-enterprise renewal, that system could have a place to demonstrate its worth. 

Centro 21 bas clearly found a potential m arket. The City of 
San Antonio’s role is necessarily limited, but we assume council would extend itself to do what it properly and feasibly can do. 

 places. The parkway itself could soon become a national historic park. It links four of the city’s tamed Spanish missions and in­ cludes the (plaint, still-service­ able Espada dam. 

San Antonians who h av en ’t toured the missions in y e a rs have a pleasant surprise ahead when they re-visit them . The trail becomes an attractive bo­ nus. 

Much written about aquifer 

Sir Re your Editorial (M arch I) 
Much has been said and w ritten about the Edwards Aquifer. 
The Express would have ifs readers believe that only San Antonio has the wisdom to protect the quality of the water in the aquifer. 
The TVVQB bas recognized that th** 
3(1 people dispersed over the 311 square miles (I per IO square miles) of the recharge zone in Kinney County need not be subjected to the sam e stringent regulations that should be impose upon the 12.SOO people clustered in urban areas over the 122 square miles 
(1o5 per square mile) of the recharge zone in Bexar County. 
Bexar County had no problem with pollution of the aquifer for more than 
2oo years and would tint have a prob­ lem today had the land over the re ­ charge zone rem ained ranch land 
Possibly the TWQB is saying “ Bexar 
County mind your own pollution c o n ­ trol business, of which there is an over abundance iii th*' San Antonio Metro- plex. and trust your n e ig h b o r s to have enough good common s e n s e to do their part iii prole* ting their o w n . as well as your, only source of w ater." 
John VV White. 
Executive Director. 
Nueces River Authority

Laufill lo hank with super stars 

Sir: You’ll meet them at almost any party. Who are “ th e m ” ? Well, sir, 
“ th em ” are th*' devoted sp orts fans who manage to root for their profes­ sional teams, support them and usual­ ly know m ost every fact about tIn* players and their averages. They also m anage to keep stored in their brain memory-bank thousands of statistical 

 trivia aud will argil*' the outcome of a gam e played days or years ago. They are the backbone of sports-Ameriea. 
When they leave a gam e, what have they really accom plished? They have spent their hard-earned money to wit­ n e s s p lay ers in th*' million d ollar category they have read about with fabulous contracts with spin-offs. 
They have watched prices far tickets rising and the dem ands of th*' super stars rising yearly. It leaves th** fans out in th** cold, as th*' super stars care little for th*' pocket book of the fans. 
I have inst the solution! If sports fans would devote the sam e tim e and energy in stu d y in g the Dow-.lunes averages instead of hatting averages, and m em orize statistics of the stock m ark et and actio n s and m e rits of stacks, they would share in th*' profits of their efforts and come home winners with dividends and stock appreciation 

 and laugh all the wav to the hank as super stars do every week 
Ely I. B ergm ann 

W e’re com m anded lo love all p erso n s 

Sir 
I som etimes wonder who is of g reater harm to th*' church — m ilitant a th e ists like Madalyn M urray O ’Hair. or wishy-washy defenders of the faith like Et*. Sherrill Smith (Letters. March 
I) 
Er. Smith condemned Mrs. O'Hair for her overhearing personality, hut never implied that the atheism she p reach es is wrong. He went on to confess that dedicated churchm en, too. are obnoxious, only adding that th*' church's “ dogm a” (Latin for “ tru th ") is no worse than that of Mrs. O'Hair. 
What a rally-ery for the besieged rem nant of C hristians! What a relief tit know that the faith and knowledge of 
Christ, for which countless m arty rs died, and to wliich we are asked to entrust our own lives, isn't any worse than the prejudice's of a befuddled old crank 
We are comm anded to love all, re­ gardless of their persuasions. We ar*' not, however, com m anded to degrade our church and faith, to fawn and flatter a few non-believers so that they might condescend to swell our congregations and drop money into the baskets. 
Egon R. Tausch

U.S. needs secrets act 

WASHINGTON - Recent in­ dications suggest that Presi­ dent Carter, as distinct from 
Candidate Carter, is rapidly discovering the essentiality of top-quality intelligence and the c o n co m itan t n e c essity for means to keep intelligence se­ crets secret. 
The new adm in istratio n's baptism of fire c a m e when the W ashington 
Post, *»n the eve of Secretary of State 
Cyrus V ance’s first Middle East trip. disclosed that the U.S. governm ent. via the CIA, had been paving multi- million dollar subsidies (“ bribes,” 
•the Post called them ) for two decades to .Jordan’s King Hussein. 
Nothing wrong 
Let it he said im m e d ia te ly that there is nothing w rong, or even ex* cepttonal, in a g re at pow er paying such subsidies (or “ subventions,” as they are technically known in diplo­ macy). 
T hroughout Britain’s two-century heyday as the w o rld 's g re atest em* pl re . its fro n tlin e i n s t r u m e n t s of 

 power were not arm ies lait its intel­ ligence services, th** Royal Navy and, above all, the pound sterling, billions of w hull were {literally dispensed to g o v e r n m e n ts , s ta te s m e n a n d any foreign recipient who could thereby 
Im* brought to serve the purposes of the crown 

Exceptional 
What is exceptional, and without precedent in history, even our own. is th a t a g r e a t n a tio n 's m i g h t i e s t new spaper (which perpetually keeps describing itself us responsible) should disclose such a rra n g e m e n ts for th e sak e of d is c lo su re — as if 
H ussein’s subvention* were somehow reprehensible — and get away with it. 
Iii dem ocratic Britain, from wh u h we derive our ( (institution aud free institutions, they have a tough official secrets aet under which w hoever dis* closes, as well as w hoever p rin ts, in fo rm atio n defined us s e c r e ts , is trusl in cam era, and, iii longstanding practice, receives a severe sentence usually involving im p riso n m e n t as well a s fin*' 
B ritain, for example aud also for 

Col. 
Robert D. 
Heinl Jr. 

 c o n trast, is now rn the p ro cess of expelling two tu rn c o a t A m ericans, 
Philip Agee (a (TA officer who de­ fected to the o th er tid e ) and Mare 
Hosenbail, a reporter whose specialty has been s y s te m a t ic e x p o s u re of non-< om m unist intelligence person­ nel and operations. 

Tough, tidy 

B esides th e ir focus on th e CIA 
(Agee w a s an editorial ad v iser for 
"Counter sp y ,’' the m agazine which fingered R ich ard W elch, our m u r­ dered CIA station chief iii Athens), both H osenbail aud Agee seem to have em barrassed Mitt, Britain's Se­ cret Intelligence Service 
W ithin w eek s, e ach w a s serv ed with a deportation notice (and could 

 iii all p ro bab ility have been p ro s e ­ cuted had tin* crown so wished). 

The tough and tidy way Britain has for disposing of those who disclose vital s e c re ts of state is im possible h e re , p a r t ly on c o n s titu tio n a l g ro u n d s, and partly on the inertia and u n w illin g n e s s of C o n g re ss to pass legislation which would punish those who disclose official se c re ts 
(and, incidentally, punish the likes of 
Agee, who knowingly divulge them to enem y intelligence services). 

Every other Western nation, except our own, has adequate laws against espionage and to protect its intelli­ g en ce se rv ic e s — especially th e ir sources and methods, the heart of the business — against exposure. 

U.S. has neither 

The United Slates bus neither?Our statutes, to Im- sure, do make it cri­ minal to divulge tax and census d a ­ ta. cotton iu tu re s, grand-jury p ro ­ c e e d in g s, aud p riv ate c o m m u n ic a ­ tions of doctors and lawyers with p a­ tients and clients 
Intelligence has no such protection 

After the intelligence debacles of lh*' p ast two y e a r s , it a p p e a r e d briefly th at the c o u n try , and even 
Congress, had been shocked into re­ cognition th at U S in tellig en ce — once the world’s best — needed legal protection for its secrets. 

At lh** prom pting of form er Direc­ t o r of Central Intelligence William E, 
Colby, 
President 
Ford proposed m i n im u m s a f e g u a r d le g is la tio n w hich w ould p u n is h g o v e r n m e n t e m p lo y e s (lik e Philip Agee) who, having sw orn an o ath of s e c re c y , knowingly break that oath and d is­ close intelligence so u rces or m e th ­ ods. 

Press exempt 

(T he press would he specifically ex em pted from the purview of the law — which in the recen t ease of 
Hussein’s subventions would exempt 
Hie Post hut punish the State De­ partm ent or CIA employe who leaked the story.) 

Until President C a rte r’s abrupt in­ tr o d u c tio n to th e p r o b l e m , the 
Colby-Kurd proposal has languished 

Mideast policy lines drawn 

WASHINGTON - This city is on the verge of another funda­ mental debate on the new Carter administration’s policy in the 
Middle East, and the debate has been building up in an odd and almost off-handed way. 
One day the adm inistration forbids 
Israel to sell 24 Israeli-built “ K fir” fighter bom bers to Ecuador equipped with a certain kind of U.S. engine. 
A few d a y s la te r, it w ith d ra w s a c o m m itm e n t by f o r m e r P r e s id e n t 
Ford to deliver high-pereussion bom bs to Israel. 
Then President C arter outlines, a l­ most casually, at a press conference, an installm ent plan withdrawal by Is­ rael to roughly the pre-1987 Arab-Is- raeli borders, and in his latest town- meeting rem ark s on foreign policy at 
Clinton, M ass., he talked about p ro ­ viding “ a homeland for the Palestinian 
’r e f u g e e s ” in som e undefined area of the Middle East. 
Added controversy 
E v e ry m o v e th is a d m i n is tr a t io n makes touching on the delicate Middle 
E astern pro blem adds to the con tro­ versy. 
Even when the President addressed an ad-hoc m eeting at the United N a­ tions and allowed representatives of the P alestine Liberation Organization to atten d , the Israeli am b assad o r in 
Washington, Sim cha Dinitz. called on 
Secretary of State Vance to express his g o v e r n m e n t’s “ c o n c e r n ” th a t th i s m ig h t be ta k e n as a sign th a t th e 
United Slates had changed its policy toward the PLO. 
The White House denied that there was any change toward the PLO. 
Change of approach 
But * learly there is a change of a p ­ proach here. 
Washington is no longer hesitating to put fo rw ard its own thoughts about how to b r e a k the n e g o tia tin g s t a l e ­ m ate, hut seem s to he insisting that peace in the Middle E ast is too serious a question to be left to the Israelis and the A rab states. 
T h is th e m e w a s s u g le s te d in a 
“ P u r p l e P a p e r ’’ p ro d u c e d by th e 
B rookings Institution in W ashington and noted with considerable interest here and e ls e w h e re b ecau se it w as signed by, a m o n g o th e rs, Zbigniew 
Brzezinski, now head of the C arter a d m i n i s t r a t i o n ’s N atio n a l S e c u rity 
Council. 
“ Rising tensions in the Middle E a s t.’’ the B ro o k in g s M id d le E a s t S tu d y 
Group said, “ . . . m ight well lead to a n o th e r A ra b -Is ra e li w ar and e v e n provoke a m ajor confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union 

Responsibilities 
“ T h e g o v e r n m e n ts d i r e c t l y concerned h ear the responsibility of negotiation and ag reem e n t, hut they are unlikely to he able to reach a g re e ­ ment alone. Initiative, im petus, and ind u cem en t m ay well have to co m e from outside. The United States, b e ­ c a u se it e n jo y s a m e a s u r e of confidence of parties on both sides and has til*' m e a n s to assist them econo­ m ically and m ilita rily , re m a in s the great power best fitted to work actively with them in bringing about a se ttle­ ment. . .”

Saudi A rabia. Syria. Egypt and J o r ­ dan .” he writes, “ that it will use its leverage in the search for peace hut not unless they m ake clear th eir a c ­ ceptance of Israel’s sovereignty. 
“ At th e sa m e tim e ,” he adds, “ Is­ rael m ust he m ade to understand that a continuance of the present stalem ate 
IS m o re d an g e ro u s than the c o n c e s ­ sio n s r e q u i r e d fo r p eac e. . . T h is m ean s that our President m ust take th*' political heat from powerful and articulate pro-Israeli d o m e stic g r o u p s

Editor’s note: This is the last of a seven-part series excerpted from 
“ Super-Wealth: The Secret Lives of the 
Oil 
S h e ik s,” by 
Linda 
Blandford. This article tells the secret life of the man who invented 
OPEC. 

By LINDA BLANDFORD 
Every Thursday afternoon and som etim es on Friday an unobtrusive car drives into the 
Kuwait Hunting and Equestrian 
Club. 
A dignified m a n with a shock of white hair and an im passive, quizzical look gets out. T h e re ’s som ething about him. You know he doesn’t belong, but all the sheiks, m inisters, excellencies m ake a point of going up to him. 
Crazy horse 

He a c k n o w le d g e s th e m , s m ile s , c h a ts , th e n g o e s off to th e s ta b le s w here Jam id a , “ the crazy one,” as he calls her, is w aiting with her Texan saddle. She’s one of the rare Bahraini 
Arab horses to be sent off the island. 
The ruler of B ahrain chose her him ­ self as a present for Sheik Khalid, 
Kuwait’s top horse owner. Sheik Kha- 
1 id, p resid en t of the e m i r ’s dirw an, presented h er to his m an . The m an mounts Ja m id a ; rides off by himself. 
He’s a loner; that m uch is clear. 
OPEC idea 

W here does he com e from? 
He holds Kuwaiti, Syrian, Algerian, 
Jordanian, and, m ost recently, Saudi 
A rabian p a ssp o rts. I t’s the last that gives the key. 
He was the m a n who had the idea that becam e OPEC. 
He was the first A rab to talk of nationalizing oil, the first to say: “ Arab oil for the A rabs.” Abdullah a1 Tariki was the first Saudi A rabian Minister of 
Petroleum and Mineral Resources. 
The story of oil in the Mideast is the story of his life, except that he would never com prom ise and he was an hon­ est man. 
Abdullah a1 T ariki c a n ’t be bothered to tell that story. He looks to the future; the p ast d o e sn ’t m a tte r to him . But eventually he unlocks it for me. 
No borders 

His father had a caravan th at went betw een R iy a d h an d K u w ait. W hen 
Abdullah w as born in 1919, in what is now S a u d i A r a b ia , t h e r e w e re no countries, no borders. 
His father took him to Kuwait slung over the side of his cam el in a sack ( “ I was only 6 and he expected m e to stay on the back of a cam e l all night'. I kept losing my headdress or my stick.” ) 
He was to stay with a half-brother and go to school. “ In the m ornings I’d get up and clean the house and in the evenings I d collect our goats out in the desert. It’s all villas there now.” 

His apprenticeship started at ll. Ile w as s e n t a lo n e on a s t e a m s h i p to 
Bombay to work for a m erchant. 

The m erchan t couldn’t read or write; 
Abdullah could do both. He becam e the m erch ant’s secretary and bookkeeper. 

His chance 

The next tr a d e r he worked for felt this quick-witted urchin should be gi­ ven a chance. He sent him back from 
India to Arabia with a letter of intro­ d u ctio n to th e S a u d i M in is te r of 
Finance. 

Abdullah had to ride a cam el from 
Kuwait across to Mecca to present it. 
On the basis of that letter he was cho­ sen to receive schooling in Cairo. 

To this day he boasts of being the school’s sw im m in g cham pion ( “ breast stroke” ); mostly he studied. 

“ I w anted to be an en g in ee r even though I was very d u m b in chemistry. 
An Egyptian officer told m e that when 
Clod created people, he created their w ealth w ith th e m , but it w as up to them to find it. 

K IN G FA ISA L 
. had a gru d ge 

 second wife (the A m erican had left years ago) until 1979. 

The Lebanese kicked him out w ith­ out w arning or explanation. The long a m i of F aisal’s unrelenting spite had reached Beirut 

He trie d w orking from C airo , but who can with a telephone system that takes two days per call? 

The Kuwaitis were delighted to have nim when he moved here. “ H e’s come hom e,” they say. 

For the past IO years he’s been an oil consultant to m any governm ents (just look at the list of passports) He also p u b lish e s a m a g a z in e . “ T h e Oil of 
A rabs.” 

W hen K ing F a is a l w a s sh o t, A b­ dullah flew to Saudi Arabia to make peace with an old friend, now King 
Khaled. 

He g o t his p a s s p o rt b a c k , but he c a n ’t see why I should find it su rp ris­ ing th at soon afterw ard he published an a rtic le in his m a g a z in e h ead ed . 
“ Rem ove the P arasites from Around the Crown.” 

It a tta c k e d everyone a ro u n d King 
Khaled “ Khaled is my hope, but he’s 

. . . . They ll always spend, never pro- duce. We open a tap, let out the oil and change it into dollars . . . . What we have is a torrent of rain and no dams. 

“ He told m e that when he served in 
T urkey he saw geologists running up and dow n the m o u n tain s looking for m in e r a ls , looking for w ealth. T h at sounded like a good idea.” 

N ext c a m e a sc h o la rsh ip to C airo 
University and after that a m a s te r's degree in geology and petroleum e n ­ gineering in Texas. 

He w as to become the first Saudi oil technocrat. 

“ In C airo th e A m e ric a n s w e re so­ m ething new to us. They m eant a lot of go ld w a tc h e s , g o ld rin g s , a lot of chew ing gum . I ju st got the idea th at I would like A m ericans very m u c h .” 

New Y ork? He hated it. 

“ I had no money but I got a guide­ book and walked into the first hotel I saw listed. It was the Waldorf-Astoria • 
— can you believe I was that naive? I ended up in the best I could afford, a m attress on a m attre ss on a floor be­ hind T im e s S q uare.” 

Loathed Texas 

T exas? He loathed it. He was lonely. 
“ I m et an A m erican, a blonde, who wanted to m a rry m e; she liked m e ." 
She liked him engh to m arry him and go back to Saudi Arabia with him. 

W en he returned the Saudis placed him with Arameo in Dhahran. Ile was the only qualified A rab in an A m erican joint, and Arameo did n’t like it. 

T hey w anted to house him in the 
Arab workers* barrack s. He held out for an American-executive apartm ent. 
That solved nothing; his wife w as os­ tra c iz e d for m a r ry in g a n ative 
“ It w asn ’t a happy tim e ." A typical Ab­ dullah rem ark . 

In 1958 K ing S au d m oved h im to 
Jedd ah to be the country’s top m an in oil. 

Becomes minister 

In 196o he was m ad e m inister (Ya- m ani w as nothing then). Abdullah was a power. 

He had a house by the sea, full of p eo p le, la u g h te r, g azelles, d o g s — 
King S au d ’s castoffs. 

“ King Saud brought five greyhounds fro m E n g la n d b e c a u s e he felt like racing them . When he got tired of the idea I took on th e dogs. T hey w ere m ales and females, so I ended up with 
17." He always turns everything into a joke. 

T h e o il-c o m p a n y m en h a te d 
Abdullah. He found some weak points in t h e i r b o o k k e e p in g . He fo r c e d 
A ram eo to pay back $145 million. 

“ My own aim was to break our 5o-59 participation agreem ent with them . I spent a year negotiating with a J a p a n ­ ese com pany to give us 56-44 Then I found out that F a isa l’s brother-in-law, 
K a m a l A d h a m , w as th e ir a g e n t 
T h ey’d already given him a million dollars com m ission, but on top of that they had a secret ag reem en t to pay him 2 per cent of their profit. I got m ad ,” one of his favorite phrases. “ I forced the Japanese to cancel the 2 per cent commission to A dham . I think 
F aisal never forgave me for th a t." 

 surrounded by parasites and since I ve always said what I believe, why stop now?” 
Don Quixote 

This Don Quixote and I talk in many places his office, his club, his car. 
One day he invites m e to dinner. He wants me to m eet his son. At the club he’s a respected figure. 
In his office in the 1o-story Kuwait 
A irw a y s 
“ s k y s c r a p e r , ” h e ’s a com m anding figure. To oilm en every­ where he’s an historical one. 
I walk into an ap a rtm e n t w here the television is alm o st b ig g e r th an the living room . T he food is a m p le , his hospitality w arm , but th e flat is too sm all for it to be anything but simple. 
He doesn’t mind I don’t m ind. His son 
Zakhr does. 

Abdullah's son 

Z akhr is tall, slender, and as good­ looking as Abdullah m u st have been at his age — he’s 24. 
What strikes me is the contradiction of his outer shyness and inner anger. 
He doesn’t know whom it’s directed at 

He hardly knows his father, from his childhood in Jed d ah he rem em b ers a big, powerful b ea r living in splendor. 
He’s stuck with an aging m an, who 
(naturally) seem s sm all to him now. 
He can only talk to him through a ser­ vant w ho’s b een w ith his fath er for years. He doesn’t know what to say. 
What is he supposed to have in com­ mon with Abdullah? 
Z a k h r is th e son of th e d iv orced 
American wife. He grew up hating his absent father; he still w o n’t see his 
L ebanese ste p m o th e r and 6-year-old half-sister. 
F or the m o m e n t, fortunately, they live in Cairo. Abdullah goes there for a week every m onth 
Not American 
Why is Z akhr here at all? Because he’s not A m erican, although he sounds like one. He w as brought up in Beirut and the U.S. H e’s graduated from Yale 
University and he needs a job. 
• 
Every tim e he goes to the States he has a hassle with the im m igration people; he has Saudi traveling papers. 
He needs his father to help him get work in the only country w here he’s legally supposed to belong — Saudi 
Arabia 
“ Am I an A rab'' T w ouldn’t be if I’d been allowed to se ttle in the States easily. So I d o n’t know what I am. But 
I’ve come to live h ere anyw ay. The outward things a re n ’t hard 
“ I can put on the h ea d d ress (I al­ ways see him w earing jeans and a red sw eater), and it’s like a wall around my eyes, m y secu rity blanket if you like. The inner things, those are what I can’t work o u t.” 
Zakhr went to Jed d ah recently. The 
Juffali m erch an t family, powerful enough I’d have thought to m ake their own a p p o in tm e n ts, p ro m ised him a job. He’s sitting here at supper; he’s heard nothing. 
His father’s son 
L ater in London I’m told by a top 
Saudi that word probably went to the 
Juffaiis that Abdullah al Tariki was all right again, but not all right enough for them to hire his son 
Zakhr m ay be a 24-year-old much- n eeded Y a le g r a d u a t e , an d w h a t’s more a Saudi. But in traditional Arabia he's first the son of his father. 
No one c la im s that Abdullah a1 T ar­ iki was d isho n est or subversive. The way it was put to m e in London by a man close enough to the throne to know was: 
“ He was ahead of his time. Nationa­ lization w asn ’t in fashion then; it was a w ord a1 T a r i k i s h o u ld n e \ e r have used.” 
A bdullah a1 T arik i is p lanning on going back to Saudi Arabia. Mostly for his son ’s s a k e , altho ug h h e ’d never admit it, partly for his own. He’s going to buy a ranch and speak his mind 
“ You have to be in a place where you can be effective. Look at them , every one of them is corrupt. It’s disgusting. 
No one is secu re in that country. No wonder they just want to m ake their 

■ v 

G A S burnoff fla re s up o v e r a refinery 

 money fast and get out I'm 56 
“ I shall go back to Saudi Arabia and 
I shall go on saying what I believe. And if a truck ‘accidentally’ runs m e over or I suffer a ‘p rem ature heart attack ,' b etter that way. I would rather finish it like that than learn to be afraid. 
Revolution 
“ Once I thought revolution m igh t be an answ er. Now I see what the m ilitary ones have done in other countries — they change the old bad ways for new bad ways. I feel — I hope — that all it needs is time. 
“ G ive th e m enough y ears and the people, even the royal fam ilies, will learn enough to m ake chang es from the inside. It’s safer that way.” 
One day w e're driving along the sea road and Abdullah falls silent; it’s un­ like him by now 
Ile thinks for a while and then says with deep feeling 
“ I f s u seless to be a Kuwaiti or a 
Saudi. It’s a piece of a tiling, i f s not a th in g rn itself. T his is what oil has done. This change is not normal. Rags to riches can happen to individuals, not 

 to nations. 
“ T h e s e a r t if i c ia l c r e a t i o n s like 
K u w ait, d ra w n on a m a p by o th e r powers, th ey’ll never accom plish a n ­ ything T h e y ’ll alw ays sp en d , never produce. We open a tap. let out the oil and change it into dollars. They call us the ‘oil producing cou ntries.’ T h at’s a joke. 
So stupid 

“ W hat we have is a to rren t of rain and no dam s. We are so, so stupid. 

“ I rem em b er once the B ritisher St. 
John Philby told King Ibn Saud that he s h o u ld n ’t touch the p eo ple, that he shouldn’t let the oil touch their lives 

‘‘At the tim e we thought he was a colonial, an im p erialist stooge I re ­ m em ber how I laughed at him. Now I wonder if he w asn’t right after all "

1963, Abdullah a1 T ank ! went too. 

" I ch o se to re s ig n lf I h a d n ’t, I would have been fired It was obvious 
A ram eo w anted my head. I co u ld n ’t stay in the country without working, and so I went to live somewhere else I w asn't bitter about it I can't h ate." 

The 
Algerian and 
Kuwaiti gov­ ern m en ts im m ediately took h un on as, their oil adviser, posts he still holds.

R eleasing terrorist 
OK — Bell 

WASHINGTON (A F ) - Atty. Gen. G riilin Bell said Friday it was only a m inor concession to au th­ orize the tem porary release of the Hanafi Muslim leader responsible for taking m ore than IOO hostages in Washington last week. 
“ This was really a very m inim al action I thought, given the release of the hostages, that it was not a drastic thing to do,” Bell said at a news conference. 
L ater in the day, he sp o k e to so m e 6oo of the 
Justice D epartm ent’s thousands of employes to out­ line his goals and respond to their questions. 
Budget 
In line with the C arter a d m in is tra tio n ’s budget cutting efforts, Bell said, “ There will be growth in the departm ent only w here need d ictates growth 
Costs will be pared w henever and w herever possi­ ble." 
A black attorney ex p ressed concern that blacks and other minorities have few opportunities for jobs as d epartm ent law yers except in the civil rights division. Bell said he would try to hire m ore m inor­ ity lawyers and assign them throughout the depart­ ment . 
As he had promised at the news conference, Bell admonished d epartm ent em ployes not to disclose confidential inform ation ab ou t pen d in g crim in al investigations. 
“ You can do great h a rm to som eone’s rights if erroneous information gets out about a grand jury investigation which m ay com e to nothing,” Bell told the employes. 

His decision 

At the news conference, the attorney general said he personally auth orized the re le a s e of H am aas 
Abdul Khaalif on his personal recognizance after the 
Hanafi leader and his ll co m rades surrendered to police and freed the hostages they had held captive in three Washington buildings for 38 hours. 
He said he approved the action on condition that a judge agree to it, and Superior Court Jud ge Harold 
Greene went along. 
No other promises were m ade to the Hanafi Mos­ lems, Bell said. “ T h ere’s no agreem ent except for one man, Khaalis, being released on his own recog­ nizance," 
He noted that Khaalis did not seek im m unity from prosecution and “ I would not have given him im ­ munity " Except for restrictions on travel, Khaalis remains free pending a g rand jurv indictment 

Negotiate 

In terrorist situations, Bell said police should be free to negotiate with gunm en in un effort to free hostages. “ It probably w ould to* a very foolish course to refuse to negotiate at all After all, you re trying ta save lives ”
