San Antonio EXPR ESS-N EW S— 
Saturday March I 9 I 9 7 7 
Page 
I -B 
M oldova met a far diilerenr destiny 
The city that spawned 
.A. 

History makes them twins. 
There are few c itie s w hose early d a y s are m ore clo sely entwined than these two. 
T he o ld e r is M on clo va — on the 
Monclova R iver in Coahuila, Mexico. 
The other is San Antonio — on the 
San Antonio River in Texas. U. S. A. 
For m any y ears they wore not in two stall's but in one — tile stat!' of Coa­ huila and Texas. 
Monclova was its capital, both when it was a province of Spain and a state in Mexico. 
But San Antonio cam e close to suc­ ceeding M onclova as the cap ital of 
Coahuila and Texas. 
Tried to move 

In a d ram atic m ove to forestall rival 
Saltillo, the state's governor, Augustin 
Viesca. in 1S35 gathered up the official documents in Monclova and headed for 
San Antonio. 
Ills intention w as to m ake San An­ tonio the s ta te 's capital He and his allies never got across the Rio G rande despite two attem pts. 
Bonnie and I spent last weekend in 
Monclova. 
Our mission w as to visit the places in 
Monclova tied with San Antonio's his­ tory. 
We could not have had a more able guide — herself an example of the ties 

F our days later he mow'd up the river and founded the Villa de B ejar — now 
San Antonio. 
History seem ed far away last F riday m orning when Patricia, Bonnie and I looked at that c o rn e r w h ere the Go­ v ern o r’s Palace stood. 
Now on that corner are the Panifi- c a d o ra P r i m a v e r a ( S p r in g tim e B a ­ kery), La Bartita Merceria (a notions s to re ), L icores N aeional (a m o d ern liquor store), a law yer’s office and the 
Carniceria La Central (butcher shop). 
Above the liquor store is a Cerveza 
C arta Blanca sign and a h ig h e r and larger Coca Cola billboard — “ refresea en g ran d e." 
F a rb e r we had seen a photograph of the last of the Governor s P alaces that had stood on the spot. We w ere s u r ­ prised that it had been torn down as recently as the 196os. 
Monclova. the site of A larcon's cap) tol when he w as g o v ern o r, and San 

For m a n y years M onclova arni San A ntonio were not in tw o states but in on e — the state o f Con• bailo a n d Texas 

 between the two cities She was pretty, young Sra. P atricia Alvarez de Valdez. 
Patricia is the daug hter of Patricia 
O'Connell, who lived several years in 
Monclova and now heads the interna­ tional division of the San Antonio Con­ vention and V isitors Bureau. 
Main plaza 

It was a high point of our trip when 
P a tric ia A lv are z de V aldez took us down to the im pressive main plaza of 
Monclova. 
On one c o r n e r of that plaza once 
Mood the Coahuila and Texas G over­ nor's Palace. 
M artin de A la rc o n , as g o v e rn o r. lived iii that p a la c e when he set out from Monclova to lead an expedition into Texas. 
On that expedition, on May I. 171k, 
Alarcon founded the Mission of San 
Antonio de V alero — now the Alamo 

Antonio, the town he founded, m et far different destinies. 
San Antonio surpassed its "tw in " in growth. 
But Monclova. on Mexico Highway 57 

 about 15o m iles south of Eagle Pass- 
P iedras N egras, has a m ajor role in 
Mexico's economy. 
It is the sit«' of Altos Homos — liter­ ally 
‘High O vens” but translates as 
"Blast F u rn ace s." 
Plant No. 2 of Altos H omos is now being built. When it is completed Altos 
Homos will be the largest steel mill from th*' Rio G rande to the southern tip of South A merica. 
Success story 
Altos H om os is an alm ost u n b e lie­ vable business success story. 
It was founded as a sm all steel mill as recently as 1941 
Its founder was 
Harold R. P a p e , who g r a d u a te d at 
Purdue University and then was with 
A rim o Steel before coming to Monclo­ va 
Pape died in 1975, A foundation he and M rs 
P a p e e s ta b lis h e d — and which Mrs, Pape is now adm inistering 
— is building a m ajo r m u seu m and library. 
Patricia took us by the m useum and library office where Rodolfo M artinez and Albert Chico Smith told us of som e of the p lans — and d re a m s — M rs 
Pape had for the m useum -library. It will be M o nelov a’s first m a jo r m u ­ seum. 
The m an who showed us the photo­ graph of the G overnor’s Palace — and a num ber of other pictures of historic 
Same ear, another nullo 

Here s an unusual tie between San Antonio and Monclova. 
When the Carmacks were in Monclova. Daniel Menchaca showed them photographs of earlier days. 

One was a snapshot of a mule pulling a small streetcar. 
Carmen Perry. San Antonio historian, rem em bers that mule-drawn streetcar well. 

"When I was a little girl in Monclova, my father had a plant making rubber Irom guayule." she says. "The streetcar ran out to his plant. 

"When San Antonio gave up tnule-drawn streetcars, this one wound up in Monclova. It had the San Antonio signs still on it." 

 im portance — was Daniel M enchaca 
He is recognized as M onclova’s No. I historian. 
Patricia had arran g ed for us to in­ terview Menchaca before we started our tour. We had a wonderful hour sit­ ting in the front room of his home just off a busy Monclova street as he told of the earliest history of Monclova and its ties with San Antonio. 
7 ‘foundings' 
H istorians generally credit Antonio de Balcarcel with founding Monclova in 1674 
"B ut there were seven ‘foundings’ of 
Monclova.” Menchaca aaid. "T he first goes back to 1577 and the nam e was 
Minas de la Trinidad. 
" E a rlie r it was th e capital of Coa­ huila but it becam e the capital of Coa­ huila and Texas w hen Alonso de Leon becam e governor in 1688." 
De Ia'on was one of the great early explorers of Texas — m aking five ex­ plorations. 
On a 1689 expedition, he crossed a stream he named Arroyo de Leon The 
Texas Handbook re p o rts it is believed to Im> tin' San Antonio River. 
"M any expeditions to Texas began in 
Monclova." M enchaca told us. "F ra y 
J u a n L a rio s , w ho wi t h B a lc a r c e l founded Monclova, m a d e an important early trip. 
Routes to S.A. 
"A few years later, m any of the fa m illes going to T e x a s c a m e from or passed through Monclova. There were two routes. 
"T he first crossed the Rio G rande at 
San Ju an B autista (now the town of 
G uerrero below P ie d ra s N egras). Tht other crossing was up river at El Paso de Aguilas (The P a ss of the Eagles) — hence Eagle Pass. 
"Of course, the m o st noted expedi­ tion was when Don M artin de Alarcon left th e G o v e rn o r's P a la c e h e re to found San Antonio.” 
Menchaca then showed some of his p ic tu r e s of h i s t o r i c M o n clo va places, including th e old G overnor s 
Palace. 
"O n e of the sad sto rie s is that of 
Juan V eram endi." he said 
Veramendi, a close friend of Stephen 
F. A ustin , was S an A n to n io ’s first mayor. His d aughter wed Jim Bowie. 
Veramendi was vice governor and then governor of C oahuila and T exas. He had a home in both Monclova and San 
Antonio. 
‘‘In 1833 and 1834 c h o le r a w as w id esp read ," M en ch a ca said 
"B oth 
San Antonio and Monclova were hard hit. 

This ancient church bell looks out on the historic main plaza of 
M onclova. O n the corner in the left background once stood the 

Governor's Palace. From that palace, Governor Martin de Alarcon 

 left to found San Antonio. 

“ M onelova’s population was 4,637. 
Of th e s e , 
571 d ie d in 
18 d a y s . 
V eramendi was one of them ." 
F ro m M e n c h a c a ’s hom e, P a tr ic ia took u s d o w n to w n to the h is to r i c church, the Parroquia. Jesus Abrego 
Riojas went with us as we climbed the narrow, winding stone stairway to the bell tower. Below us was the historic 

 plaza. 
We drove in front of the fine stone building that centuries ago was a ho­ spital and then a jail. Now it is an arm y post. 
"In 1811 more than 3oo of P adre Hi­ d a lg o ’s follow ers s e e k in g fre e d o m from Spain were jailed in it," Men-

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Saturday March 19 1977 
Mart slip slight Business and Finance 

 fM rsftoTO Tflt ft xrxr-ta a. 
Kl 'V a r IN D E X at index report 

N EW Y O R K (A P ) - 
The stock market, show­ ing little response to an expected jum p in the consumer price index, recorded a small decline for the second straight session Friday. 

The Dow Jones average of 3o industrial stocks slipped 3.82 to 961.o2, closing out the week with a net gain of 13.3o points. 

Losers held a 7-6 edge on gainers at the New 
York Stock Exchange. 
Big 
Board volume eased off to 19.84 million shares from 2o.7o million on Thursday. 
As the market opened 

 the government reported that tho consumer price index jumped I per cent last month—equal to a 12 per cent annual rate. 
It was the sharpest in­ crease registered by the measure of inflation trends in 2% years. 
Analysts noted pres­ sure on some glamor stocks, with some invest­ ing institutions evidently anxious to lighten their holdings in that de­ pressed sector of the market before making their first quarter reports. 
Standard & Poor’s in­ dex of 4oo industrials 

 dropped .29 to 113.37, and 
S& P’s 5oo-stock compo­ site index was down .22 at 
1o1.86. 
Glamor issues show ing losses at the 4 p.m. close of the N Y S E included 
Eastman Kodak, down 
2*4 at 7o%; Burroughs, off I at 68%; McDonald’s, down I Vs at 44%, and 
Walt Disney Productions, 
% lower at 38%. 
The N Y SE’s composite index gave up .o9 to 55.36. 
On the American Stock 
Exchange, the market value index fell .26 to 
112.46. The NAS DAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market closed at 96.44, up .o2.

LATEST WEEK 
---- - 

M exicana gets new regional manager 

Express-News analysis 

ANALYSIS SY CHARLES E CARDEN 
M ONDAY 
- 
After opening on the familiar draggy note of the last several weeks, the mar­ ket staged a surprise late rally and the Dow 
Jones Industrial Average posted its best rise of the year. It gained 1o.64. The action centered on blue chips, with the Dow ris­ ing 1.12 per cent against a rise of o.69 for the 
N YSE Index of all com­ mon stocks. There was divergence even among the blue chips, with A l­ coa posting a new 1977 high and A T & T a new 
1977 low. No fundamental news sparked the rally; technicians said it was evidence that recent selling pressure had been satisfied and toe-testing on the upside was in order. 
TU ESD AY - The rally continued and this time was supported by im ­ proved volume. Trading at 23,94o.ooo shares was the highest in five weeks, and the D JIA , up 6.65, posted its highest close in seven weeks. The upside action broadened, with advancing issues running two to one over declines, and upside volume near­ ly three to one over de­ clining volume. 
W E D N ES D A Y - The bulls beat back profit taking that developed 

 naturally after the 17 point advance of the pre­ vious two days. The Dow held in a narrow range and closed up 2.99. It achieved its fifth conse­ cutive advance for the first time this year. 
American Can, one of the 
Dow components, posted a new 1977 high. 
THURSDAY - Bulls were cheered as the market was able to cut in half an early loss of more than 6 points in the D JIA. 
It closed off 3.16, its best reading of the day. The loss followed a rise of 25 points in five days. 

FR ID A Y 
— An early news item helped tilt the market to the downside. 
A Labor Department re­ port that the February consumer price index rose to a 12 per cent an­ nual rate (higher than had been expected) in­ fluenced the Dow Indus­ trials in posting a loss of 
3.82. Of the the 3o stocks making up the 
Dow average, seven ad­ vanced, 17 declined and six remained unchanged. 
Kodak suffered the worst loss, off 2%. 

S U M M A R Y 
- The market ran rampant on the first part of the week, but the rally wilted. Ne­ vertheless, the 
Dow 
Jones Industrial Average 

 posted its second weekly gain in three weeks. 

RA N G E — High was made on Wednesday at 
971.58. Low was made on 
Monday at 944.73. Close, 
Friday, 961.o2. Gain on the week, 13 3o. Volume, all shares traded on the 
N Y S E , 1o5.91 m illion shares. 

--- ---------- 
- — 

Regional operations of 
Mexicana 
Airlines are under new leadership. 
Jesse Castillo, a native 
San Antonian, has as­ sumed the post of re­ gional sales manager. He replaces Ignacio Cedil- los, who is retiring. 
The 48-year-old Castil­ lo, who began his career with Mexicana as a re­ servations agent, said he plans to strive for in­ creased tourist exchange between Mexico and the 
U.S. 

Pattern 

That was a pattern set by his predecessor. 
By pushing for an in­ creased tourist ex­ change. Castillo said he hopes to bring home a 
Mexicana Airlines sales trophy. 
The trophy, which is currently in Chicago, is for booking flights from 

Dtc7u * iu 11bT mAR ,1 

 the U.S. and Canada to 
Mexico. 
‘i'v e accomplished my 
Castillo, who has been g „ai which was to im- with Mexicana Airlines prove the relations since 1961, was district between Mexico and the sales manager before his promotion. 
Cedillos — his prede­ cessor — was the first regional sales manager. 
He served in San Antonio nine years. 
He is retiring after 4o vears with the company. 

1^ 
JESSE C A S T IL L O , left, a s s u m e s duties of retiring Ignacio Cedillos 

 but those ill feelings have been reduced. 

U.S.” Cedillos said. 
“ I am a Mexican na­ tional .. . and I thought it necessary that the two countries understand each other.” 
He explained Mexicans had ill feelings about 
Americans 35 years ago. 

“ But, there s still a lot of room for a greater ex­ change of people and I believe once the econo­ mic situation in Mexico stabilizes more Mexican tourists will be coming 
_ to San Antonio." 

Cedillos and his wife are retiring iii E l Paso.

MERCHANDISE 
MART 

Call 
225-1666 

Sugar futures looked steady this week in de­ fiance of developments which have at best left the market with many uncertainties to ponder upon. 
The May contract pen­ etrated substantial resis­ tance around the 9.15 per pound level on the charts although this feat was not accomplished without some muscle flexing. 
It is well known news by now the U.S. Food and 
Drug 
Adm inistration plans to take saccharin off the market and has furthermore projected this could take place as early as mid-summer although the unexpected­ ly m assive public opposition to such a ban could set tho FD A ’s ti­ metable back. 

Impact 

What is less well known at this time is — with some degree of ex­ actness — what impact a 

 saccharin ban will have on sugar prices both in the domestic and in the world market, and what possibility there is in­ dustry and consumer groups opposing the ban might mobilize quickly and effectively enough to override the F D A ’s at­ tempted ban on the only artificia l sweetner a l­ lowed on the U.S. m ar­ ket. 

While pound per pound replacement of saccharin with sugar, assuming a 
3oo times sugar sweet­ ness equivalency, would require about 8oo,ooo tonnes of sugar per year in addition to an esti­ mated annual usage of 
9.8 million tonnes, it is expec ted only a portion of that amount will actually be replaced with sugar. 
Dieters and diabetics will obviously not readily return to sugar once sac­ charin is taken off the market. 

COMMODITY 
REPORT furnished bv (herald S. 
Cohn, \ ice president, safes division. San An­ tonio office, Bache liai­ se* Stuart Inc. 

It is estimated about 56 

 per cent of the artificial sweetener market would be replaced by sugar. 
This would come out to about 4o6.ooo tonnes ad­ ditional sugar use per year in the U.S. 
The 
International 
Trade Commission, how­ ever. belittled the poten­ tial of sugar to replace saccharin when it decid­ ed last week that since a ban on saccharin would amount to an additional need for sugar of only about 125,ooo tonnes in 
1977, that a 4.275 million tonne quota on foreign imports into the U.S. this 

 year would he adequate. 
That means an already over-supplied world market will have less ac­ cess to its outlets in the 
U.S. than orig inally thought. 
Futures have been left to ponder whether or not the potentially bullish ban on saccharin will ac­ tually take place, whether it will mean that much to U.S. suear con­ sumption and whether a possibly too-low foreign import quota, in the event of a ban on sac­ charin, might be expand­ ed on later review. 

Read Ann Landers 

On Life 

 and Love 

 in the San Antonio Express

1675. Fray 
Juan Larios, one of the founders of 
Monclova and of this chapel, was one of the first priests to come to Texas.

We went to the Ermi- tade Zapopan, a church built in the 17oos — to the church of San Francisco dc Asis — to all that is left, a beautiful restored part of the wall, id the chapel of La Pursim a. 
All had San Antonio and 
Texas tics 
Bul no story in Mon- cima matches in senti­ ment and San Antonio ties the slurs of the (icr- man flour m illers 
Bonnie and I learned of these m illers when we did a story on 
A < 
Thomac s historic Yndo 
Bandi in VV ilsoti ('minty 
Millers 

These m illers cann* from San Antonio -- and even earlier from New 
Braunfels — about KIO years or more ago 
Barly Saturday P a tri­ cia, Bonnie and I drove west from 
Monclova through the beautiful countryside — semi-de­ sert and green, irrigated 

 f i e l d s 
About UU miles out the road to Torreon there was a sm all roadside sign that said ” < ’eternal)* la.” This is a condensed 

 version of Ciudad del 
Alemania or, in English, 
“ Germantown.” 
The setting was spec­ tacular. We were at the loot of a long mountain range — high, rugged and blue. D irectly in front of us a pretty little river came out of a deep gorge 
On a swift m illrace from the river stood a tall, white flour mill Its gates said “ Molinos del 
C arm en” 
— 
Carmen 
Mills. An old fashioned millstone was imbedded in the wall on each side of the wide gates 
Mill story 
VV e drove inside and soon were talking with the m ill’s owner, Marin 
Miller We never met a man we liked more on first sight 
As he showed the three of u s all through the mill 
— even drove (lowii to where the drive shaft cairn* off the big water­ wheel — he told us the mill s remarkable story aud its San Antonio con­ 

 n e c t i o n s 
"M y grandfather, F e ­ derico M ueller, came here from San Antonio and started the mill iii 
IST!) Ile had been an as­ sociate of CMI Guenther 

 in founding the Pioneer 
Flour M ills in San An­ tonio in 1851,” M ille r said. 
“ My grandfather had one unusual experience. 
Ile was attending Ford’s 
Theatre in Washington the night Lincoln was shot. 
" I still have relatives iii San Antonio. My cou­ sin, Carlotta Gonzales 
Miller de I'rrutia, is the widow of Dr. Urrutia.” 
(Dr I'rrutia. who died here in 1975 at 194. was one of the most famous surgeons San Antonio ever had.) 
“ When my father started m illing wheat hen*.” Miller continued. 
“ some of the flour was sold in San Antonio — hauled there by ox cart 
That was a haul of about TIKI m iles — by plodding oxen. 
During its 98 years the m ill has gone through troubled times 
In the 
Mexican Revolution, the 
Carranza forces and the federalists fought a bat­ tle here. 
“ My father’s brother was killed in the battle and the m ill was hurtled,” Miller said. 
But the m ill’s past — with its m oth birthday coming iii 1979 — doesn't 

 keep Miller from looking to the future. He is now planning new electric equipment for the mill. 
On our way back to 
Monclova, we stopped at the pretty town of San 
Buenaventure and talked with Carlos Thomac. an irrigation company offi­ cial lh* is related to the 
San Antonio Thomaes. 
The Thomae fam ily, out of loyalty to the 
Union. went to Monclova during the Civ ii War. 
“ My grandfather. Teo- doro Thomae, estab­ lished the first flour milli rn this region in 1872." 
Carlos Thomae said. 
“ The fam ily had been m illers in New Brau n ­ fels 
“ It operated until the 
194os. Viator to power the mill became scarce be­ cause it was needed for irrigation so the mill was closed." 
Our reception bv 
Carlos Thomae was no 
.less hospitable than that by Miller. 
Diary 
Back in San Antonio, I went to the Daughters of the Republic of Texas 
Library at the Alamo and read much of the “ Diary of the 
Alarcon 
Expedition.’’ Reading it 

 in the mission that Alar­ con and Fray O livares founded added to its dra­ ma. 
The diary was lost more than 29o years. It was found in 1955 in the national archives in 
Mexico City and trans­ lated in 1955 by Fritz Lee 
Hoffman. A reader of the diary must agree with 
Hoffman: 
“ One can hut marvel at 
Alarcon's substantial ac­ complishments.” 
But it is also heart­ warming to know those 

 early day greats had their human side. 

F ra y 
O livares was authorized IO soldiers as a guard. He asked Alar­ con for “ ten m arried men of good habits.” 
Gruff soldier Alarcon re­ plied that he had no 
“ apostolical college” from which to recruit such men. 

But Olivares in time got his men. And the mission he nurtured at its birth will live forever.

 xsssSsss l l . , , urs must go or blow 

By JE F F Cl ROSSM AN 
OF THI EXPRESS N EW S STAFF 
RICHFIELD, Ohio - The 
Spurs’ Week of Reckoning be­ gins Saturday when they face the Cleveland Cavaliers at the 
Coliseum at 7:oo p.m. CST. 

In the next seven days, the Spurs will play six games in five cities in three time zone's. 
Every g am e is against a playoff 

^ TI , Channel 12. 7 ft.rn. 

Irani, and five of them are against 
Eastern Conference contenders. 
The only Eastern power the Spurs do not play are themselves. 

After Saturday’s gam e, they go to 
Washington for a Sunday night game against the Bullets. Monday, m erci­ fully, will be a day off. 
The Spurs play Boston at hom e 
Tuesday, meet the Nuggets in Denver 

Wednesday, face the Rockets at home 
Thursday, and fly to Philadelphia to meet the Sixers Friday. 
It is both an exhausting and crucial week. 
“ I hate to bunch games together,” 

 said Spurs Coach Doug Moe, “ but I suppose if we go 3-3 or above against those teams, we'd be doing pretty well. 
“ Sure, the travel is difficult, but we can’t concern ourselves with that. At this point in the season, we have to 
P la y o ff tic k e ts o n sa le 

Spurs’ season ticketholders will be receiving their order forms for home playoff games in the immediate future. 
The Spurs’ management has said that tickets to the first four home games are available. 
Season ticketholders have the option of picking up their regular seats as well as ordering additional tickets to the four games. 
However, in keeping with NBA policy, prices have been 

 raised one dollar across the board to $8, $b and $4 
General Manager John Begzos said season ticketholders have until 5 p.m. April I to return the order forms 
Begzos addt'd that should the Spurs be eliminated before playing four home playoff contests, "season ticketholders who purchased four games worth of tickets could either apply the purchase to next year or have their money refunded. 

 continue to play well 
The Spurs have won seven of their last eight games, but only one of their victims — the Cavs — were above the 
.5oo mark. 
And it is still but a short distance from first to third place in the Central. 

“ lf we can stay close we’re in good shape,” said Moe. “Washington’s lost a lot lately, but they still have a good home schedule. They had a lock on it before their slump. 

“ Right now it depends on Houston. 
They finish the season with something like six of their last eight games on the road. When Houston com es to our place Thursday, it ll be a two-game swing.”

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS N EW S 

HOUSTON — Trinity’s Erick 
Iskersky upset third-seeded .Jai 
DiLouie of Southern Methodist 
Friday as the Tigers clinched a tie for the team title at the 19th 
Annual Rice Invitational Tennis 
Tournament. 

With two days remaining. Trinity is on top with 18 points, six ahead of second-place SMU. Texas is a distant third with eight points. Trinity, win­ ners of the last two Rice Invitational titles, has three singles players and two doubles teams left. SMU has both doubles teams, but just one singles player left. 
Iskersky. unseeded bere and the No. 
4 player at Trinity, downed the No. I 
SMU star. 7-6 (5-4). 3-6. 6-o. He fol­ 

 lowed that triumph with a 6-2, 6-1 vic­ tory over Texas’ Gary Ploek. 
“ I never served better in my life." 
Iskersky, a freshm an from Toledo, 
Ohio, said. “ I do not know why I serve 

✓ R E S I LTS, Pa fie ru: 

 great one day and not the next. Nor­ mally, my serve is not as much of a weapon as it was today." 
DiLouie was in com m and in the opening set against Iskersky, leading 
5-1 and preparing to serve out the set. 
But Iskersky broke serve and won four 

 s tra ig h t gam es. He broke DiLouie again to go up 6-5. but DiLouie re­ tu rn ed the favor, forcing th e tie ­ breaker. 

“This is the best day I have had at 
Trinity.” Iskersky said. 

TU team m ates Tony G iam m alva, the top seed, and Larry Gottfried, the 
No. 4 seed, also won their m atches 
Friday and will meet in one of Satur­ day's . semifinals. 

Second-seeded Ben McKown was the lone Trinity loser, dropping a 6-2, 6-4 m atch to SMU’s Chris Delaney. De­ laney and Iskersky will be in the other singles semifinal. 

Trinity, the top-ranked team in the country and champion here IU times, had its two doubles teams get wins Friday, too._____________

PHILADELPHIA 
(AP) 
- 
George McGinnis scored 22 of his 28 points in the first half, powering the Philadelphia 7hers to a 124-1o4 win over the Houston 
Rockets in a heated battle of two 
National Basketball Association leaders Friday night. 

Holding a 31-3o lead early in the se­ cond period, the 76ers reeled off 18 straight points to blow the game open. 
McGinnis had ll points and reserve 
Steve Mix addl'd IO as the 76crs main­ tained the 19-point lead at halftime, 
67-48 
The Atlantic Division-leading 7Bers led 96-7o after three periods.

Celtic tickets scarce 

Only a few tickets remain for next Tuesday’s NBA game in the Arena between the Spurs and Boston Celtics. 

Spur General Manager John Begzos said that all $7 tickets were sold on 
March ll, the first day they went un sale fur the Celtic contest. “ And uur Sa tickets were gone by March 14 or 15 — that’s the first time we have sold all the Sa tickets before the $3 tickets,” said Begzos. 
"Ordinarily, if people can’t get the 
I jest seats ($7), they buy the cheapest ones (S3),” he added 
Standing-room-only ducats are ex­ pected to be sold prior to the 7:35 p.in. tipoff Tuesday.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 19 1977 

St. Mary's^ Trinity in action 

Hie St. M ary’s Rattlers 7/fe-8 ) will open defense of their Big State 
Conference baseball championship Saturday against rival Texas Lutheran 
(«-<) at 2 p.m. at V .J. Keefe Field 
The Trinity Tigers will also be at home, completing a three-game series with Hardin-Simmons in 1:3o p.m. doubleheader at Stevens Field. 
Cars com pete at Pan Am tonight 

The 1977 stock car racing season resumes at Pan American speedway 
Saturday night with a full program. Including a tire rolling race and a fans’ race where six tickets will be drawn and the winners ride in a special raee with the six top drivers. 
Bowling tourney fo r D eaf slated 

The North Fast Association ol tile Beat will hold its individual Handicap 
Deaf Bowling Tourney Saturday at the Sports Palace. There will be three sessions during the day. 
The remainder of Saturday's schedule includes:

D EN VER (AP) — A ruling by a three-judge panel of the 1oth 
U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reinstated on Friday a Utah television blackout of the NCAA 
West Regional Championship 
Basketball game in Provo, Utah. 

The panel overturned an order by 
W illis Ritter, U.S. District Court chief judge for Utah to allow the Saturday afternoon Idaho State-Nevada-Las Ve­ gas game to be televised in tile state. 
Order 
Hitter issued the order T hursday in 
Salt Lake City just two hours before the start of the Nevada-Utah NCAA semifinals match, which Nevada won, 
88-83. 
Friday s ruling came in an appeal by tin* NCAA of a suit filed by Salt Lake lawyers Robert Peterson and Richard 
Allred. 
The suit contended the Utah tele­ vision blackout ordered by the NCAA violated antitrust rules and that there were irregularities in ticket sales which resulted in inadequate time lur unsold tickets allotted out-of-state schools to bv returned and sold in 
Hah. 
The NCAA filed the appeal less than 
45 minutes before the Nevada-Utah game was to begin, but Court of Ap­ peals Clerk Howard Phillips said the appeal came too late and no action was taken Thursday. 
However. Phillips said the matter was submitted to the court Friday and 
Judges Robert M cW illiam s, Jean 
Breitenstein and William Doyle over­ turned Ritter's order. 
The Nevada-Utah game was tele­ vised by Salt Lake station KU TV. No request was made to allow KUTV to broadcast the second semifinals game 
Thursday, iii which Idaho State beat 
UCLA 76-75 
NBC broadcast both games region­ ally. 
KU TV was not a party to the suit. 
But KU TV sports director Bill Mar- eroft said the station had planned to broadcast tilt* Idaho Statc-Nevada re­ gional final. 
However, Marcroft said the station has a contractual agreement with 
NHC, which has an agreement with the 
NCAA, and will abide by the Circuit 
Court's ruling.

BOSTON (A P ) — Two free throws by 
Dave Cowens with 48 seconds to play lifted the Boston Celtics to a 98-96 victory over the Atlanta Hakws in a 
National Bascctball Association game 
Friday night. 
Cowens had IO of his 18 points in the final period and the Boston center made a crucial block of Hawk John 
Brown s shot in the final two seconds. 
Boston led by Kl for most of the game, but John Drew brought the 
Hawks back to within two, 89-87, with 
5:36 to play. Drew led all scorers with 
38 points, but his desperation shot from 25 feet out alter Cowells' block went wide at the buzzer. 
Jo Jo White and Curtis Rowe topped 
Boston with ‘2(1 points each, and for­ ward Sidney Wicks added 17 for the 
Celtics. Center Steve Hawes tallied 17

Cleveland

Friday night.

Mike Bantom vv it ii 8 46 to go in the final period gave the Nets their big­ gest lead at 79-71, hut after thai the Cavaliers outscored them *2o-3 to turn the game around.

81-79 oil the last of three consecutive baskets by 
W alker. A goaltcnding call against Cuvs center 
Jim (hones permitted the Nets to tie the score, hut ( hones put Cleveland ahead for good at 83-81 by hitting a jumper with 
4:46 to play.

T rinity socked 

Hardin-Simmons pitcher Roger Con­ nell limited Trinity to just three lilts 
Friday night as the Cowboys whipped the Tigers. 5-1, at E M . Stevens Field in the first of a three-game series. 
The teams will complete the set with a 1:3o p.i i i . tvv nihil! Saturday at 
Stevens Field. 
Connell (1-2) got all the runs he needed when Phillip Tippen smacked a two-run homer in the fourth. 
Trinity (6-12) got one of those flack iii tile fifth, parlaying a walk, sacrifice, stolen base and an error into a run. 
Ruben Lozano, who got one of the three 
TC lilts, walked, moved to second on a 
Rich Squilla sacrifice, stole third and scored a miscue by second baseman 
Rusty Ratline. 
The Cowboys (111-8) added three insurance runs off losing pitcher 
Robert Ahrens (o*3) in the eighth. 
Larry Tatum doubled and Tippen walked. Ahrens got the next two liar- dui-Simmons hatters, but Rusty Dobbs reached on an error by third baseman 
Jim Summerset!, loading the bases.

K a rla B a k e r. Fox T eih. jr ., F O 

The long-limbed lass from Roosevelt broke records in the long jump and triple jump with marks of 17-9 and 
35-2. respectively in Thursday’s action. 
And came back Friday to take her third first of the meet by winning the 
22o-yard dash, in the absence of Hous­ ton's premier sprinter Debra Pennix, with a time of 26.o. Finch also ran an­ chored Roosevelt’s third-place winning 
44(1 relay and second-finishing 88o re­ lay. 
But Roosevelt could only manage second place in the team standings with 8o*7 points as the powerful Ma­ cArthur team racked up 14o to win. 
Clay tough 
In the boys’ division M arshall's 
Randy Clay was a double winner, tak­ ing firsts in the 12o high hurdles and the 33o intermediates with times of 14.4 and 38.9. 
But Clay wasn’t particularly satis­ fied with his performance. /\fter run­ ning a 14 I (best mark thus far in the city) in the highs in Friday morning’s prelims. Clay had this to say about his showing in the finals, “ it wasn't a real good raee. I ’ve been working pretty hard, but there’s nobody to push me in the highs.” 

Anderson, too 

State-leading miler Mark ;Xnderson of Jay was also dissatisfied with his first-place finish of 4:17.6. Anderson led the next closest miler in the state by IO seconds after running a 4:14.o9 lust week. 

Anderson, still winded from his race, called his performance, “ not very good." The blond haired runner ad­ ded. “ The first lane is real loose. I ran almost the whole race in the second lane. 

The 88o-yard dash was a smoker, as three of the state's top half milers lowered their times. Fox Tech’s Leon 
Banks won the race at 1:56.o with 
Churchill’s Don Jones nudging out 
Houston's David Collier for second at 
1:56.7. 

Churchill won the boys’ div ision with 
97 points, followed by Ja y (7U) and 
Houston (61).

Foreman suffers mild concussion 

SAN JU A N , F R. ( A F ) - 
George Foreman remained ho­ spitalized Friday, the result of dehydration and a slight con­ cussion, while promoter Don 
King mused about a Muhammad 
AU light in Havana and Jimmy 
Young awaited the next deve­ lopment in a suddenly booming career. 
"The doctors have decided lo keep hiin iii until tomorrow and let him rest.’’ Foreman's secretary, ( ariette 
Jackson, said Friday after the former heavsweight champion's upset loss to 
Young Thursday night. 
Miss Jackson said that “ heat pros­ tration is the only thing wrong with 

 him. All the tests are A-OK. 
It was hot as the devil in there.” said Foreman, referring lo the ring conditions at the Hitherto Clemente 
Coliseum 
But a hospital source also said that 
Foreman had suffered a slight con­ cussion. foreman said, “ I though I won the light. I thought I won Hie first seven rounds and the Kith “ 
However, on the cards of two of three officials, Young was a comfortable winner, a winner even before lie knocked down Foreman iii the 12th and final round. I hat knockdown also made Young a winner on the third of­ ficial's card. 
“ All I want to do is walk on tile l>eaeh ami cat ice cream ," said Foreman, who plans lo luke a six-week vacation.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Saturday March I 9 19 7 7__ * 

Cold, dry winter might hurt ducks 

Lamar 

 adds 

Clark 

BEAUMONT (A P) - 
.lim Clark, assistant de­ fensive secondary coach at Southern Methodist 
University, has been named linebacker coach at Lamar University. 

('lark replaces Dan 
Hooks, who resigned to become defensive coor­ dinator at West Orange 
High School. 

Clark lettered three years at Oklahoma State as a defensive back and a receiver from 196H-88. 
/★converse 
CUSTAR 

THE $ 
SHOE 1295 

» 
Ll ISI K E S I'O IIT 

 n a n M i n i \ 

2 i i \ . s t . n u n 
> 
THEE r I S K I M , 
II I I H HI IU ll ISL 

M H I I l l s ! n i 
‘hums i ii i i i I i i i n 

Snow reports from Canada in­ dicate a cold, dry winter across most of the prairie provinces could adversely affect waterfowl populations this year. 

It is hoped that heavy spring snows and rains will prevent a poor spring runoff, lf the snows and rains do not come, the number of ponds, potholes and other wetlands used by waterfowl for nesting will be reduced. 
“ .January and February weather did not significantly improve already dry conditions in the principal waterfowl breeding provinces of Alberta. Sas­ katchewan and Manitoba,” reports biologists with Ducks Unlimited. 

“ Precipitation has been 5o per cent 

 below normal in large areas of both 
Manitoba and Saskatchewan. Snow­ pack conditions in Alberta range from abote normal to insignificant.” 

Texas weather certainly Is no less predictable than that of the Canadian prairies, and the way things are going, we could experience another extremely dry spring and summer. 
Fortunately, lakes are in good shape, but if the first half of the year is dry and farmers in the Valley need large amounts of water for irrigation. Falcon and Amistad could be drawn down and not replenished by snow runoff from the Rockies. 
A dry spring and summer also could hamper 1977 production of quail, tur­ keys and antler growth on whitetail bucks. 
Big bass tournament 
The fourth annual Big Bass Tourna­ ment sponsored by Mursch Sports 
Headquarters on Medina Lake will be held April 3. 
Cash or merchandise prizes will be offered the top 2o fishermen. First place will be worth $75o and. a free mount; second place. $25o; third. $125; and fourth and fifth. $1oo each 
Contestants must register at Mursch 
Sports, o132 Bandera before ti p.m. 
April 2. 
Entry fee for the tournament is $15 per person. 
Headquarters for the contest will be located at the public boat ramp at the end of Park Road 37. Fishing hours will be from 6:3o a.m. to 5 p.m. 
★ * * 

A Colorado ice fishermen who caught 

 an illegal trout was caught by surprise this winter when up skated a game warden to issue a citation. 

Although Warden .Jim Houston of the 
Gunnison area was a little rusty at skating, he managed to check ice fi­ shermen in a 1o-mile circle during a day on the blades. 
More Saturday short shots 

And Caldwell County .Judge Leonard 
Scott was surprised when he an­ nounced that he would seek an end to deer hunting in the county. 
Very few hunters complained to the judge, but residents of the eastern section of the county did. They promptly let the judge know that it is impossible to grow vegetables in some parts of the county because of the deer. 

The judge changed his mind about 

 closing the deer season, but he still hopes to have the quail season cut in half in order to increase the number of quail in the county. 

.Judge Scott has another surprise coming. He can eliminate the quail season entirely, and it won t increase the quail population. Ohio had a closed season on quail for 5o years, and there weren’t any more quail around when the closed season ended than there were when it began. lf Caldwell County landowners want more quail, all they have to do is de­ velop more and better quail habitat. 
They’ll soon learn they can’t stockpile the short-lived little birds. 
★ ★ ★ 
Still on the subject of surprises, there were some bewildered pheasants in Matagorda County earlier this month when wildlife biologists dropped nets on them from a heli­ copter. Those pheasants probably thought they had encountered a hawk to end all hawks. 
The method of capturing birds was developed nine years ago by the Texas 
Parks and Wildlife Department when the Air Force needed some prairie chickens moved. The chickens were using landing strips as booming grounds. 

The device developed is a circular 

 net attached to the skids of a heli­ copter. The birds, which couldn't be trapped on the ground because of wet conditions, were flushed by the copter, then pursued until they tired. The copter then hovered over the bird, and the net was dropped. 

It took biologists only a couple of hours to capture seven pheasants. The birds were fitted with transmitters so that their movements can be followed, then released. 

Gant puts it straight 

In broad bold stripes and contrasting collar to set this cool and comfortable all-cotton knit apart from the rest of the crowd. It’s definitely not just another shirt.

Dodgers select advisory board 

An Advisory Board, which will serve as a steering committee to promote San Antonio’s pro baseball team was announced Friday by owner Wally Moon. 

The nine member board is made up business and professional leaders in San 
Antonio. 
Moon said the board was formed “ to lend its experience and knowledge of San 
Antonio and the community at large” to General Manager Wally .Joe Moon in his first year with the club. 

Named to the board were: 
.John Barger, vice-president and general manager, radio station WOA1; Bob 
Farmer. Sigmor Oil Company; Dr. .J..J. Maniatis, dentist; .John Monfrey, beer distributor; Tom Murrah, president, .Jefferson State Bank; Is. Charles Neely, 
Knowlton’s Dairy; Bill Schliek, Estate Management Group; Joe Ii. Straus, .Jr., 
Frank Co.; and Lyle Van Doozer, General manager. Gebhardt’s.

F O R T W O RTH ( A P ) - T ex as A&M follow ed th e p o w e r h ittin g of first b a se m a n Kyle H aw thorne and d e sig ­ nated h itte r T im F e ic k e r t to a 5-1

2 p .m . 
Saturday.

IOO freestyle event, had the fa stest tim e in the 5o and also qualified to d efend h e r 
IOO crown. Hyde had the fastest m a r k in the I DO b r e a s t r o k e in a d d i t i o n to g a in in a fin als b e r th in t h e 2oo I n ­ dividual medley.

Ark. (A P ) - The Uni­ versity of Arkansas be­ gins spring football practice Saturday with­ out Frank Broyles as head coach for the firsl time since 1957, 
Broyles gave up his coaching duties late last year to spend full time as athletic director.

B u c k le y leads 

NORTH OLM STK I), Ohio (A P) - 
Roy Huck ley of Columbus, Ohio, won seven of eight matchplay games F ri­ day to take the lead in the $75,ooo 
Professional Howlers Association tournament. 
Buckley, seeking his first victory this season, advanced from third place with games of 225. 225. 192, 236. 195, 
238, 297 and 223 for an eight-game block of 1.742, a 217 average. His 
34-game total, including 4o5 bonus inns for 13 match play victories, is 8,o34. 
Pete Coil tun of Windsor, Conn., who started the day in fifth place, jumped to second by winning six matches. Ills 
34-game total was 7.9KH Rounding out the top five were George Poppas of 
Charlotte. N C., with a 7.977 total, 
Jim m y Certain of Huntsville. Ala . 
7,97o, and Wayne /.alin of Tempe, 
Ari/., 7 929 Wayne Webb of Rehoboth, 
Mass., the leader since the first round, averaged dilly 189 and fell to loth

McCullough leads by 2 over Watson 

JACKSONVILLE. Fla. (AP) — Mike McCullough, one of the longest of the longshots in a field of stars, confidently conquered the whipping winds that destroyed the tempo and tempers of his fellows, shot a 74 and retained a two-stroke lead Friday in the second round of the $3oo,ooo Tournament Players Cloit Cham­ pionship. 
“ .lust do the best you can,” shrugged McCullough, a 31-year-old former school teacher who hasn’t com e close to winning in five years of tour activity and, until his opening HH, hadn't even led a tour event.

AP WIREPHOTO

IW C o f f e r in g H a m le t 

“ Everything you ever wanted to know about 
Hamlet’ but were afraid to ask” could be the name of a new course to be offered at Incarnate 
Word College. 

The college's continu­ ing education program is taking the upcoming production of “ Hamlet” to use the resources of the drama and English faculties to delve into 

 what the play is all about, as literature- and produc­ tion 
The' four-part course on 
Hamlet, called Eternity or Entirety, begins on 
March 28 and continues 
Irish Fling Sunday

Proof that once the 
Irish start celebrating it takes a while for them to stop will be offered Sun­ day at the Institute of 
Texan Cultures. 
The institute is spon­ soring an Irish Fling at 3 p.m. as the final event in the St Patrick Day cele­ brations which began 
Thursday. 
Formal entertainment 

 begins on the stage under the dome at 4 p m with 
Sister Teresa Carter’s 
Traditional 
Irish 
Dancers, followed by 
Irish tenor .John Don­ ahue 
The family entertain­ ment is free and open to the public. There will be free institute parking for visitors coming to the party.

(he “ Hamlet’’ production in the college’s auditor­ ium. The course runs from 7:3o p.m. to 9:3o p.rn on throe nights and the play itself begins at 8 p.m.

Arthur Sierra, assistant professor of English, in leading the discussion sessions. 
Richard .Jones, who will star in the IWC pro­ duction, will also speak to the class 
All of the classes will hi* in the college auditor­ ium with the “ Hamlet” set as the backdrop.

'Tinder’ all too familiar 

B y R O N W H IT E 

 may sound 
San Anton- 
The story fam iliar to ians. 
The setting is San An­ tonio in 1876. Mayor Lola 
C rockw cll is on the bandwagon to close down the dance halls. 
The dance hall owner, 
Oscar DeLavaca, (also the only supplier of firewood for the city) re­ taliates by tripling the price of the wood. 
There’s a city council­ man, Uncle Sam, who wears a red, white and blue costume and spends his time buying snow- cones and planning Cen­ tennial parades. 
There’s a newspaper rn town. The Excuse and 
Snooze, which delights in bold headlines ( " B ig 
Bird Eats Kelly Field’’). 
M elodrama 
Theater 
It ’s all part of M elo­ drama Theater’s topical 
"T in d er Treachery," a spoof of our current poli- ticians and fuel crisis that sounds good on paper, but doesn't entir­ ely succeed on stage. 
Perhaps ifs because it would be hard for any stage show to match the real-life absurdities San 
Antonio has experienced with its politicos we might sometimes wish were fictional). 
Or perhaps ifs that the audience is oo keenly aware of what "T in d er 
Treachery’’ is satirizing that everyone is sitting 
(tut there making up their personal script as the show goes along. In any ease, audience members are anticipating and shouting the punchlines before the actors. 
It’s a play that’s fami­ liar before it’s seen, and 
Burdette Pa rk s’ script holds few surprises, few of those moments that make any play worthwhile when the au­ dience wishes. " I f only I had written that. .. . It’s a play that too obviously could have been written by anyone. 
This is not to say that 
-Tinder Treachery” — particularly buttressed by P a rk s ’ direction — doesn't have some good moments. 
Editor 
The scenes in the office bf newspaper editor Herb 
Sm art (M ike Stevens) are nearly worth the price of admission them­ selves Smart is a maniac who can only speak in four-word headlines 
("Bloody Man Buys Ta­ co” ). And the scenes contain one of the better songs in the show, a sa­ tire on journalism. 
The play is more lively, too, when Uncle Sam 
(Steve W are) or Mayor 
Crockwell (Havre Nolan) are on stage. W a re ’s councilman is a power ful. overgrown spoiled kid, sucking his thumb and whining to get his way with the Centennial celebration 
Nolan makes a fine visual im itation of the real Mayor Lila Cockrell. a sort of living Kewpie doll It’s a pity she isn't given more to do in the show. 
George Burnette crea- toa an enjoyable, if im i­ tative, character as Har­ old Baskin, the snow cone vender who comes to the 
Institute exhibits cultures 

Six travelling exhibi­ tions which range from the horse age to the space age are being shown through April 15 at the 
Institute of Texan Cul­ tures. 
The Moody Bicenten­ nial Humanities Exhibi­ tions have been put together by the Human­ ities Research Center of the University of Texas al Austin. 
The exhibition is free and open to the public. 

W a t e r c o l o r 

 c l a s s e r d u e 

A new series of water­ color classes, taught by 
Caroline Shelton, opens at the Southwest Craft 
Center March 29 

( lasses w ill include demonstrations arid cri­ tiques by the instructor. 
For enrollment and in­ formation telephone 

224-1848. 

Review 

 city’s rescue. 
They are nice perfor­ mances, all of them. But they have to deal with overly long exposition, and vast spaces arid of action or carefully con­ ceived comedy. 
This may be a case of a show that could never live up to its advance press. But one still feels that it could have come closer. 

San Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S— 
Saturday March I 9 I 977 

Poco Loco opens 

The Poco Loco Del Rio club held its grand open­ ing ceremonies this week complete with welcome visits from other neigh­ boring Riverwalk busi­ nesses. 

The guests were greet­ ed by club owner and band leader Frank Pena 
His club is located at 5o5 
N. Presa St., overlooking the Riverwalk. 

Paseo del Rio Associa­ tion President Franklin 
Hicks cut the ribbon for­ mally opening the new addition to the river bu­ siness community. 

Rio Ramblings 

Latin music for danc­ ing by the Poco Loco 
Mexican Brass will be featured at the restaur­ ant and night club. Live music begins at 8:3o p.m. 
Tuesday through Thurs­ day and at 9 p.m. on F ri­ day and Saturday. 

 evening.

Padgitt Dotson and Jim 
Smith will be exhibited at 

Mud Gallery beginning 
Saturday. 
The public is invited to the opening of the show which w ill be at the 
Greenhouse, 312 N. Presa 
St., from 8 p.m. to IO p.m. G uitarist Chuck 
Rich will entertain at the reception________________ 

The menu is built ar­ ound steaks, with both 
Mexican and 
Anglo versions offered. Lunch hours are from ll a m. to 
1.3o p.m., with complete dinners served every

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 19 ]977 

To hove your pntblem solved or a ques' don answered* arite Action-Express, VA). 
Hot 2171, San Antonio, TX 7H2*)7. 

Police praise 

I would like to congratulate a San Antonio police­ man and a couple of on-the-ball Citizen’s band radio operators. 
I had been one of those CB skeptics. I could never see any good they were doing and was always ready to find fault with traffic officers 
But, believe me, I was wrong on both counts. 
In early March, my wife was the victim of a hit-and-run driver on 11135 at Southcross Blvd. The accident not only demolished her car, but caused her to hit another lady. 
Luckily a witness was able to supply the police officer with the license plate number of tin* hit- and-run driver. 
The policeman put it on the police radio and a 
('Ber heard it Ile spotted the car, followed it and was able to identify the driver who fled tin* scene. 
I believe me. I think this is really great for our policemen and the ( liers to work together. 
I would like to thank this police officer for his hard work in helping my wife at the scene. 
Recently I read where Action-Express found a policeman who helped two students who were left behind on a school trip from Laredo. 
L. S. II 

THAMK5, 6UY; 

Action-Express would 

 also like to commend 
Patrolman Robert An­ derson, Badge number 
o3o7, for his action in helping your wife. 
Action-Express would 

 like like to stress the im­ portance of cooperation with the San Antonio Po­ lice Department in the case of hit-and-run acci­ dents or any other ca­ sualty, burglary, or dis­ turbance. 

Great decisions 
Max I contribute additional information to the topic of (Ireat Decisions ’77 program? 
The General Federation of Women’s Clubs will conduct a nationwide survey on four international topics in the Great Decisions series. 
The is s u e s iii the order of priority are: Panama and the United States, Foreign Policy: Congress versus the President, Nuclear Proliferation and 
Moral Values and Foreign Policy. 
These were chosen from a list of 12 topics last 
.lune by the (IFVVC board of directors. The list was suggested by the Foreign Policy Assn., a non-profit, nonpartisan educational group which specializes in information on world affairs. 
Each club iii the Texas Federation of Women’s 

( lu lls is urged to work with other groups in its community, such as P-TAs and other women’s organizations, schools, colleges, men’s service clubs and church groups to create a representative community audience to consider the international issues. 
State b> state, the results will be collected, evaluated arid released in a news conference beamed to the President of the United States. 
The U.S. State Department will hold a conference with leaders involved iii the survey to discuss the issues with them iii order to gain a true consensus of public attitudes. 
Studying the foreign policy issues and recording your Mews iii one specific way you can register your opinion with the U.S. State Department. This is a rare oppounity not to be missed. 

Mrs. ROLAND M. DIXON JR. 
INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS DEPARTMENT 
( llAIR MAN 

Action-Express would he glad to pass this in­ formation along. 
(ireat Decisions, now in its 23rd year, is a na­ tionwide foreign policy study-discussion pro­ gram. ( entering around small groups and a pre­ pared discussion booklet, the program is designed to acquaint the public with the nation's most pressing foreign policy problems. 

Discussion groups 

 meet once a week, for about one and a half hours, for eight weeks. 
Followine each discus- 

 tabulated nationally. 
Nearly 1oo.ooo citizens 

 particpate in Great De­ cisions each year. 
Anyone interested in 

(ireat Decisions should contact Robert T. Handy, the state coordinator for 
(ireat Decisions. 
Handy will send you 

 brochures, posters, 

 guides to program dete­ r m e n t and (ireat De­ cision booklets. 
Handy's address is 

Texas (ireat Decisions, 
KOOI Palm er Highway, 
Texas City, 7759o 

Jewelry com plaint 

I have shopped in San Antonio all my life have always respected each store’s policy. 
When I buy something on sale, and discover I don’t like it or the fit if it is clothing, I know I am stuck with the item because most stores have no refunds on sales items'' signs all over the place. 
However, this time I think I have a legitimate gri|M* 
A couple of months ago. I bought a pair of gold earrings, on sale, from a local jeweler. They were nice earrings and at a very reduced price so I could not turn them down. 
Tile store does have a "no refund on sales items"! sign on the cash register, but I did not think I would have any problems since this is a reputable firm. 
Needless to say, the earrings have not held up. 
I did wear them continuously, but I have other jewelry, which is solid gold, that I wear just as much aud nothing has ever happened to it. 
I even wore these earrings in the shower. Gold products should be able to withstand this. 
A few weeks ago, I noticed the earrings began to chip. Can you imagine my surprise when I disco­ vered they were not real gold, but only gold painted? 
I got to the jeweler's as soon as possible, and they would not take them back. I think I have bien taken, and by a “ reputable" firm too! 
Can you help me get my money back? Thank you for any help 
I* J. (. 

 and 

Both (br manager and 

 the salesman remem bered the occasion and said they explained to you that they could not take them back because they were not advertised or displayed as solid gold earrings. 
The sales rack, and all 

 earring cartons, clearly say. 
“ I I karat gold 

 post,*’ only. The entire earring is not gold. 
Many earrings for 

 pierced ears are made with gold posts, or wires, or are by po-ailergi/ed (or women who have sensi­ tive ears.

Too much exercise not good 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: I am 26 years old. I have been doing an exercise that involves lying on my back and lifting both legs about six inches from the floor, then holding them there for about three minutes at a time. 
I have begun to have back pains, also pain in my arms and a stiffness in my neck when I turn my head. I have had pelvic X-rays, complete blood tests, urine analysis, chest X-rays, cardiograms, and have been examined by my gynecologist several times. 
Can you comment? — Mrs. .LYV. 
With all that attention 
I'm amazed no one has suggested the obvious — quit those exercises if you haven t already done so. The exercise is rather strenuous, espe­ cially if you were relati­ vely inactive prior to starting out on your conditioning program. 
Lying down with the legs raised is not one of the purposes for which the human body was de­ signed. It may be fine for some, apparently not for you. 
The strain is chiefly on the thigh muscles and the long muscles of the back and neck. With some peo­ ple any slightly forward curvature of the lower spine may produce the pain you report. X-rays, if taken from the side, would show this. 
I suspect though that your problem is entirely muscular. If you must do such exercises find better ways to go about them. Build up to them gradually within your limits. Try soaking in a hot tub before retiring, and be sure your mattress is sufficiently firm for your weight. 

Spine 

If your pain doesn’t go away with these conserva­ tive steps, then you had better see an orthopedic doctor. Your spine may be slightly nut of line, ag­ gravated bv these exercises. 
Your letter is proof that one doesn't have to be 
"past 5o" to develop serious problems from unwise exercising. 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: Do you have any information you can send me on colitis? Is there some organiza­ tion I can write to? — H R. 
The National Foundation for Ileitis and Colitis. 
Inc., has some excellent material on the subject, and a particularly interesting pamphlet crossed my desk quite recently. The foundation is a non-profit, re­ search-oriented organization dedicated to finding causes and cures of these two intestinal disorders. I am not sure whether the material is available' gen­ erally, but you can write the national headquarters at 295 Madison Ave.. New York. N Y. HMH7. There may be a local chapter in your phone book. My own booklet on colitis can lie obtained by sending 25 cents and a stamped, self-addressed envelope to me care of this newspaper. 

Bed-wetting con be a frustrating problem bot it can be controlled 
To learn how, write to Dr. Thosteson in core of this new spaper, for a copy of his booklet, 
Bed-W etting: W a y s to Stop It." Enclose a long-self-addressed, stam ped envelope and 25 cents. 

Health 
By George C. 
Thosteson, M.D.

SUNDAY: This is the vernal equinox, as­ trological New Year’s 
Day. The Sun moves from Pisces into Aries at 
12:43 p.m. EST. For na­ tives of both signs this year's progress is stren­ uous but enjoyable You glimpse the future in moments of inspiration. 
Relationships involve many levels of cons­ ciousness. Today’s Pis- ceans are middlemen collectors, assemble items for public uses; the 
A hens seek priority in hazardous fields, are strongly partisan, gifted iii the arts.

Wife charged in shootings 

A 54-year-old woman was released from Bexar 
County Jail Friday after being charged in connec­ tion with the death of another woman and the wounding of the suspect’s husband. 
Charged with m urder and attempted m urder is 
Willie Mac Moore of 718 
Knotty Oak Trail. She was released after post­ ing bonds totaling $15.IMM) set by Night Magistrate 
Manuel Lopez. 
Police said the incident occurred about 3:3o a.rn. when the wom an r e ­ turned from work and 

 allegedly found her hus­ band in bed with another woman. 
The woman then alle­ gedly fired several shots from a .22 caliber pistol, police said. Her husband was wounded in the thigh and fo re arm and the other woman was struck in the head, officers re­ ported. 
The dead woman was identified as Frankie Ni­ chols. 32. of 148 Alabama 
St. The s u s p e c t’s hu s­ band, Floyd F. Moore. 
48. was listed in satifac- torv condition at Bexar 
County Hospital.

Commissioners Court agreed Friday to fight a suit for rein statem en t filed by a former Bexar 
County Courthouse jani­ tor. 
The ja n ito r, d is ­ charged by maintenance su p e rv is o r A. D. C al­ laghan last September, filed an appeal last month His pica for rein­ statem ent has already been rejected by the 
Bexar County Civil Ser­ vice Commission follow­ ing a December hearing on the case. 
Seferino M. Ozuna Jr. brought the action in district court but no date for a hearing has been set. 
The janitor's suit c la im s he was d is ­ charged without recourse to the existing grievance and appeals mechanism spelled out for all Bexar 
County employes. 
W ater hoarding 

SALT 
LAKE 
CITY 
(AB) — Worried about a possible drought and en­ couraged by the Mormon 
Church, many Utah resi­ dents are filling their basements and garages with stocks of bottled water. 
Like o th er W estern states. Utah has had little rain or snow this winter and is rep o rted d rie r than it has ever been since record-keeping be­ gan in 1892. 
S tores are se llin g 
55-gallon plastic drum s for as much as $3o. 

In other action. Com­ missioners Court tentati­ vely endorsed the idea of applying for $13o,9o3 in federal anti-crime funds to initiate a special “ m a­ jor offense b u r e a u ’’

Democrats 
“ It always seemed with a Dem ocratic Congress and a 
R epublican president, it (the lack of energy policy) was the o ther fellow ’s f a u lt,” 
G u th rie said, ‘‘but it c a n ’t be the o th er fel­ low s fault any more."

April 2o

Conservation 
Conservation measures may be part of C arter’s proposals, he said.

St. 
Mary’s, Guthrie said that in the area of fossil fuels, b e tte r fuel recovery methods will receive first attention. 
Carter seeks oil spill fund

COMPILED HOM Witt SltVIClS 
WASHINGTON 
- 
President Carter Friday proposed a $2oo million federal fund to clean up oil spills and compensate their victims. 
He also recommended tougher standards for oil ta n k ers th a t use U.S. ports in order to cut down on the spills themselves. 
The P re sid en t noted that the problem is glo­ bal and said he plans to co m m u n ic a te d irec tly with the lead ers of a number of m ajor m ari­ time nations to solicit their support for interna­ tional action.

S e p te m b e r 1974 when d o u ble-digit inflation gripped the economy.

Ex-councilm an is theft victim 

Police Friday were probing the theft of sterling silver sets valued ut $1o,oo4) taken from the home of former City Councilman Alfred Beckmann of 23o3 
Woodmen Drive. 
The three silver sets, containing more than BOO pieces, were in a drawer in the linen and china closet in the dining room. The entire drawer was taken along with its contents, police said 
Although the theft was not discovered until 
Thursday, the Beckmanns told officers they believed the sets were stolen Wednesday night when the couple left the residence between 7 p m. and 8:3o p m 
Police said entry was probably gained through a sliding door 
The sets were stolen about two years ago, but were later recovered, police said 
Beckmann served as a city councilman about two years ago. 

The government said o v erall, food p rice s soared 2 per cent last month with nearly all the in c rease due to the extremely cold weather, which d am ag ed crops and hindered transporta­ tion. 
Travel bans are lifted 
WASHINGTON - For the first time since 195o, 
Am ericans arc free to travel anywhere in the world w ithout r e s tr ic ­ tions on use of their passports 
J u s t a fte r m id n ig h t 
F rid a y , un executive order banning the use of an American passport for travel to f'ubu. North 
Korea. 
V ietnam and 
Cambodia expired. 
Within an hour after a 
Miami business offering travel to Cuba opened its doors, 188 persons had inquired about making the trip. 
Carter wants aid increase 
WASHINGTON 
- 
President jcarter has asked Congress for an in­ crease of more than $ billion over the Ford ad­ ministration’s foreign aid boost that would allow other nations to spend more of their own money on weapons. 
The C a rter request seeks $7.5 billion. 
A White House spokes­ man said the request for the approaching fiscal year reflected a shifting toward economic aid for food, the necessities of 

 life and a reduction of e x p e n d itu re s on w e a ­ pons. 
Autopsy net for 
Main union man 

LAS VEGAS. Nev. - 
An autopsy has been scheduled to determine the cause of death of Al 
Bramlet, the labor leader whose p artly d e c o m ­ posed body was found in the desert three weeks after he was reported missing. 
Authorities identified his bullet-riddled body through fingerprints. Po­ lice sources said an in­ formant told them he had witnessed the execution style death of Bramlet, 
8o, leader of Local 228 of the C ulinary w o rk e rs 
Union.

A lien jailings report made 

A total of 588 aliens were jailed in San An­ tonio during 1976 for var­ ious crim es other than illegal entry, a Bexar 
M etropolitan C rim inal 
Justice Council report shows 

Data on alien arrests 
Were provided by the U. 
S Immigration and Na­ tu raliza tio n 
Service through a letter from 
District Dir. Joe J. Sta­ ley. BMC JC Dir. Bill llolchak review ed the material for the council during a regular Friday meeting 
Generally, the material was Used to emphasize the impact of aliens on crime and economics in 

Bexar County. 
Of the 588 held in Bexar 
County Jail. only about 3o w ere legal aliens with appropriate permits for residence here, the r e ­ port indicates 
During that year, the jail pro cessed about 
36.5oo prisoners, includ­ ing those tagged as alien 
Staley s inform ation showed Bexar County has a resident population of about 4o,(HH) aliens He also estim ated at least that n u m b e r of illegal aliens live here 
Turning back (o the al­ iens jailed in 
1978,

Other offenses

Info rm atio n C enter in 
Austin is now collecting information on arrests of foreign-born persons by local, county and state 

Officials in Texas. 
Copies of criminal his­ tory rep o rts on the a r ­ rested persons are being m ade av ailab le to S ta­ ley’s office here, hts let­ ter noted

Windsor firm features model of Forrest Glen 

Value is what you get with a new Windsor home. 
For less than $3oo a month, you can own a new three-bedroom, two-bath home in Forrest Glen, the popular northwestern Bexar C ounty communi­ ty. 
7523 Piper's Way 

This value is based on purchase price of $31,475 with no down payment and VA financed at 8 per cent annually with 36o equal monthly payments of 
1297. 

This home at 7523 Piper's Way fea­ tures exquisite carpeting, central air and heat — and all in a decorator- coordinated interior. This is inst one of tile value-filled houses presented by 
Windsor Homes. 

Windsor homes surround you with quality, luxury and convenience. 
Quality is emphasized; buyers would prefer to pay a little extra than have to face replacements rn two or three years. That's why Windsor Homes uses only high-grade materials that will give maximal life to your home. Su­ perb craftsmanship and close attention to detail are more contributions to your home's durability. 
\ 
Many people buy their new home after having lived in a luxurv apart­ ment for several years. In that time, they have grown accustomed to lux­ uries like carpeting, fireplaces and central air and heat; so. W indsor homes include these features as well as some others that very, very few apart­ ments offer; sunken living areas, cathedral ceilings, indoor u tility rooms, m aster suites with sitting rooms and garden kite hens with sorv e-outs to backyard patios 

Speaking of kitchens, they include range, vent hood, dishwasher and dis­ poser for maximal convenience and efficiency. 

Windsor homes are built creatively for you. Their research has revealed the most preferred floor plans; to these plans are added innovations that have received popular acceptance. 
F]aeh Windsor home is built in way that you. too. can add your own crea­ te lty. 
You'll find Windsor homes in the 

 m o s t desirable areas of t o w n : The 
Great Northwest. Forrest Glen and 
Bristol Place. Model homes are open in each area until dark. 
To reach Bristol Place, take N E. Ill 
35 north to Rittiman Road and turn east. 
To get to The Great Northwest and 
Forrest Glen, exit NAV 
Loop 41o at 
( ulebra Road and turn north.

Business is booming in Ray Ellison areas 

Business is booming at Ray 
Ellison's s i n subdivisions sur­ rounding San Antonio, and the management team at Ray E l­ lison Homes believes tin* pheno­ menal sales figures during the first 21 months of 1977 will continue throughout the year. 
According to II b Maurer, director ut marketing for Ha\ Edison Homes. sales figures lur Jan u ary and F e ­ bruary arc running better than double the PITH rate for the same months, and actual sales are exceeding sales pro­ jections for 1977 by substantial mar­ gins. 

CLA SSIFIED D ISPLA Y 

“ We've always believed that we're dealing with a sophisticated buyer," 
Maurer said, "but this year really proves the point People are looking at the overall housing situation across the nation and looking at the inflation that’s affecting materials like lumber and bricks, and they’re deciding that. if they’re going to buy at all. they’d better do it this year, before the price of a new home really does go out of reach for the average homebuyer." 
Maurer pointed out that the situation in San Antonio is much more favorable regarding the prices of new homes than elsewhere iii the country but sounded a note of caution as he indi­ cated an av erage inflation rate of about a half of I per cent per month in this 

C lA S S irilD DISPLAY 
CLASSIFICO DISPLAY 

 a tea. 
"There's been an awful lot of static in the mass media about new homes being out of reach for tin* average homebuyer, but it’s apparent that people here aren't ready to believe that." Maurer said, "at least, not yet.” 
Maurer pointed out that a great deal of buyer confidence in the Ellison pro­ duct has been surfacing during the first months of 1977. 
"W e're certainly not bashful about the fact that we are volume builders. 
That’s the name of the game for us." 
Maurer said "but, volume building to us isn t a dirty word, and it isn't to the consumer, either, because he knows that Hay Ellison has really mastered the art of volume building. He's put 

CLASSIFIED

San Antonio areas where new home sales are roughly double 1976 rates. Buyer confidence in the Ellison product plus choice locations around 

 together a management team over the years that knows how to apply the very latest in construction techniques and methods. 
“ And, buyers know that we know how to take full advantage of volume purchasing strategies when it comes to buying materials and supplies. I’m very simply, they know we’re not going 

 the city are only part of the reason for the suc­ cessful year, and much of the credit must go to 
San Antonio's Realtor community, which prefers to bring their clients to Ray Ellison neighborhoods.

 to do it at the expense of quality. We’re building the best new homes in town in our price range, and it's a broader range than ever before. We’re proud of that." 

Maurer said one of the strongest drawing features of all new Ray E l­ lison homes built since January, 1976

"To make new home monthly pay­ ments fit the family budget," he said. 
"people are looking with great interest at our energy package because it does cut utility bills significantly with nor­ mal usage, and that makes a lot of sense to todav’s consumer."

REALTORS SELL OUR HOMES — AND LOTS OF THEM! 
That’s why realtors and Ray Ellison work hand in hand to sell Ray Ellison homes. This year, already proving to be a GREAT year for new home sales, all of us at Ray Ellison Homes are first to acknowledge that the professional real estate community is a key ingredient in the successful sale of new 
Ray Ellison homes. 

REALTORS WONT WORK WITH JUST ANY BUILDER. 
Realtor reputations are often linked to the kinds of builders and new homes they offer to prospective home buyers. They know that slipshod craftsmanship won’t satisfy their customers and will hurt the real estate market in the long run. Thus, their preference for Ellison. 

REALTORS HAVE SPECIALIZED KNOWLEDGE 
OF THE HOUSING MARKET. 
Many new home buyers who realize this fact consult real estate agents for the same reasons they consult their lawyers for legal advice and their physicians for medical aid — because the realtor is a professional with specialized experience, training and background. 

TWO OUT OF THREE NEW HOMES PURCHASED 
FROM RAY ELLISON DURING 1976 WERE 
PURCHASED THROUGH REAL ESTATE AGENTS! 
That’s certainly proof of the confidence that the realtor community has in Ray Ellison Homes. It’s also proof that realtors know Ray Ellison homes represent broad variety and diversified price ranges that answer clients’ individual needs and preferences.

OPPORTUNITY 

San Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S- 
■Saturday March I 9 I 977 
Homecraft Corp. has been acquired by a firm said to be the largest home builder in the United States. The U. S. Home Corp. now is the firm’s new name. Under the name of Homecraft Corp., much building and developing was done for the Bexar 
County area. The firm chose to do both in the growing — if not thriving — north­ 

 western and northeastern parts of the county. Its first community here was Twin 
Creek, where, with its new name, the firm still offers new homes for sale and presents fully furnished, professionally decorated models to visitors. The next community 
Homecraft opened was in the near north­ western part of Bexar County that boasts 

Homecraft Corp. becomes division of U. S. Home 

Homecraft 
Corp. has born acquired bv I S 
Home ( orp., said to lo* 
• v largest homo (milder 
•** : ■ I lilted 'italO'*, and 
' boltin to operate 
. or Un now name. I S 
Home Corp 

More than J 1* yearn

Great bedroom, 
Agnes and Harry Owens! 

D on't be surprised if someone tells you how great your Great America nome looks. Because at 
Great America, we believe you can see the difference quality makes. 
In our garden kitchens, w'tth handfinished cabinets and top quality appliances. In our roomy living areas, with vaulted cathedral ceilings, built-in bookcases and woodburu­ ing fireplaces. In our lavish ceramic tile baths, with marble vanities and decorator appointments. 
Even in our generous mas­ ter suites, with private baths and walk-in closets. 
Everywhere you look, there is careful attention to design, styling, practi­ cality and energy-effi- ciency. 
But that's only the in­ side story. Outside, Great 
America homes are strik­ ing! v individualistic. Each home is designed tor its particular homesite. Some are traditional, others reflect the informality of 
California styling. Some have soaring rooflines, 

 cedar trim and second- story balconies. Others are simple, yet elegant. 
But all are equally suited to entertaining and day- to-day family living. 
You'll find these really great homes in San 
Antonio's finest com­ munities. In Northwest 
San Antonio, we have new homes in Park Forest, 
Hidden Creek, Forest Oak 
Estates, and now, 
Elm Creek. In North 
San Antonio, we have new homes in Thousand 
Oaks, The Oaks in 
San Pedro Hills, and 
Hidden Forest. Each community is minutes from excellent schools, near major shopping and employment centers. 
Prices range from the upper-4o's to $1oo,ooo. 
Visit these fine com­ munities today and look for our new red, white and blue signs. For additional information on a particu­ lar community, call 
69o-o3oo. The really great homes in San Antonio are 
Great America homes. lust ask any of our home­ owners.

HOMECRAFT introduces 7 Vt per cent interest rates in six sites 
Homecraft offering 

An annual interest rate as low as IV2 per cent will be offered with VA financing for selected homes in all Homecraft Corp. residential areas this weekend. 
As well, VA financing which requires a total move-in cost of only $1 can apply to many home purchases in Homecraft communities ranging from northwestern Bexar County all the way up to Comal and Guadalupe Counties. 
Models showing 

Luxury features of Hom ecraft houses arc dis­ played in the models shown in each neighborhood. 
They include appointments like woodburning fire­ places com pletely handcrafted, boxed w.i.uows, wooden cabinetry, fine carpeting, color-coordinated wallcoverings and all-electric kitchens with dish­ washers. disposers and Magic Chef ranges with continous-clean ovens. 
Other fine features of Homecraft houses are pa­ tios. room-finished two-car garages with overhead doors, accent paneling and sculptured front doors 
These homes also boast features that exemplify the real meaning behind Homecraft’s recent housing concept, th** “ Snug Home.” 
“ Snug H om e” is a term H om ecraft chose to briefly describe the solid construction of its IOO per cent masonry homes. Although it sounds simple enough, there is much to it, especially when the need for modern families to save as much energy as possible is considered. The Snug Home accom ­ plishes that with ease. 
Energy-saving features in Homecraft houses ac­ tually result in “ tight” insulation — not just ample insulation. cu m u r e w r i t —
