Items included in the Snug Home concept are double paned, solar gray and light resistant win­ dows; foil-faced sheathing added to wall insulation to reflect both heat and light; and steel-encased doors with magnetic, refrigerator-type weatherstripping. 
To make a grand display of all these fine features, most Homecraft models are fully furnished and professionally decorated. Consider the wide variety of both homes and communities by Homecraft plus all the advantageous term s and affordable prices, and you've got a “ Parade of Homecraft.” 
Twin Creek 
Twin Creek is the first of the Homecraft com ­ munities for the San Antonio area. Situated between 
Bandera and Culebra Roads and off Grissom Road north of N.W. Loop 416. the northwestern Bexar 
County community has become the address of so many families that it now is considered one of the more established recent neighborhoods. 
Streets here necessitate slow traffic, and house exteriors along each create an impressive blending of both colors and styles. This shows how Homecraft plans its areas strictly on a professional basis. 
The com m unity also features its own private clubhouse and amenity area. It offers green-sur- faced, fenced tennis courts lighted at nights. Other facilities are a swimming pool, wading pool, club­ house with equipped kitchen and children’s play­ ground. 
Although surrounded by nature. Twin Creek also has a location of utm ost convenience. The thor­ oughfare Bandera Road is just a mile away; N.W. bion 41*1, one mile more. 
Outside city limits, Twin Creek residents pay no city taxes with their home payments. 
Located in the preferred Northside School Dis­ trict. Twin Creek is also close to UTSA, US A A, South 
Texas Medical Center. Southwest Research Institute and Kelly and Lackland AFBs. 
Greenridge North 
The second of the Homecraft areas for San An­ tonio. Greenridge North boasts an amenity area at the peak point of the hilly community situated off 
Toepperwein Road east of Nacogdoches Road north of N E. Loop 41o and west of Y E . Ill 35. 
Its amenity area features a junior olympic size swimming pool, wading pool and clubhouse with equipped kitchen 
Although Greenridge North is slightly outside the city limits, the community is near North East Dis­ trict schools, Randolph AFB. Windsor Park Mall, the Outer Loop, N E. Bl 35, UTSA, USAA and other major destination flints. 
Meadow Oaks 
The third Homecraft residential area for San An­ tonians, Meadow Oaks has caught the interest of many a home hunter looking for a fine house nestled among trees in a neighborhood near all the conven­ iences of the city. 
Situated just smith of N E. FM 1664 and east of 
N E. IU 35, Meadow Oaks fits that description to tin* fullest. Its serenity, combined with its convenience. has attracted many since it opened 
Homes here are situated on oversized lots and are designed for families of today who want the most in a new home. 
The community is convenient to Randolph AFB via N E. FM 1664. It also is near the shopping and entertainment facilities in Universal City, 
Complete city services, of course, are in Meadow- 
Oaks, despite its serene setting. It is outside San 
Antonio city limits, which calls for lower property taxes included in monthly home payments. It is in the Judson School District, with good proximity to an elementary school and a junior high school. 
Also, an amenity area called The Oaks Swim and 
Tennis Club is exclusively for the enjoym ent of 
Meadow Oaks residents. 
Woodstone 
This northeastern San Antonio neighborhood is one Homecraft m ore or less “ adopted’’ for the benefit of many San Antonians. 
Homecraft takes great pride in its ability to in­ troduce a series of new homes priced so low that a sharp contrast to prices of thor builders’ houses in 
VV<K>dstone is at once noticeable. 
H om ecraft’s houses include a series of all-tna- sonry homes priced from as low as $3o,95o. Some models this weekend are offered for even less than that because of a close-out sale. 
The com munity of Woodstone is exciting in a number of different ways. Homes are built on over­ sized lots with many trees. Ail lots front on paved streets with concrete curbs. Underground utility lines eliminate unsightly poles and lines that would m ar the natural beauty of the serenity and rolling terrain. 
Woodstone. near numerous destination points and within the highly rated North East School District, is reached most easily by exiting from N.E. Ill 35 to 
Judson Road, proceeding west toward Nacogdoches 
Road and follow ing signs. 
Oak Creek 
The fourth community professionally planned by 
Homecraft, Oak Creek stands out as a prime exam­ ple of its lengthy experience in developing com ­ munities for modern living and lasting values 
In choosing the serene setting for Oak Creek, 
Homecraft was sure to preserve Mother Nature s own creations in a way which allowed all city con­ veniences, R e s u ltin g ^ . Oak Creek boasts fully paved, c u rb e d s tre e ts , all city u tilitie s and sidewalks 
Because the building/developing firm plans to build luxury homes on the area’s 3oo acres of wooded elegance, special extras are offered among homes now showing in the neighborhood. Even custom building is welcomed here iMikak Creek is serenely situated between Culebra and Pig ranee Roads just inside NAV. FM 16o4. 
Northcliffe 
The most recent of the Homecraft areas, North- cliffe is stated as a collective name for three differ­ ent residential areas. 
The $156 million resident la I/golf course commun­ ity is located on 8o5 acres with substantial frontage along N.E. Ill 35. Construction is well under way on 
Phase I of its $2 million golf, tennis and swim d u b amenity program. 
Northcliffe has three model home parks, with 13 fully furnished, professionally decorated model homes: 
N orthcliffe Country Club E states has hom es priced from $66,366 to $93,566, and many have a view of the 18-hole championship golf course. Northcliff!* 
Fast has two- to four-lH*droom hollies priced from 
$27,566 to $31,756. Northcliffe has spacious three- and four-bedroom homes priced from $37,25o to $44,956. 
To reach Northcliffe, take Y E . Hi 35 north to the 
Cibolo-1 (abortus Road exit and follow the signs lo the community. Its fountain cntranccway is quite noti­ ceable.

Solar energy homes need not be architec­ tural monstrosities. This home, financed by 
G rea t Valley Savings of Reading, Pa., uses a solar furnace to provide from x/i to % of the home's heating needs. The system provides both heat collection and heat 

 storage functions in a small, lean-to struc­ ture at the rear of the house. Hot w ater also is provided by the solar system. The home sells for about $ 4 5 ,o o o .

‘Boom’ foreseen for housing 

Late inflation can hurt’ 

SPECIAL to THI GOLDEN T W IN S 
There's a housing boom ahead, but that and some other generally good economic news could disappear in a flurry of double-digit inflations figures by early next year, two leading economists said today. 

Currently sour economic news, ac­ cording to Kenneth .1 Thygerson and 
Dennis J. .lacobe, largely should be discontinued as "energy-related distortions" of a “basic economic well being.” 

Booming economy 

In fact, the two economists said. the overly stimulative monetary po­ licies of the last six months plus a 

CLASSIFIED DISPLAY 
----- 

“ sharp production upturn” following recent plant closings and layoffs “ will create booming economic conditions 
VE Inch will become apparent as early as the second quarter” of 1977. 

Thygerson is chief economist and lacobe an economist for the United 
States League of Savings Associations, the principal trade association serving the $39o billion savings and loan busi­ ness “ Economic Topics” is a League newsletter p eriod ically sent to managers of member savings and loan associations. 

The housing industry will share in the 1977 boom, Thygerson and .lacobe said They predictt*d that single-family housing starts this year would surpass tummc Pitney---------------to 

1972’s record 1.3 million units, with 
“ new strength” in the multi-family s«*ctor pushing total starts to as much as 1.9 million. 

A “ plentiful” supply of mortgage money at the nation's savings and loan associations will aid the housing boom, the League economists said 

But Thygerson and Jacobe also had words of caution 

Tin* "long-term substance” ot the country’s energy supply problems will be apparent again next Winter, the economists warned, with the timing of the next energy crisis dependent upon weather during the remainder of this said. 

 rc n n » i« D & iiK £ v ------------------ o jlsm fk d d w u o 

Winter, the amount of energy used this 
Summer for cooling purposes and weather conditions next Winter. 

“ The worst aspect of the energy crunch is its inflation potential.” Thy­ gerson and Jacobe said. 

“ Stimulative monetary policies, big federal budget deficits and an econo­ mic boom all create an increasing de­ mand for goods.” the economists noted. “ But. when the inevitable en­ ergy crunch restricts the supply of goods and services, then we have a rising probability of a return to dou­ ble-digit inflation.” 

That return to double-digit inflation could come as early as the first quarter of next year. Thygerson and Jacobe

Prime age group for biome buyers growing fastest 

684-7o47 

SPECIA L T O THE G O L D E N T W IN S 
The nation’s primary home buying age group 
— those between 3o and 44 — is now growing faster than any other, and, to meet the resulting hous­ ing demand, mortgage lenders will have to adopt innovative ways to make home ownership possible, tin* president of the 
United States League of Savings 
Associations declares. 
“ The war baby boom of th** 194os has turned into the home buyer boom of the 197os.” said U.S. League President 
John A Hardin tn remarks to th** an­ nual convention of the Institute of F i­ nancial Education at the Palmer I Pius** in Chicago 
3o million families 

“ In the post World War ll period. while the populous generation has been growing up, the savings and loan bu­ siness has supplied home purchase funds for nearly 3o million American families and helped make almost two thirds of Am erican fam ilies home owners.” said Hardin, president of th*1 
First Federal Savings and Loan Asso­ ciation oi Hock Hill, S ( 
' Today we have lo oiler that same 
I opportunity to the new home buyers. 
“ The dream of home ownership should not be destroyed by inflation. high housing costs and the steady eva­ poration of space to build new homes. 
"W e must find new ways to make home financing affordable for young families. And we must direct more of our nation's construction resources to preserving existing housing." 
Hardin said people in the age group from 3o to 44 are, historically, the pri­ mary home buying population group 
This age group is growing faster than any other. 
“ The generation that was born dur­ ing the 194os, swelled school rooms in the 195os and crowded college cam* puses iii the 19oos is now stretching 
Illume buying demand,” said Hardin. 
He said the phenomenon of extraor­ dinary growth in this age group helps explain why housing demand has not slackened despite an overall leveling off of i s population growth 
"F rom 1975 to 198o there will have been an increase of more than 6 (mi­ llion Americans between the ages of 3o and 44,” Ii** said “ This is almost as many as the increases of all oilier adult ag** groups combined iii the same per­ iod." 
Hardin said to help meet the de­ mand prospective home owners should be given greater flexibility in mortgage financing 

 ll** cited two experiments in mort­ gage lending now under way in ( all* tornui that open new opportunities tor 

►The flexible payment, by which a young fam ily would start m aking mortgage payments of less than th** full principal and interest due each month and. later, as their income in­ creases. so would their monthly pay­ ments. 

•The variable rate mortgage ties in­ terest charged to the cost of money iii th** financial marketplace To prevent fluctuation in the amount of the home owner’s monthly payment, one varia­ ble interest rate technique would shorten — or lengthe n — the term ot the loan with each rate change, leaving the payment level intact 

Hardin pointed out that the mort­ gage instrument most commonly used today — fixed payments and interest rates, over a long term — has not c hanged since before the new genera­ tion of home buyers was born 

“ We should develop a wider range ot choices for our consumers, lh** home buyers,” said Hardin. “ Working with officials at th** federal and state levels, we can do so The statutory authority exists for much more flexibility iii the types of mortgages that can be of­ fered." 

Hardin said the savings and loan business is also actively working to revitalize urban areas, so Ilia! more existing housing is available to young families. 

“ Our cities arc a primary housing recourse tor young people We applaud the new A dm inistration's national commitment to preserve* arid restore city neighborhoods We, in the savings and loan business, are doing our part and we ar*1 ready to do more,” Hardin said 

Pamphlet 

A 18-page pamphlet, HHC - 198, explaining home heating systems is available for 25 cents from th** Better 
Heating-Cooling Council, F. () 
Box 
282. Berkeley Heights, N J (17922 
Written as a guide for prospective home-buyers, it explains the advan­ tages «if hydronic (hot water) heal, how it operates, and how it ties in with solar heating and with air condition­ ing 
Comparisons also are provided with other types of heating systems, and a table shows conversion factors for equating oil vs gas vs electricity for heating 
Also available from the Council is a 
3o-page pamphlet, “ The New Heat 
Pump,*’ BUC • 194, for 75 cents, pus- tag** included in both l ases This one explains th** operation of air • to - air heat pumps for homes, and contains tables of comparative operating costs and energy consumption, as well as diagrams showing how they work

G REAT A M E R IC A m o d e ls e x e m p lify top custom qu ality 
Great America offers top quality 

Quality built elegance* and dynamic styling add up to the personality-plus 
G reat A m erica hom es, creating so much excite­ m ent am ong home buyers in San Antonio. 
Every turn of the cor­ ridor and every room of the home surprises the visitor with refreshing and exciting features. 
Panoramic 
Enter a Great America home to the b re a th ta k ­ ing, panoramic view of a spacious living area with brick-crafted fireplaces and s o a rin g ceilin g s which m ay extend beyond second-story liv­ ing areas or indoor bal­ conies. Generous panels of glass merge the envir­ onment and the home in­ to one airy, open living concept. 
N atural utilization of sp ace by the 
G re at 
America home designers e lim in a te s the four- walled, elosed-in feeling of conventional housing. 
Instead, a Great America home may center lift* ar­ ound an enormous family living area adjacent to the breakfast nook and kitchen and with easy access to outdoor patios. pools and garden lands­ caping. 
Formal living and din­ 

 ing areas — many with built-in buffets, cabinets and glass-doored upper cabinets for display — lie to the opposite side of the kitchen, creating a com­ plete walk-through serv­ ing area perfect for home entertaining. 
T his u n stru c tu re d feeling of extended living space is found among the b edroom s and m a ste r suite, all tucked away from traffic a re a s for privacy and many with sloped ceilin g s, glass- paneled walls and indoor or outdoor balconies overlooking great views or living are as below. 
Master suite plans to ex­ amine the alternatives to the d ark and crow ded baths com mon to most hom es with se p a ra te his-n-her dressing areas, vanities and walk in clo­ sets connected by a sun­ ken tub. O ther plans combine patio and sitting areas in the master suite.

Loop 41o, with hom es from $59,ooo to $75,ooo.

America homes are avai­ lable in the community from $56,ooo lo $72,ooo.

C l A lt m t D D IS M A Y 

SPECIAL TO THE G O LDEN TW INS 
WASHINGTON - While gen­ erally endorsing the ('arter Ad­ ministration's budget proposals for housing, the National Asso­ ciation of 
Hom e 
B u ild ers 
(NAHB) has urged Congress to extend a program that provides 
7l 2 per cent mortgage interest rates for moderate and middle- ineome home buyers. 

V andal G rav lee, vice p resid e n t- treasurer of NAHB and a home builder from Birmingham, Ala., has outlined 
NAHB’s position on a number of hous­ ing programs in testimony before the 
Senate Committee on Banking, Hous­ ing and Urban Affairs. The committee is holding hearings on housing author­ ization legislation for fiscal 1978 as well as supplem ental appropriation requests for fiscal 1977. which ends 
Sept. 3o 
Brooke-Cranston 

NAHB su p p o rts extension of the 
Brooke-Cranston program due to ex­ pire on Sept. 3o because it would pro­ tect tin* housing industry against the tight and expensive mortgage money conditions that precipitated the 1974-75 housing collapse, Gravlee said By re­ ducing interest rates to 7*2 per cent, the program also helps many first­ time buyers who have been priced out of the housing market because total housing costs, including interest rates, utility costs and property taxes as well 

 as construction and land costs, have gone up much faster than family in­ come in recent years 

The Emergency Credit Act of 1977, sponsored by Sen William Proxmire 
(I)., Wis ). chairman of the banking committee, would extend the Brooke- 
Cranston program. Gravlee noted 

But the Proxmire bill would increase also the interest rate ceiling from 71-2 per cent to the FUA rate (presently 8 per cent) and establish an income li­ mit based on 12o per cent of the median income of the area in which the pro­ perty is located. 

Gravlee urged Congress to keep the lower interest rate and the present mortgage and price ceilings instead of imposing the tighter income limits. 

Gravlee suggested also a few ad ­ ministrative and legislative changes that would stimulate construction of apartm ents for low income families under the government’s Section 8 ren­ tal assistance program. Since the pro­ gram was enacted 2G years ago, fewer than 4o,ooo Section 8 starts have been recorded. 

Gravlee urged Congress to place greater emphasis on new construction. 
“ Al a time when rental vacancy rates have dropped sharply, and there is an unquestioned need for new multi-family housing, it seems inap­ propriate to place such a heavy re ­ liance on existing housing,” he said. 

Section 8. unlike previous low in­ com e housing p ro g ra m s, provides 

 rental assistance payments to tenants rather than subsidizing mortgage in­ terest rates. Low and moderate income families pay from 15 to 25 per cent of 

 th e ir incom es for re n t, with HUD making up the difference between the tenant’s payment and the fair market rent for the unit. 

 a j u S i m e d i s m a y 
“ 

Construction up 

 in S.A. vicinity

McGraw-Hill Information Sys­ tem s Co. has reported on .Jan­ uary contracts for building in the standard metropolitan area of San Antonio, co n sistin g of 
B exar, Comal and Guadalupe 

Counties. 

An authority on the construction market, the firm produces Dodge Re­ ports and Sweet’s Catalogs. 
According to George A. Christi! vice president and chief economist of 
Dodge, the first month’s construction activitv followed this pattern:

$27,266 in 
1974 from 
$17.16<i in 1976. In the same period, median ho­ meowner incomes rose 32 lier eent to $12,866 from

Page *12-D San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Saturday March 19 1977 
GARDENING 
Practices peculiar to S. A . 

 tty TKR RY WILBOURN 
COUNTY f HUNTON HOSTtCUlTUmST 
Mavins lived here in San An­ tonin for several months now, I find many things very peculiar to this area of Texas that tin* home gardener must he* familiar with. Today’s column will he devoted to discussing some of these peculiarities. 
Those of you who have listened to my discussions on lawn care know my feelings about applying soil to the top of an established lawn I feel that the potential harmful effects certainly outweigh an> benefits you think you may be receiving. This appears to have become a common practice here iii San 
Antonio, and I cannot understand why. 
Under the grass 
Certainly, we have heavy, tight soils in the area, and the addition of a sandy loam to these soils is beneficial, but it should be applied under the grass, not on top of it. that is. modify the soils adequately prior to lawn establishment lr too thick a layer is applied, the grass will be smothered. Also, there is always the possibility of bringing iii nematodes, grubworms and weeds such as Johnson grass and nutgrass. 
These weeds are extremely difficult to control, particularly in St. Augustine grass. 
I have lived in various areas of the 
South and have never encountered this practice before. There's a lot of work in spreading the soil to not receive aav significant benefits. The only situation where I would recommend applying topsoil is when soil is extremely shal­ low, that is. it would be better to apply soil prior to putting out the grass. 
I was also told by a homeowner that he was applying topsoil to decay the thatch. Applying soil will not totally decay the thatch In fact, if you have a heavy layer of thatch, and. as you ap­ ply soil, you could be causing some­ what of a hardpan from the undecayed organic matter under the applied soil 
There are much better lawn care procedures to follow that require less work and still maintain a beautiful lawn. These include applying iron sul­ fate and a complete fertilizer in the 
Spring and adequately controlling in­ sects and diseases 
Another peculiarity I have found is 

TERRY W ILBOURN 

 that St Augustine is called or referred lo as earpetgrass. Carpetgrass may In1 a colloquial term for St. Augustine, hut it is not St Augustine, f'arpetgrass is an entirely different grass, grown prim arily in the deep South, prin­ cipally Florida It is grown from seed; 
St. Augustine cannot be grown from seed. It does not even resemble St. 
Augustine It could become a problem to homeowners because carpetgrass seed is available iii the trade Don't confuse it with St Augustine. 
Another problem common to Bexar 
County is the high pl I soil Generally, we find two types of soil here a heavy black clay and caliche. Both types of soil have a high pH, with caliche being a little higher. The term pl! refers to tin' degree of acidity or alkalinity of the soils. A pl! reading of seven in­ dicates neutral soil Soils here in tin' 
San Antonio area range from about 7.1 to eight. 
Sulfur is applied to soils to lower the pH It is a fallacy to think that one can lower the pl! of caliche soils There is lust too much parent calcium material to counteract This doesn’t mean that you can't grow plants, though Iron also should be added to the soil because iron becomes unavailable at high pH’s. Probably the best material to add is iron sulfate. The sulfur will help lower the pH, and the iron will keep the plant from becoming chloro­ tic or yellow. In heavy, deep clay soils with no caliche, it is possible to lower the pl! over a period of time. . 
Addition of gypsum, washed coarse sand and plenty of organic matter will help loosen even the heaviest of soils 
Pecan leaves and hulls, oak leaves and other acid, organic material will help the pl! problem, also. When selecting trees and shrubs, choose those that will tolerate the high pl! soil or be prepared to do a lot of soil modifica­ tion. If you choose azaleas, camellias and other acid-loving plants, you will need to totally replace the soil iii which they are to bo grown If your soils are caliche, I would not even try lo do this. 
Finally, I should mention that the walnut caterpillars are out and making their presence known These worms hatch out from eggs on the leaves, eat the foliage and move up and down in masses on the twigs and trunks. 
Spraying the worms with Sev iii or dia/inon will kill them. If they are feeding, you can spray the leaves with 
Bacillus thuringiensis.

Gardeners’ Q u e s t i o n s - Answers 

Bv TKR RY W ILBO URN 
CO U N T Y EXTFNSIO N HOBTICUI TURIST 
Being new to San Antonio, I would like to know if there are any flower shows in the area this Spring 

You're in luck. There is 

 the annual Spring Flower 
Show being conducted today and tomorrow, 
March 19 and 2o, at the 
San 
Antonio 
Garden 

(enter. 33IO N. New 

Braunfels Ave. The times are 2 to ti p.m. today; IO a rn. to 6 p.m. tomorrow. 
It is a beautiful event that Is open to the public. 
I believe admission is $1. 
Hope you enjoy it. 

I have a pecan tree I would like to transplant. Is it too late? 

All trees and shrubs 

 should be transplanted when they are dormant, for example in January or February. The plant 

 needs time to partially re-establish its root sys­ tem before it leafs out. I would wait until next year. 

How should I prune an extremely tall and leggy nandina plant? 

Prune back about a 

 third of the tallest stems to 12 to 18 inches from the ground. New growth will develop here. Next year, 

 and subsequent years, do the same thing. Pruning this way will keep it full and prevent it from hemming spindly. 

Questions on various aspects of lawn, garden or plant care, as well as landscaping, can be answered in this column. Please address any correspondence to the columnist himself and not to this newspaper. Correct mailing address is-. Down to Earth, c/o Terry Wil- bourn, County Extension Horticulturist, Texas Agricul­ tural Extension Service, 2o3 W . Nuevo St., Room 
31o, Son Antonio, TX 782o7. 
OLA ISI FUD DIS ALA Y 
ClAWlfB WWLAX ----- 

Savings associations have been the typical fa­ m ily's best source of home mortgage money even during the econo­ mically turbulent years of the early and mid-197os, the United 
States League of Savings 
Associations claims 
In fact, the League re­ ported. savjugs assoria- lions 
‘ provide more mortgage credit to more 
American families than any other type of finan­ cial intermediary." 
Booklet 
The I S League is the principal trade associa­ tion serving the $39o bil­ lion savings and loan bu­ siness 
The data are contained in a newly re­ vised booklet published by the League. It is enti­ tled ‘ W ho Helps Ameri­ can Families Buy Their 
Homes?” 
According to the book­ let. savings and loan as­ sociations had ‘ nearly 
$3oo billion" invested in residential mortgage loans at tin* beginning of 
1977 — 75 per cent of all sav ings and loan assets. 
No other lender is so committed to the home mortgage market, the 
CUiilMfi DUA LAY----- 

League said 
The commitment has been especially strong during the past two years, aording to Federal 
Reserve 
Board and 
League data. A chart in the "Who Helps” booklet indicates that savings and loan associations made approxim ately three of every four mort­ gage loans during 1975 and 197»i. 
The League publication also emphasized the 
‘ unique position" home financing institutions have in the Am erican economy. For instance, fam ilies purchasing homes normally buy new appliances, more furni­ ture, more of everything that goes into a house. 
Thus, the League said. th(> "positive effect" of each family's home pur­ chase ‘‘ripples through­ out the economy — from local shops and stores to the regional and national industries which make the goods families buy." 
Although the first sav­ ings association was created in Hit' IL S. in 
1831, the booklet empha­ sizes that Congress has encouraged land and home ownership as a na­ 

 tional policy tor nearly 
2o(1 years 

The list of supportive legislation includes a 
1785 law which permitted anyone to acquire o4o acres of unclaimed land for $1 an acre; the Ho­ mestead Act of 18o2, which did much to open the western states to settlem ent: and the 
Home Owners' Loan Act of 1933, which helped to modernize the created 

 savings and loan busi­ ness. 
Other important legis­ lation includes ho­ meowners' tax deduction of mortgage interest payments and legislation authorizing savings asso­ ciations to pay a slightly higher savings rati* than commercial banks to be certain home financing institutions can attract enough savings money to support the home mort­ gage market.

VALENTINO LIKES WHITE 
...also boleros, lace, narrow pants 
ROMANCE OF RUFFLES 
• •• and a calypso beat 

 l*HOTOS SY PAT MAMIITON 
Italian accent over evening at McNay 

By MILDRED WHITEAKER 
Women's Editor 
Some 
35o elegantly dressed men and women strolled the galleries and patio of McNay Art Institute for “ Festa Italiana” — de­ spite the fact that many of the invitations were never received. 
A h ard -w o rk in g telephone com m ittee was responsible for the turnout and the success of the gala, sponsored by the Friends of the McNay and Frost Bros. The 
Friends have friends indeed! 
Although held on St. Patrick's 
Day. the black tie benefit for the m useum was Italian almost all the way — except for a calypso touch of Brazil! 
Guests dined at a “ O n a Ita- liana” served buffet style and featuring new versions of recipes from ancient Italian families. 
Highlight of the evening was the presentation of the spring and sum m er fashions of Roman de­ signer Valentino, who calls this his “ Happy Collection/’ An apt description. 
The c lo th e s have a young, happy a ir — though th e y ’re designed for women “ from 18 to 
8o.” noted A ngela Istok. vice president and director of the Va­ lentino operations in the United 
States. 

Miss Istok was Frost’s special guest . along with Stanley Platos, 
V alentino's director of sales in the U. S. Both make their head­ quarters in New York. 
The spirited show was held in the Sylvan and Mary Lang Gal­ lery against a setting of palms and colorful tropical flowers ca r­ rying out Valentino’s Brazilian theme. 
M odels danced and p ran ced down the zig-zag runway to a ca­ lypso beat — in the same manner the show was presented in Valen­ tino’s 
Paris opening. 
Models-’ obviously were having a fine time and the audience was enthusias­ tic, a combination that’s hard to beat at a fashion show. 
Bolero 

F'or this writer, as well as other women in the audience, the event was tinged with nostalgia. One of 
Valentino's main themes is the revival of the bolero, that short, sassy jacket which was almost a 
“ uniform’’ in this country in the late 4os 
He uses the bolero in varied ways with skirts, with pants or sometimes with both. 
The second major “ shape" of the collection is the apron, which is really two skirts — one over the o th e r. The sh o rter one is the apron! He uses this twosome in daytime and evening lengths. 
O th e r fashion notes a re m s newly-narrowed pants ( “ Almost 

 a jeans cut," according to Miss) 
Istok); shirttails worn on the out­ side; dram atic touches of lace; j flowers in the hair, lots of white| 
— and a snappy little straw derby with the sporty ensembles. 
For evening, he m ay team white pants with an apron or hip-stitched skirt (accented with1 lace) and an off-shoulder blouse. 
Or by day. he m ay com bine' pants and shirt and bolero. The belted shirttail gives a new sil­ houette with the bolero. 
Daytime skirts often have an inverted pleat all the way up the back — great for walking but not so good for sitting. 
Among Valentino’s favorite co­ lor combinations are white with tobacco or white with tobacco and black. And he is using a beautiful, bright shade of blue. 
John Palmer Leeper, director of McNay, welcomed guests, and 
Richard 
Frontman, executive vice president of Frost’s, set the scene for the show. 
“ Get ready for the glory oi white, the romance of ruffles, the flowering of prints, the fun of aprons and the beat of the bo­ lero.” said Frontm an The Small 
World Combo provided a terrific calypso beat of its own. 
Don Strange was responsible for the Italian gourmet food. 
The audience was fashionabl> attired — with the women in short party dresses looking the newest and sharpest.

SHOW 

LESLIE FAV 

 today, 1:oo, in the mall court, north star mall, spring & summer dressing premieres with a runway show of leslie fay s latest collection, a fashion envoy will be on hand to assist you with selections, soon horn, the look of separates, all in one, green or blue with white, encron® polyester, 6 to 14 sizes, 48.oo. the collection will also be modeled informally in the spectator shop, 1o:oo to 4:o1). 

FROST BROS. 

Saturday M arch 19 1977 
Lift a stein to 
German food 

Fashions 

\ ' 
' * 
* for spring 

Americans respect the little businessman when he is a hard worker said Horst Kau. wip­ ing his hands on his gravy-soiled apron and joining us for coffee after Sunday lunch. 

My husband, my parents and I were having a leisurely meal in his Little 
Bavarian Restaurant at 21o2 S. Presa, 
“ just beyond the railroad tracks.” 
Ran and his wife Erns have been in the United States 23 years and ob- viously have worked hard to establish their business. 
They do ev ery th in g around the restaurant—from cooking to serving to occasionally entertaining (he plays the guitar she sings). 
Ran even decorated Little Bavarian to look like the ‘old-fashioned" places in his homeland 
The cook is an a rtis t," he says. 
When you have good taste for food, you have good taste all a ro u n d ” 
Rau describes himself as a “ profes­ sional cook from Germany.” 
But he gives credit for his success to his family as well as to the restaura­ teurs and hoteliers under whom he trained. 
“ The influence from my parents is very strong," he explains. "It goes with you all your life. You remember the ‘tastt's.' 
INcw York 
Kau has brought some of those tastes of Germany to San Antonio via Canada, 
New York (where he cooked at Lu­ d lo w ’*), New J e rs e y and M iami 
Beach. 
(His experiences before that include cooking on a ship before the war and serving three years with the German 
Army in Russia.) 
The Rail s first restaurant in San 
Antonio was a German delicatessen at the corner of East Houston and Travis. 
Now in their fifth year at Little Ba­ varian. they're dishing out German specialties such as Sauerbraten and 
Beef Roulade (my two favorites), an occasional Veal S c a llo p in g (good cooks learn to prepare all cuisines. 
Rau says) and Veal Cordon Bleu (call ahead to order this). 
Rail s philosophy is to offer good food at rea so n ab le p rice s 
—so customers will come back for more 
And to help keep down costs by not hiring too many employes. 
We thought the service could have been more prompt, though our wai- 

 j Where lo go 
What lo eat 

B> Jane llbrich 

 tress Erm gard (she was the only one on duty) with her heavy German ac­ cent and perky answer to everything, certainly added to the atmosphere. 

And Rail s periodic tours through the dining rooms were a friendly gesture. 

All entrees are priced below $3 and are serv ed with a salad and som e combination of dumpling, vegetable and gravy. 

Hot spice 

The salad dressing as well as Mrs. 
Rail’s famous cucumber pickles are flavored with a slightly-hot (mustard seed, mavbe?) spice. 

We ordered the Sauerbraten, Beef 
Roulade Yager-Schnit/el (veal cutlet. with mushrooms) and Cassler-Ripp- chen (smoked pork loin). 

Of the four, the first two were the most flavorful, although each plate was a generous, hearty meal. 

Beverage prices seemed high by comparison. Imported (G erm an, of course!) beer is $11o per bottle and domestic beers range are HO and 73 

C ( ‘l l t S . 

Wines (German Rhine or rose) are KO cents a glass. 

All desserts are 7o cents. Only the apple streudel (ours were cooked in dumpling style) is homemade. 

Weekday lunches range from $1.5o to 
$2.5o and include a variety of typical 
German (and some American) sand­ wiches. 

Little Bavarian is open from ll a.in. to 3 p.m. and from 5 to 9 p.m. Tuesday through Friday, from 5 to midnight 
Saturday and from I to 7 p.m. Sunday. 

(Try to time your visit so you don't get caught by a four-diesel engine pulling a mile-long string of Southern 
Pacific freight cars like we did!) 

I lift my stein to tins little bit of 
Germany just south of San Antonio’s business district. 

Party closes opening night of dinner play 

By EVE LYNN 
SAWYER 

The First Nighter 
Party follow ing the op en in g of the 
Church 
T h e a te r ’s play “ Two for the 
S e e s a w ” capped a highly en tertain in g evening. 
Guests met the show’s stars. 
Tom Parker and 
Terri Pena R oss and complimented them for their fast-paced perfor­ mance. 
Parker is the artistic d irec to r of the theater staff. 
Terri told us she started acting in college at UT and m arrie d the director of her first col­ lege show, Allen Ross. 
With her rehearsals for 
" S e e s a w " , w hich con­ tinues through April 1H, and his re h e a rs a ls for 
“ Hamlet” opening at 
Incarnate Word College next week, “ we haven’t seen much of each other lately." 
Although this is Ter­ ri’s first play for the 
Church Theater, she has performed at the Hacien­ da Theater. 

Who, 

 painted all of the homes on King William Street and has just had them published in an unusual pair of books en titled 
“Caroline Shelton Paints 
King William Street.” 
The King William As­ sociation has published 
1,ooo copies of the pair of books. Two panels 1H feet long with all the homes adjoining on the north 
^ side of the s tre e t are printed in one book, and chiffon, h an d k e rch ie f those on the Southside print dress in mauve and are *n the other.

William home she had m oved into only six weeks earlier. The old

Cold cream is handy cleaner 

The 
Biggest 
PUNCH 
Gets the 
Best Results 

Dear Ann Landers: 
Recently you published a letter from a wife who was ashamed of her hus­ band’s hands. He was a mechanic and his hands looked dirty, especially under the fingernails. 
Years ago I was intro­ duced to a m an w ho had the best-looking nails and hands I had ever seen. I was surprised when my friends told me he was an automobile mechanic. 
His treatm ent consist­ ed of keeping a mr of cold cream (the cheapest he could buy) in his locker. 
Every m orning before he started to work, he would stick his fingers and thumb into this jar and rub the excess cream a1! over his hands and wrists. 
When he finished he wiped off the grease with paper towels, washed his hands and was ready for an evening of bridge or whatever. 
Another m e ch a n ic, who also used cold cream, kept a heavy bath towel handy. He pushed the cuticle buck on each finger and his nails looked great. — Another 
Fan 
Dear Fan: Thanks for the tip. A nother w riter said lard w orks just as well as cold cream — and it s cheaper. The things you folks te a c h each other! Isn’t it beautiful? 
Here's a n o th er su g g es­ tion: 

Ann 

Landers 

 will wash the grease and grime away. — Bayou 

Dear Bayou: Thanks to you and m y friend He- loisc. Here’s another tip: 

Dear Ann: 
Before the days of d e terg en ts, en­ gineers and m echanics cleaned their hands the natural way. If you care to pass it on, feel free! 

Use about V* pint of or­ dinary m o to r oil and wash the hands in it until the g r e a s e disso lv es. 
Then wipe clean with a piece of cloth Finish with warm w a te r and m ild soap. It w o rk s like a charm. — F.M.C. 
, press, Box 2171, San An- 
Dear K M T .: Sounds tonio, Tex. 78297. sensible. — Thanks for writing.

They want the best for me. but when I get angry, 
I don’t s e e m to re ­ member that 
At night when I lay in bcd, I th a n k the good 
Lord for giving me such wonderful parents. The letter from “ Thanks for the M e m o rie s " really made me think. 
My parents read your column every day. I hope you will print my letter. 
They will know I wrote it. 

Dear Friend: I am not printing your signature or city. A g reat many parents who have 
13-year-old daughters, would like to think this letter w as w ritte n by their c h ild . L e t’s let them.

Dear 
Ann: 
Tell the mechanic’s wife to keep a large s h a k e r of su g a r handy — near the sink. 
When he washes his hands, no m a tte r what kind of soap he uses, if he shakes a little sugar into the palms of his hands, he 

Dear Ann: I want to say 
“thank you” to “Thanks for the M em ories,” the girl who wrote and said her father died when he w as 42. 
She was ashamed of the tim es sh e had talk ed back to him and was sick at heart that her father would n e v e r walk her down the wedding aisle or see her first-born child. 
She wrote, "I wish I had seen such a letter when I was 13.” 
Well, I’m 13 and I ha\e never been so touched by a letter in all the years 
I've been reading your column. 
Both my parents art* living, thank God, but I, 

Antique 

Series 

Bart VU, the last in the series on Collect­ ing the New Antiques, will be published in the Monday Express. 

Director 

W illiam A. Larsen, managing director of the theater, was inviting all the guests to taste the liver pate. He was the one who made the delicacy, and he told us he does g o u rm et cooking as a hobby. 
Larsen volunteers his time at this theater, and is also in charge of the Ft. 
Sam Houston Playhouse and the Harlequin Dinner 
Theater. 
In addition. Larsen is a former Minister of Mu­ sic for the First Baptist 
Church in Battle Creek, 
Mich. The idea of having a theater in a church was a n atural for him with his background. 
He told of looking for a suitable building in the 
King William area that could be used for plays. 
One Sunday morning he and his wife. 
Marcia. were driving past the old 
Methodist Church dated 
191o. and noticed that no people were coming out of it. 

Purchase

KENS offers food production film 

A special film showing the efforts of American youth lo become efficient producers of food will Ik* shown at ll) 3o p rn Sunday over KENS-TV. 
The film was produced by the station and will have 
Bob Rogers as narrator. Pat Wolford, a junior at 
John Marshal! High School, is the* student in the flint. Research was done by Nancy Clayton 
Tile film shows scenes from the Bexar County 
Junior Livestock show. John Marshall show and the 
San Antonio Livestock Show and Rodeo

T H E B I B L E 

No. 283. Jonah Returned to Dry Land 

After Jonah had been cast overboard into the raging sea, he was swallowed up by a great fish which the Lord had arranged for him 
And Jonah was inside the fish three days and three nights. Then 
Jonah prayed to the Lord 
‘ W hen my soul fainted within me I remembered the Lord: and my prayer cam e in unto thee, into thine holy temple. They that observe lying vanities forsake their own mercy But I will sacrifice unto thee with the voice of thanksgiving, I will pay that that I have vowed. 
Salvation is of the Lord " (Jonah 2:7 9) 
"And the Lord spake unto the fish, and it vomited out Jonah upon the dry land.” (Jonah 2 1o)

Rally to present 
'Living Proof9 

NEW B R A U N FE LS - 
Tho Texas Lutheran Col­ lege concert choir will present a program of music ut the 1o:3o a.m. 
Sunday worship service at St. Pau l Lutheran 
Church here. 
The 55-voice choir is the first touring college choir in the Southwest and is under the direction of Dr. Sigurd Christian­ sen. 
Selections for the pro­ gram include contem­ porary composers Ri- chard 
Felciano and 
.Charles Ives. Spirituals. folk songs and some classical works will also he featured. 
On March 3o. the TU choir will begin its 4Kth touring season with con­ certs scheduled in Okla­ homa. M issouri. Ohio and Pennsylvania. 
Lenten mission is slated 

The 
Rev 
George 
Butchee and his wife. 
Connie, will present a 
Lenten New Life Empha­ sis Mission beginning on 
Sunday and running through 
Tuesday at 
Bethany United Metho­ dist Church 
A 12-hour prayer vigil will begin the mission from 6:3o a.m. to 6:3o p.m. Sunday. Also. a 
“ fill-a-pew” plan has been instigated bv the membership to help sup­ port the Lenten empha­ sis. 
Tile Rev 
Mr. Butchee and Ins wife will be the presenters of the themes. 
“ Roots.” “ L ife .” and 
“ Love" through drama­ tic presentations aud congregational participa­ tion. 
A nursery will be pro­ vided and a free-will of­ fering will be collected to help defray expenses. 

Standing behind the church vibraphone are co-pastors of Southside 
Evangel Temple, left to right, the Rev. Don West and his wife and 
Mrs. Marvin Carter and the Rev. Marvin Carter. The vibraphone is the featured musical instrument during Sunday morning worship services at I o:3o and at 7:3o p.m. services. Both pastors and their wives extend a cordial invitation to the public to worship with their congregation on Sundays and at 7:3o p.m. Thursdays. The church is at 25oo S. Presa St. 
Media will 

A five-screen m u lti­ media production enti­ tled “ Living Proof” will be presented during a 
Living Proof rally begin­ ning at 7 p.m. Wednes­ day at La Villita Assem­ bly Hall 
The rallv. sponsored bv 
F irst Baptist Church. will feature Dr. Bill Self, pastor of the Wieuca 
Road Baptist Church in 
Atlanta, Ga. 
Dr. 
Self serves as president of the I million member Georgia Baptist 
Convention 
The multi-media pro­ duction will feature ways in which persons within the church are becoming living proof of Christ s power in their lives through the ministry of the congregation. 
The rally will have an old-fashioned supper. 
Prior to the rally. the church will be host to 
Alton Newell, chairman of the board 
Industries. 

CHURCH NEWS 

 speak at 7 p.m. the church. 5! lough Ave. 

Sunday at 
5 MeCal­ 

 ef Newell who will carry 
Christian m essage 

M arsh all 
M cLuhan, one of the creative thinkers of our society, has a book. “ TIK1 Me­ dium and the Message.” 
He analyzes the changed patterns of thinking that he predicts are happening out of the whole saturation of com­ munication media iii our lives. 
Whether he is accurate or not, evangelical 
Christians have decided that the media should carry their message. 
The com munication media is now being utilized by the Christian community in more in­ tense ways than ever in history. 

Bv 
Rev. I 
Jiminy R. Allen 
Pastor. 
First Baptist Church 

Hard on the heels of the com m unication effort with the theme of “ I found it” has come the effort by Texas Baptists to share their message with a “ Living Proof” campaign.

Fair and mild to prevail Saturday 

ASSOCIATE FSI SS 
High cloudiness — part of spring’s early warning system — poured across North Texas Friday behind a cold front which left most of South Texas sunny and mild 
Gardeners and spring watchers worked under somewhat cooler temperatures which prevailed north of the front, ranging from the 4U’s in the 
Panhandle and far West Texas, to 5o’s and 6o s across the remainder of the state. Afternoon ex­ tremes ranged from 62 at Amarillo to K3 at Orange. 
Northerly winds of IO to 15 miles an hour prev ailed north of the front. 
Forecasters culled for fair and mild conditions 
Saturday with morning lows iii the 3o’s in the west, 
-Ill’s central, and 5U’s in South Texas

.13 

The campaign consists of the testimonies of var­ illus outstanding and well known figures who have come to a personal ex­ perience with God in .!e- siis Christ and present their vv itness as liv itig proof that Christ can meet the needs of other lives. 
A m illion dollars lias been invested in sharing that message across the state. The money has come from the free gilts of concerned Baptists 
Local congregations are tin1 center of the ac­ tivities that follow up the m edia with efforts to share the gospel iii wor­ ship celebrations and in interpersonal communi­ cations. 
Late 
As is predictable, 
C hristians and church­ men are late to the scene of media efforts. 
It is true that out­ standing personalities like Fulton Sheen and 
B illy 
G raham have shared the religious message through the media. 
However, the moving 
•if the philosophy of me­ dia communication away from one man speaking before an audience to various kinds of ap­ proaches has been a pat­ tern. 
Churchm en arc awakening to the need of investing their energy iii such efforts. 
Criticism 
The effort has come in for criticism. 
Some have felt that any such effort would be too narrowly sectarian and have objected to it. 
Others have felt that the religious experience is p riva te rather than simply being personal. 
They are offended by the idea of articulating the faith in such personal and intimate terms. 
Some have felt that the effort will be a misuse of money since ifs such a highly expensive field and the results are.very difficult to measure. 
Welcome 
Over against these ob­ jections, there has been a welcome freedom of ex­ pression about the spiri­ tual experience iii recent 
.veals. 
Tins is true because leading figures in the field of politics, educa­ tion, business, and sports have been less reticent about sharing their faith. 
T h ere s been an ab­ 

 sence of narrow dogma­ tic sectarianism also in these efforts. 
The Rev. Ken Coffee of the San Antonio Baptist 
Association was quoted in the Roman Catholic paper of this diocese as saving. “ W e’re not ne­ cessarily trying to make 
Baptists out of them. We hope to create a God* counsciousness. so that they might look back to their religious heritage and maybe turn buck to the church ." 
The reporter fa light the spirit til the effort by saying. “ In tins way the cam paign might help 
Baptist membership, hut it might also help the 
Catholic church in Texas or the Lutherans or many other denominations." 
Awareness 
There’s a deep sense of awareness that if God chooses to move in a spiritual refreshing that 
He leafs across various kinds of doctrinal and denom inational d iffer­ ences to renew and change peoples’ lives 
It will take time to tell whether such media ef­ forts w ill bt* useful en­ ough to be repeated in various sections of the country. 
There is. however, a compulsion iii the seri­ ous Christian's life to re­ spond to the command to 
“ Go into all the world and preach the gospel to every creature.” Mark 
16:15 
There is no doubt that mass media is the essen­ tial ingredient for such com m unication in our day.

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sot March 19 I 977 
Man says son was freed for $14,ooo 

B R O W N S V IL L E (A P ) - 
A 
Ken­ tucky man claimed 
Frid ay 
Mex­ ican police extorted $14.OOO from him in exchange for release of his son. a r­ rested on marijuana charges in neigh­ boring Matamoras, Mexico 
I S Consul Francis Aren/ said the incident, which began Tuesday night, ended Wednesday night when the son was released to his father who paid the ransom. "It started as an arrest and ended up as an extortion," Aren/ said 
Student in Texas 

The father. Perry Greer, 47. of Lex ington, Ky., said ins son. P e rry Lee 
Greer .lr.. 19, a student at Southwest 
Texas State University at San Marcos, was freed at tin* 
International 
Bridge at midnight Wednesday. The father said he paid $14.OOO of the 
$2o,ooo the extortionists o rig in a lly demanded 
Greer, who said he is part owner of the Patterson and Greer Coal Co in 

Lexington, told Aren/ he received a frantic phone call from his son at 4 a iii. Wednesday who told him that he had been arrested in M atam oras for possession of m arijuana and police wanted $2o,IKM) for his release. 

Aren/ said he has asked Mexican officials for an investigation and also notified the U.S. Em bassy in Mexico 
City. 

Investigation 

The investigation was believed to be iii the hands of federal police because city police had handled the arrest. 

" I don't know why they picked me. I dont know if they checked license numbers or what. I am not a real rich man. but I am in the fortunate or un­ fortunate situation of having some money,” said the father

Motoring 
World 

Saturday March I 9 I 977 
Future for car bright colors 

D ETRO IT — Look for a r e s u r ­ gence of two-tone paint effects in to m o rro w ’s cars, not g arish and splashy, but subtle and tasteful. 
With tho resizing of Chevrolet's standard family-sized ears, Chevrolet's t hief interior designer sees a bright fu­ ture for increasing use of softer and more conservative tone-on-tone exterior paint combinations as well as exciting innova­ tions in fabric use in interior car design. 
“ Tone-on-tone exterior painting and color graphics, along with new compu­ terized fabric manufacture are the wave of the future in interior and exterior au­ tomobile design," according to George 
Moon, executive-in-charge. automotive interior design. General Motors Design 
Staff. "The resizing of automobiles in the industry will tend to make cars look si­ milar. 
Area of color 
“ One individualizing technique left will be in the area of color and color packag­ ing. 
"The subtle and pleasing tone-on-tone paint finish of the 1977 Chevrolet Caprice and Impala are a case in point," Moon said. “ The unique architecture of the au­ tomobiles — the dignified profile and simple lines — have come together to bring a strong return to the tone-on-tone, two-tone body paint application." 
Tone-on-tone painting is where the top half o f the car is painted in one shade, while the bottom half is painted in a 

 contrasting shade of the same color. 
Differing from the strong contrast of two-tone applications in the mid-5lis, 
Moon pointed out that today’s approach contributes to the overall styling of the ear by not calling attention to the paint technique itself. 
Reaction favorable 
"When we first showed the 1977 Caprice to a group of Chevrolet executives many months ago. the general reaction was very favorable. It wasn’t until several minutes later that someone noticed the two-tone paint treatment. That was an indication to us — the delayed reaction — that we had succeeded in achieving our design goal. In other words, the toning was subordinate to the overall styling of the ear." Moon said 
Does this portend change iii the role of color in automotive styling? 
"The role of color in automotive styling is still two-fold,” he said. “ You have the cyclical color changes year to year, and you still have innovative color changes which are much more dramatic These tend to show u p iii new color preferences in the small sporty ears. van. pickup and recreational vehicle areas. 
Popular color 
"Fo r example, the most popular color among Chevrolet owners iii 197H was light blue, followed closely by white and silver 
Ten years ago. a majority of Chevrolet owners also preferred light blue. Going

Rod East, left, heads the San Antonio Automobile Dealers Assn, for 
1977-78. W ith East are Homar W alker, treasurer, and directors Charlie 
Huffington and Mike Patton. Not shown are Ernesto Ancira Jr., vice president, and directors Dick Kane and Bill Langley.

Lotus Elite is unique car 
REPORT 

Fuel cost governs choice o f autom obile 
Do you believe the price of gaso­ line is going up? 
Mitre and more people that I talk to lately express a strong belief that prices w ill cont mile to rise 
We live in an inflationary economy; everything, it seems, increases in price. so why should gasoline he an exception? 
It s not It will go up The question is how much and how fast? 
Now it seems the Alaska oil we have been looking forward to for so long is going to come on shore in the I S at something more than $17 a barrel 
West Coast use 
Oil at that price will increase the price of gasoline where that oil i> used. Most of the Alaska oil will be used on the West 
Coast ll the price of gasoline reaches Ko cents a gallon, then m ile s per gallon will b e ­ come the major consideration for most new ear buyers. Until then traditional factors will prevail. 
The Ko-cent figure is the benchmark 
'cited bv Ford Motor Co Vice President 
Ben Bi dwell as the point at which the 
American consumer will turn from tradi­ tional size ears to compact vehicles 
Here iii T e x a s we are a long way from 
Ko-cent gas. but still a lot of people are concerned about the cost id operating their ears — not sn much right now fait two or three years from now when they will still be driving the same ear 
Hedge bet 
New ear buyers today — some of them at least — want to hedge their l>et 
Nu. I don't know where you eau buy a full-size, or mid-size, sedan thai will seat six adults, carry enough luggage for a two-week vacation, come with air-cmidi- tioning. power steering, power brakes. 

See At TO TALK. Page K 

By JIM ABBOTT 
M ITO EOI TO* 
Unless you are a race car enthu­ siast, the nam e Lotus may not be fam iliar, but if you know about fast cars, Lotus is a household word. 
Now the Deoole who build the Lotus in 
England have gone one gian' step beyond the race course to bring us one of the most unique grand touring ears on any road 
The Lotus Elite, Model 5o3. is first of all an eye-catching beauty The distinctive wedge shape not only adds to the appear­ ance of the ear. but the design ensures maximum aerodynamic efficiency and stability. 
The Lotus is not one of those cobbled together kit ears that the British are quite fond of. 
No indeed. It is a carefully engineered motor car that is remarkable in every detail 
Leading stylist 
The interior was done by Guigiaro. 
Europe's leading stylist, and he should receive an A-plus for the achievement. 
The front seats — I can’t really call them buckets, they are far more than that 
— are as comfortable as they appear to be. The head restraints are not only fac­ tional hut attractive. Lateral support is excellent, and 
I might add much appreciated during rapid cornering. 
There is ample back and forth travel for both passenger and driver. The reclining hacks can be set to suit the mood 
The driver will find that every consi­ deration has been given to make sure he has complete control, and knows what is going on at all times. The instrument pane! is well thought out with vital infor­ mation easy to see, secondary information available, but not distracting. 
Back seat for people 
What we have not mentioned until now is the back seat. Yes. ifs there; and the pleasant surprise, ifs for people 
Not dogs. eats, luggage, babies or groceries, lint for real grown people. 
Now let that soak in for inst a moment. 
How many real grand touring ears can you name that can seat four people? Un- huh, that s a toughie isn't it 
The lift-up rear winflow gives access to a luggage area that will accomodate en­ ough baggage for four people for a week-end. if you pack carefully . There is a maximum of ll cubic feet of space 
The 3o3 comes with a five-speed manual gearbox. 5th gear being overdrive, with an excellent ea^v to find shift pattern 
Factory air. AM/FM stem) with tape deck. flower steering; in fact, you would be hard pressed to add any extras to the ear. 
Robert Smith, of Robert Smith Motor 
Co., 7114 San Pedro, distributes Lotus cars for a seven-state area He told us the 

- -Tv mr* -»-• - 

IN­ 

D IS T IN C T IV E w e d g e sh a p e a d d s to e y e -c a tch in g b e a u ty o f 
Lotus Elite 

CIA SU H jO-Ol SPLAY 
CtA SSW RO -O lW A Y 
OAVSmlO S IW Y 

Elite appeals to a very special group ot people. 
"The person who buys an Elite has a need to seat more than two people. For instance, a young doctor with a family who wants to share his appreciation of a fine car would buy the Flite It will seat four people very comfortably,” Smith said "This automobile has more leg room in the rear than a new Thunderbird, or a 
Mark V 
“ Women now-a-days are in a stronger position in the market-place, and we're happy about that Iii the past the woman might have run down and bought a little sports ear, now she can. b ecau se women are earning as much as men, move into the Lo tu s market." 

Appeals to success 

Tin* Lotus Elite is the type of motor ear that appeals to the successful professional 
■person, man or woman, who wants to in­ vest in a prestige car 
The market for expensive ears is open­ ing up because of the increase in price of all automobiles. 
The person who is looking for someth­ ing different for Ins money, something that will give him a rewarding driving experience, is now aware that the Lotus is not beyond reach. 
There is another phenomenon at work in today s auto market. Certain exotic, unusual or special ears are not depre­ ciating in value; some are. in fact, selling for more today than when they were new tour or live years ago 

Example 
Smith cited the example of the now discontinued 
Lotus 
Europa 
The last 
Europa was built as a 1974 model, and was at one time selling new for sK.9ini A clean 
‘74 model today will bring &K.IMMI 
Of course, no one can guarantee what a used ear will bring in the future, but it is an interesting consideration

 small car. and by many standards the 
Lotus Elite is a small ear. but is is a very safe ear. It not only meets but in many eases exceeds by a substantial margin all current U.S. and European safety standards 

Wide protection 

Tile Lotus is sn designed that the body and chases provide the occupants a wide margin of protection iii the event of a collision, in May 1975 the E lite was iwarded the Don Safety Trophy. 
Lotus has completely reorganized its narketing in the U S to assure owners of skilled mechanical service and availabili­ ty of parts. 
While the Lotus Elite offers a lot for the pi t-.on who has occasion to carry more than two people, the Lotus Esprit, has a completely different character for those. who want a true sports ear 
But that s a different story, one that we will bring you in a future Road Report

San Antonio E X P R E S S - N E W S — Satu rd ay M arch 19 1977 
COLORFUL FUTURE 

( ontinind from Page I 

 back to ltlo*), tin- favorite color in tho auto industry was — you guessed it — light blue. So you sec definite color preference cycles not only company to company, bul throughout the industry as well 
“ In the early Utah's the most popular color was still black. Then in the late atis, 
I mids and early TIK other colors besides blue were unite popular, includim: boites and golds, rods and maroons and greens 
“ This year. the Chevrolet Corvette reintroduced black to the line for the first time in many years. Black is becoming more and more popular in smaller cars and is showing .strength iii the van. mini truck and pickup markets, One of our most visually exciting 77 Caprice models has a black exterior, gold side stripe, silver wheel covers and a beige interior." 
Moon added. 
Where do color stylists get their ideas? 
Listen to people 

“ We listen to a lot of people." Moon said. "paint experts/fashion designers, textile makers, and even our own Chev­ rolet dealers — very im portant links between tis and those who buy our pro­ ducts. 
“ One year we decided to elim in ate greens from color charts. But iii our first color review with dealers, we were told 

AUTOMOTJVt DISMAY 

 that green was a favorite of the nation's fleet buyers. Although it was only a three per cent color to us, it represented a great many potential car sales to our dealers 
The point reinforced a lesson we had once learned and forgotten — that the automobile market is highly diversified, and that a great variety of color tastes and needs must constantly be kept iii mind bv the color sty list 

Im portant source 
^ cording lo Moon, the nation's fashion industry has been an important source of color expertise as well. 
At a New York fashion show several years ago. we were greatly im pressed vv ii Ii a new line of color fashions featuring the maroon family. called ‘auburglne.* 
"W e bought an auburgine sport jacket. brought it home and developed several car interiors around it 
Besides being very popular, it alm ost becam e the number one car interior color that year." 
Another area offering great possibilities is interior fabric design for passenger cars. 
“ The bold, new geom etric patterns used iii the seat fabric of the 1977 Chev­ rolet ('hevette Sandpiper model is one of the more recent developm ents.'' Moon said 
"The new computerized fabric dyeing 

A U T O M O riv i OI AP! AY 

 technique developed by a South ( arolina firm is another. The process actually prints a design on raised fabric using hundreds of dye jots. The computer-con­ trolled jets place the dye in proper amounts deep down to the base of the fabric, resulting in a rich, colorful and textured finish. 
Less expensive 
"The new process is less expensive than the .lacquard-loom method, less tim e­ consuming and can print a complex de­ sign on any raised fabric without com­ pressing it," Moon said 
"The entire area of color painting and color fabric usage is exciting. We are on the threshold of revolutionary develop­ ments i i i this area." 
Keams of information 

SPACIAL TO THC f XPKtSS Nf WS 
DKTKOIT — The mushrooming paper mill arouses Chrysler s environmental vice president Sydney L. Terry. Environ­ ment Protection Agency regulations for emission level certification ran 14o pages in 1972 and Chryslers application totaled 
774 pages. EPA added 5(1 pages of regu­ lations and 167 pages of ancillary data by 
1975 Corporate response required 8.75K pages. In terms of cost. Chrysler’s ex­ penses were $2o million in 1972: $45 mil­ lion i i i 1975. 

AUTO TALK 

G E O R G E M O O N , standing behind color panels, points to the tone-on-tone color separation at the beltline of 1977 Chev­ rolet Caprice Classic sedan 

A O TO M O T'V * DISPLAY 

Continued from Page I 

 power windows, power seats, cruise con­ trol. AM/EM 8-track stereo, tilt steering wheel, electric sun roof and goodness knows what else, and still give 2o miles per gallon in city driving and 25 on the highway. 
And, oh yes, you would like to pay about 
$5 non for the car. certainly no more than 
$5,5oo 
Friends and neighbors, there ain t no such animal 

Compromise 

 lf you are buying a new car today — with one eye on the future and the other on your bank account — get ready to com­ promise. 
If you want top gas mileage, you can have it. lf you want a luxury automobile. von can have it If you want a big car. you can have it. If you want a small car. you can have it. But you can't have them all in one car. 
Cheaper 
There are some very good compromises on the showroom floors today, cars that will give better mileage than those you could buy two or three years ago, and like almost everything else they cost more than they did two or three years ago. 
I don't know when, if ever, gasoline will 

A U T O M O T iy* DISPLAY 

 reach 85 cents a gallon Even if it does. that will be a lot cheaper than most of the world can buy it, if that makes you feel anv better. 
. . . 
What I ani trying to say is that I don t know what is the best new ear for you to buy. I don't know what the conditions will be three, four or even five years from now when you will still be driving the new car you buy this year. 

What I do know is that people who come to me for advice don't want to hear what I tell them, don’t pay much attention any­ way and generally are disappointed that 
I can't tell them where to buy the above mentioned dream car. 

Surprised at quality 

I have talked with people who have bought new cars iii the past few months and most of them — and I do mean most of them — are pleased and surprised with the quality and performance of their new cars. lf you want to buy a new car, and you find one you like and can afford, buy it. 
If the price of gasoline has you worried, the Federal Energy Administration pub­ lishes a gas mileage guide that will give you tho Environmental Protection Agency ratings for all cars sold in the U. S.. 
For your guide write to Fuel Economy, 
Pueblo, Colo. 81oo9.

PARTIAL LISTING: Several high board beds, rocking choirs, 

 old desk choirs, dressers, chino cabinets, bookcase, secretory 

 desk, dining room tables, wooden plant stands, wooden 

 high chair, ond all kinds of assorted choirs. Carborundum 

 antique display case, assorted floor lamps, Phonolo crank 

 type record player. Brunswick 
Model 
1o1, Ponotrope, 

Rodiola radio, trunks of all sizes, shapes and makes, sad­ 

 dles, picture frames, all sizes, pictures, several very old bird 

 coges, with and without frames, mirrors, fireplace screens, 

 galvanized milk con, bells, small nail kegs, small iron doll 

 bed, much much more. 

GLASSWARE: Fruit bowls ond platters, cups and saucers, 

 vases, assorted sizes and colors, sherbert bowls with plates, 

 refrigerator bowls with lids, depression glassware, carnival 

 glassware, black milk glass plates, crystal glasses, salt and 

 pepper shakers, fruit jars, glass food choppers, antique 

 bells, iron skillets, muffins, dutch ovens, animal traps, 

 scales, assorted kerosene lamps, railroad lanterns, glass 

 lomp shades, 
2 kerosene lanterns, much more 

 miscellaneous.

 sow, paint sprayer, assorted screw drivers, electric drill, elec­ 

 tric motors, electric sander, hedge trimmer, hand drills, Pick 

 ox, 'ledge hammers, table grinder, pipe vise, assorted wood 

 planes, log sow, Skiis super duty saw Model 114, Hay hook, 

 assorted pulleys, butcher knives, pocket knives, wet stones,

 ding machines, portable typewriters, woter heaters, duck

ENGINEERS 

TRACoR. INC., Austin, Texas bos challenging career 

 openings for Electrical Engineers in its Applied 

Technology Division in Austin, Texas. The work in­ 

 volves design and development of airborne and 

 ground hosed digital communications terminals 

 ond related equipment for Military customers. A 

ISEE degree ond 3 to S years of design experience 

 with digital logic systems, minicomputer systems, 

 or microprocessor systems is required. Previous design experience for Military electronics systems 

 is preferred Assembly language programming ex­ 

 perience for minicomputeis or microprocessors is 

 desirable Send your resume ond salary history to: 

Personnel Manager, IIACQt, INC , 65oo TRACoR 
LANE, Austin, Texas 78721.

The only two incum­ bent city councilmen running against each other in the April 2 city election were each go­ ing for the o th e r’s jugular Friday. 
Reacting to a charge by Ford Nielsen of ex­ cessive absenteeism on his part. Phil Pyndus checked the record and claim ed Nielsen, in­ stead of leveling the charge, should be de­ fending against it. 
The record, signed by 
City 
C lerk 
Garland 
Jackson, reflects that 
Pyndus has attended 
12o of 127 City Council meetings between May 
I. 1975, and March 17, 

1977. 
But the record shows 
Nielsen attended only 
114 during the same period 
Transportation 

Nielsen, meanwhile, accused Pyndus of sup­ porting a h ill which would put the opera­ tional responsibility for public highways, streets and airports into the hands of the federal government. 
The accusation was made in a speech at a 
Friday luncheon. 
Nielsen said the bill would have taken con­ trol of San Antonio's transportation systems

PIC K ANO SH O V E L L A B O R . 

 out of city and county control 
Drainage 

The tim e is rig h t. 
Nielsen said, for San 
Antonio to solve its streets and drainage problems. 

Nielsen also said although District 8 is one of the fastest grow­ ing areas of the city, it doesn't have bus ser­ vice adequate to ac­ commodate that growth He pledged lie will work with the tran­ sit system to see bus service is extended into areas of the district not presently served. 

B illa Hays 
O' h e ’ll push d ra in a g e 

City Councilman Bob 
Billa, running for re­ election in District 3, told a grouj) of High­ land H ills residents 
Friday he wants to con­ tinue working for pro­ posed drainage projects in his district. 

"Some drainage pro­ jects are still in the study and planning stages," B illa said, 
"and I feel with my two years' experience on council and rn position as a member of the 197o and 1974 bond com­ mittee for street and drainage improvement gives me the best qua­ lifications for getting these projects im ple­ mented." 

He specifically said he favored construction of the Pollydale Drive •

Street drainage projects.

Mrs. Franklin Hicks, right, presents certificates to winners Friday of the 52nd annual Battle of Flowers Assn. Oratorical Contest at the Institute of Texan 
Cultures. Sylvia Green won second place and $ 1 7 5 , while Brian Carpenter placed first and received $ 3 o o . Carpenter will be the honored guest speaker during the Battle of Flowers luncheon April 21 during Fiesta.

 community leaders. 
The charge was made by Pablo Escamilla Jr., a trustee of the 
Edgewood School Dis­ trict, and John C. Do­ minguez, chairman of the 
C itizens 
Action 
Task Force 
They said 
Rohde should have taken ac­ tion in opposition of the proposed bunk reloca­ tion as early as Feb 12. rather than recently. 

The bunk's proposed move would be from 
C astroville 
Road to 
Bandera and Wurzbach roads. 
Escam illa and Do­ minguez said another 
District 6 City Council candidate, Jesse Diaz has acted in the best interest of District ti by bringing the plans of a possible move to the community’s attention and by appointing a task force to keep the hank 
Escam illa said the bank should stay at its present location be­ cause any new bank to replace it would not have as much lean re­ serve or capacity as the 
Kelly Field bunk. 

 was operating a cam­ paign headquarters in an 
" A " residential zone. 
That prompted Mrs. 
L. W 
(T in k e r) M ur­ dock to move the cam­ paign headquarters into the trunk of her ear, but former Constable Jack 
Brown, owner of the headquarters at 213o 
Chiliad Road prevailed on her to move back into the building, brown painted out the word "headquarters,” 
Subsequently, Brown was notified he couldn't park his truck and trailer on a paved lot he owns next door to the headquarters 
Departm ent of 
Building and Planning said "storage of com­ mercial equipment’’ is not permitted in an "A " residential zone. The truck had been parked only overnight. 
The third visit by De­ partment of Building and 
Planning came when Brown put his daughter’s ear on the lot with a "For Sale" sign on the windshield. 
The notification said sale of an auto iii an 
"A" residential zone is not permitted. 
Brown, who donated the headquarters to 
M rs.

Elizondo: Silence binding on SASO board in ouster 

Persons demanding to know why Deputy Supt. 
Henry Rodriguez’s con­ tract was not renewed know the board is bound to silence, board Presi­ dent W illiam Elizondo said Friday. 
Dr. Elizondo was re ­ sponding to protests from a group of San Antonio 
African coal to Florida 

W ASHINGTON POST SERVICE 
WASHINGTON 
- 
South African coal will be brought to the United 
States next month to fire two electrical plants on the west coast of Florida that are owned and oper­ ated by Gulf Power Go. 
The Gulf Coast electric com pany will im port 
5oo,ooo tons for the year s ta rtin g in A pril. 

 l f Mr. R od riguez dors 
UI ti link for a h i ’ii r ill g in 
IO days. his supporters must accept the fact he does not leant the rea­ sons aired' 

School District residents who threatened to stage a school boycott over the firing of Rodriguez. 
In a Ixia rd meeting last week, the school board voted 4-2 in executive session not to renew Ro­ driguez’s contract. 
Not policy 

No reasons for the dis­ missal were given at the meeting because Dr. Eli­ zondo said it was board policy not to discuss per­ sonnel in public. 
The resid en t’s group. w ho threatened Thursday to keep their children out 

 of J. T. B rac k en rid g e 
Elementary School, said they wanted to know the reason for the dismissal. 
“ U n d er the privacy rights granted to public em ployes, reasons for firing a person or not renewing a contract are kept confidential unless the person involved asks for a public h e a rin g ,’’ 
Dr. Elizondo said. 
Can request 
If Rodriguez wants the reasons for his termination made public, he can request a public hearing within Hi school days of the official notifi­ cation of his termination, the board president said 
“ If he does not ask for a public hearing within that time, then his sup­ porters must accept the fact that he does not want the reasons aired 

“ And they m ust r e ­ concile themselves to the fact that the choice was 
Mr. Rodriguez’s, not the board’s." he added. 

NEW LONDON, Tex. 
(AP) — Participants in one of the nation's most unusual class reunions gather here Saturday to recall that day 4o years ago when 2o9 fellow classmates and teachers were killed in the New 
London school explosion. 
“ It will be like a family reunion We have more in common than most class g ro u p s,” said 
John 
Baucum, an engineer for 
General Dynamics Corp. 
B aucum . 57, of F ort 
Worth, was a junior when the school exploded. His 
14-year-old sister was killed Authorities said an electrical sp ark touched off an accumula­ tion of natural gas in the school basement March 
18. 1937. 
“ I was in a classroom with 28 other students. 
Only nine in the room survived. The teacher was k illed ,” Baucum said. 
Too painful 

O rganizers of the reunion said two s u r ­ vivors would not attend because memories of that day are 
“ just too painful." 
“ The students in the building where the ex­ plosion occurred would have been dismissed at 
3:3o. The explosion, I recall, was at 3:2o," said 
G lorietta Shaffer, who lost her brother Gabe in the blast. 
Mrs. Shaffer said Gabe 

 had asked to stay home from school that day, but his mother refused. 
“ My m other blam ed herself for 
G ab e’s death.” she said. “ She never recovered and died four years later." 
She said former New 
London residents from 

Iowa. California, Loui­ siana and Oklahoma are planning to be here Sa turday, as well as a large number from Texas. 
“ We are expecting at least 15o for the dinner and as many as 45o for the memorial service,” 
Mrs. Shaffer said. 

The dinner will be at 
5 3o p.m . at Kilgore, about 12 miles away from 
New 
London. 
The m em orial serv ic e is scheduled at 2 p.m. at the site of the explosion, where the present school is still located 
At the time of the blast. 

 the death toll was higher than any explosion disas­ ter in history. Two sub­ sequent explosions, both at ports, surpassed the 
New London Fatality fig­ ures. 
The explosion was so tremendous that children were blow n 75 feet.

Now you can have a beautiful green lawn 

 without work or worry thanks to liquid fertilizers applied by a-Perm-o-Green. 

A greener lawn is what you’ll notice first— usually within IO to 14 days after we first spray your lawn. 
It will be greener because it is healthier. Greener because a-Perm-o-Green’s nutrients are promoting a deep root system and strong stems and blades. 
You’ll notice something else too, no chinch bug or grub worm problems because a-Perm-o-Green applies the correct insecticide at the right time— before damage is done. 
Join the thousands who are enjoying greener, healthier lawns thanks to a-Perm-o-Green applica­ tions last year. Your satisfaction is assured or you don’t owe us a cent. 

Why is a-Perm -o-G reen so effective? 

Your lawn is sprayed with liquid fertilizer specially prepared by a-Perm-o-Green to meet current soil, temperature and moisture conditions. 
Nutritional elements plus nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium are seasonally adjusted to promote the growth most beneficial at the time of application. 
Research proves that proper nutrition— rather than the soil itself— makes the difference between success and failure in creating a beautiful lawn. And creating beautiful lawns is what a-Perm-o-Green is all about. 

Average Cost? Less than $2o per application. 
Seems amazingly low, but a-Perm-o-Green is able to buy fertilizers and insecticides in quantity and pass the savings on to you. The average size lawn really 

 does average less than $2o per application— about the same as if you bought materials and applied them yourself (not counting the trips you’d make to the fertilizer store, the time and gamble over the correct mix to use, and the spreader equipment you’d have to rent or buy!) 

W hen do you join the p ro g ram ? Now! 
O ' ti c next few weeks our lawn care profes­ sionals will take the a-Perm-o-Green trucks out to spray this year’s first treatments on lawns throughout this area. 
Make sure your home is one of our first stops. Call us right now!
